(2)  Dogs must display current identification tags in the manner provided by section 6-44, and must be healthy, parasite free, and properly vaccinated, as required by chapter 6 of this Code. If requested by an animal control officer, owners must provide current vaccination and registration information. 
(3)  In the event of dog bite or injury, the owners must exchange current identification tag information, addresses, phone numbers, and any other information that may be helpful in locating the dog(s). If the dog bite involves a human, the incident must be reported immediately in accordance with Texas law by calling the city animal services division or city police department. 
(4)  No animals other than dogs are permitted in the dog park. 
(5)  No puppies under four (4) months of age are allowed in the dog park. 
(6)  A maximum of two (2) dogs per owner are permitted in the dog park at any one (1) time. 
(7)  Dogs must be leashed when entering or leaving the dog park and off-leash while inside of the dog park. 
(8)  Upon entering the dog park, dogs must be unleashed only after entering the double-gated holding areas, not while inside the off-leash areas of the dog park. The outside gate must remain closed while the inside gate is open. Upon exiting the off-leash area of the dog park, dogs must be leashed inside the double-gated holding areas prior to exiting the dog park. 
(9)  Dog handlers or owners must be at least twelve (12) years of age or older. 
(10)  Children under the age of twelve (12) years are prohibited from entering the dog park without adult supervision. 
(11)  Children are not allowed to run with or chase dogs in the dog park. 
(12)  Only dogs weighing thirty (30) pounds or less are allowed in the area designated for small dogs; however, the remainder of the dog park is open to dogs of all sizes, including dogs weighing thirty (30) pounds or less. 
(13)  Dogs that are aggressive, in heat, sick, or have open wounds are not allowed in the dog park. 
(14)  Owners are required to pick-up and dispose of their dog's feces both inside and outside of the dog park. 
(15)  No carriages, bicycles, skate boards, scooters, skates, roller blades, sport activities, children's toys, wading pools, or any motorized vehicles are allowed in the dog park, unless necessary by reason of handicap or disability. 
(16)  No smoking, alcoholic beverages, food, glass containers, or dog treats are allowed in the dog park. 
(17)  Digging is not allowed in the dog park. Owners must repair any damage caused by digging. If the owner fails to repair any damage caused by digging, the city may assess any damages and costs against the owner. 
(18)  Dog grooming is not permitted in the dog park. 
(19)  Owners must remain in the park and keep their dog in voice and sight control at all times. 
(20)  Spiked, prong, choke, or pinch collars are not allowed in the dog park. 
(21)  Shoes must be worn at all times in the dog park. 
(22)  Balls and plastic discs are the only toys allowed in the dog park; no other dog toys are allowed. 
(23)  No commercial use of the dog park is allowed, including dog training classes, solicitations and/or advertisements. 
(24)  Violators of this article may be subject to removal and suspension from the dog park, by the director of parks and recreation or his designee, or any animal control officer. 
(25)  Any dog designated, declared, or found to be a "dangerous dog" or "dangerous animal" in accordance chapter 6 of this Code, under state law, or under the ordinances of any governmental entity in this state is not allowed in the dog park. 
(26)  All other general park rules and city ordinances must be obeyed while using the dog park. 
(Ord. No. 2019-04, Pt. 1(Exh. A), 4-9-19) 
Sec. 6-74. - Signage. 
    The city shall post and maintain clearly readable sign(s) in a conspicuous location on or near the entrance area, which signs shall provide notice regarding: 
(1)  Hours of operation. 
(2)  The rules of regulations of the dog park. 
(3)  A statement limiting the liability of the city, such as: 
"Use of this park is at your own risk. Dog owners/handlers are responsible for the actions and behavior of their dogs and are liable for damages or injury inflicted by their dogs. The City of Sweetwater has no liability or responsibility for damage or injuries in the dog park. Park users assume all risk associated with use of the park and waive liability of the City of Sweetwater for any injury or damage caused by dogs or humans while accessing or using the park." 
(4)  The appropriate penalty provision. 
(5)  Contact information for the parks and recreation department and the Sweetwater Police Department 
(Ord. No. 2019-04, Pt. 1(Exh. A), 4-9-19) 
Chapter 7 - BUILDINGS AND CONSTRUCTION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) ---

Said sections pertained to building code, gas code, mechanical code and substandard buildings and derived from an ordinance adopted Mar. 13, 1973; § 1 of an ordinance adopted Oct. 30, 1975; §§ 1-5 of an ordinance adopted April 26, 1977; an ordinance adopted Sep. 29, 1981; Ord. No. 87-01, adopted Jan. 13, 1987; Ord. No. 89-04 adopted Feb 14, 1989; Ord. No. 89-06, Feb. 14, 1989; Ord. No. 89-07, adopted Feb. 14, 1989. Said Ord. State Law reference- General authority to regulate buildings, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 1175(25), (34); police power, Vernon's Ann. Civ. art. 1011. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 7-1. - Purpose. 
    It is the intent of this chapter to provide for the administration and enforcement of certain technical codes as may be adopted and amended for the purpose of establishing minimum standards, provisions and requirements to secure public safety, health and general welfare, including the protection of property, from fire and other hazards attributed to the built environment. 
(Ord. No. 93-03, 3-9-93) 
Sec. 7-2. - Definitions. 
    Building official shall mean the officer or other designated authority, or their duly authorized representative, charged with the administration and enforcement of this chapter. 
    Built environment: Any construction, alteration, repair, maintenance, removal or demolition, location, use and occupancy of every building or structure, including equipment and every electrical, gas, mechanical, and plumbing system within the corporate limits of the City of Sweetwater. 
    Department of law shall mean city attorney. 
    Homeowner: As the term applies to this chapter, homeowner shall mean any person who owns a single-family residential dwelling unit, who does or intends to use such dwelling unit as their primary residence and homestead. 
    Secretary shall mean that person appointed by the building official to serve as secretary to the board of adjustments. 
(Ord. No. 93-03, 3-9-93; Ord. No. 2001-04, 5-8-01) 
Sec. 7-3. - Fire districts. 
(a)  The city commission of the City of Sweetwater may, from time to time, adopt by ordinance boundaries establishing new or amending existing fire districts or zones within the corporate limits of the city for which special construction requirements are necessitated due to the specific characteristics of an area such as, but not limited to, zoning regulations or congestive development. 
(b)  The fire limit ordinance adopted and enacted March 11, 1929, defining such fire limits and establishing the territory contained therein, a copy of which is on file in the city secretary's office and the building official's office, is hereby designated as the First Fire District and is hereby incorporated herein by reference and made part of this code as fully as if copied at length. 
(Ord. No. 93-03, 3-9-93; Ord. No. 2001-02, 2-15-01; Ord. No. 2001-04, 5-8-01) 
Cross reference- Fire prevention and protection, § 10-20. 
Sec. 7-4. - Permits. 
(a)  Permits for any work for which regulations are established by a federal, state or municipal license act, law or ordinance shall be issued only to persons duly licensed pursuant to the applicable license act, law or ordinance and, to homeowners, as defined in this chapter, who themselves will perform such work on the single-family residence qualifying them as homeowner. 
(b)  Persons applying for a homeowners permit may be required to sign an affidavit showing ownership of the property and his/her bona fide intention to live in the residence and that he/she has not secured a homeowners permit for any other street address within the last two (2) years prior to the application. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to make any installation, alteration or repair of any building, structure, or appurtenancy thereto, for which a permit is required, without first obtaining the proper permit or permission from the building official prior to commencing work. 
(d)  When a person, company, firm, partnership or corporation fails to obtain a required permit or prior permission from the building official before commencing work on any job or project, such person, officer(s) or agent(s) actively in charge of the work being performed shall be liable for a double charge for the permit in addition to any other punitive action taken by the city. 
(Ord. No. 93-03, 3-9-93; Ord. No. 2001-04, 5-8-01) 
Sec. 7-5. - Notice of violation(s)/stop-work orders. 
(a)  Upon notice from the building official, work on any building, structure, electrical, gas, mechanical or plumbing system that is being done contrary to the provisions of this Code or in a dangerous or unsafe manner, shall immediately cease. Such notice shall be in writing and may be made by certified mail or may be posted at the job site, notifying the owner, agent, or the person doing the work, stating the violation(s) and the conditions under which work may resumed. 
(b)  If, after receiving a stop-work order form the building official, any person fails or refuses to cease such work pending an appeal, if any, or fails or refuses to make the corrective measures pursuant to the stop work order, such failure or refusal shall constitute a misdemeanor and the building official may cause a summons to be issued without additional notice. 
(Ord. No. 93-03, 3-9-93; Ord. No. 2001-04, 5-8-01) 
Sec. 7-6. - Appeals. 
    The board of adjustments established in section 13 of Appendix A, Zoning Ordinance of the City of Sweetwater is hereby vested with the powers, duties and procedures of the electrical board and the construction board of adjustments and appeals referenced in the technical codes herein adopted. 
(Ord. No. 93-03, 3-9-93; Ord. No. 2001-04, 5-8-01) 
Sec. 7-7. - Penalties. 
    Any person who violates any of the provisions of this chapter shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punishable as provided in section 1-11 of this Code. In any case in which a violation of any of the terms or provisions of this chapter is by a firm, association, partnership or corporation, then the officers or agents actively in charge shall be subject to the penalty herein provided. 
(Ord. No. 93-03, 3-9-93) 
Secs. 7-8-7-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - BUILDING CODE 

Sec. 7-16. - Code adopted. 
(a)  The specifications, rules and regulations entitled International Residential Code, 2012 Edition thereof, as published by the International Code Council Inc., a copy of which is on file in the building official's office, is hereby enacted and adopted as the residential code for one- and two-family dwellings for the city, and is hereby incorporated herein by reference and made part of this Code as fully as copied at length, except insofar as it may be inconsistent with specific provisions of this chapter. 
(b)  The specifications, rules and regulations entitled International Building Code, 2012 Edition thereof, as published by the International Code Council, Inc., a copy which is on file in the building officials office, is hereby enacted and adopted as the building code for all other structures not listed in subsection (a) of this section, for the city, and is hereby incorporated herein by reference and made part of this Code as fully as if copied at length, except insofar as it may be inconsistent with specific provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 93-03, 3-9-93; Ord. No. 2001-04, 5-8-01; Ord. No. 2001-14, 12-11-01; Ord. No. 2008-02, 2-12-08; Ord. No. 2013-11, 5-14-13) 
Cross reference- Gas code adopted, § 7-31; mechanical code adopted, § 7-46; plumbing code adopted, § 7-61; electrical code adopted, § 9-196; Fire prevention code adopted, § 10-1; housing code adopted, § 15-1. 
Sec. 7-17. - Changes and additions to adopted building code. 
    The building code adopted by the provisions of this article is hereby amended so as to include, or, so as the following shall supersede when in the contradiction thereof: 
(1)  Moving of buildings. All buildings moved into the city limits from without, or relocated within, shall conform to all the rules, regulations and provisions of the Sweetwater Code of Ordinances, including zoning. Before any permits are granted for such moves, excluding pre-manufactured units such as mobile homes, an inspection of said building shall be required to be performed by the city building inspection department, and all code discrepancies noted therefrom shall mandate correction as a condition of the issuance of such permits. Inspections required to be performed outside the city limits shall require a fee, as established from time to time by the city commission to be paid in advance by the applicant. 
(2)  Bond required. Before any person, firm or corporation shall engage in the business of moving structures into, out of or within the city, such entity shall first obtain the proper permit and deposit with the city a good and sufficient bond in the sum of fifteen hundred dollars ($1,500.00) to be approved by the city attorney, conditioned that the person, firm or corporation engaged in the moving of structures will faithfully observe all laws pertaining to that activity, and further that the city shall be indemnified and saved harmless from all claims arising from accidents and damages of any character whatsoever caused by the negligence of such person, firm or corporation engaged in the moving of structures, or by any other unfaithful or inadequate work done, either by themselves or their agents or employees. 
(3)  Registration required. Before any person, firm or corporation shall move any structure into, out of, or within the city, the party who intends to perform the moving shall register such intent at the code enforcement office at city hall, providing the following: original copy of the bond described in (2) above; the date and time of the intended move; the address of origin and destination; the route; the name of the owner of the property; and the current fee required as determined by the city commission. 
(4)  Plans and specifications. Plans, and specifications when required by the building official, shall be required on all new buildings and structures to be constructed within the corporate limits of the city. Such plans and specifications shall also be required for additions or alterations to existing buildings or structures when deemed necessary by the building official. All plans and specifications shall bear the name and signature of the person responsible for the design. The use of design professionals shall be in accordance with the adopted building code unless exempted by some specific state or federal law. All plans and specifications submitted under such exemption shall bear a certification by the applicant of the specific applicability of such exemption which permits the preparation by a person not so registered. 
(5)  Concrete or masonry foundation walls/concrete footings and floorslabs. All foundation walls and concrete footings which support load bearing walls shall contain sufficient horizontal and vertical metal reinforcement, as approved by the building official, or shall be designed by a structural engineer utilizing applicable ASTM standards listed in ACI 318 along with the adopted building code. All floor slabs shall contain sufficient horizontal metal reinforcement, as approved by the building official, or shall be designed by an engineer utilizing applicable ASTM standards listed in ACI 318 along with the adopted building code. 
(6)  Building permit fees. A schedule of permit fees shall be established from time to time by the city commission. 
(7)  Permits of use of public ways. Building permits shall not include permission to occupy any part of public streets, sidewalks, alleys or public property of any kind with building materials or equipment without first obtaining written permission from the city manager and obtaining a permit for the use of public property from the building official's office before operations have commenced. Such permit shall be for the duration of construction or such lesser time as the city manager may determine. 
(8)  Unsafe buildings or systems shall be abated in accordance with article VI of this chapter. 
(9)  Arc-fault circuit-interrupter protection may be used in dwelling units in accordance with the International Residential Code, 2012 Edition. 
(10)  Subsections, of the International Residential Code 2012 Edition, 105.2 subparagraphs 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 10 are deleted in their entirety; R313 is deleted in its entirety. 
(11)  Subsections, of the International Building Code 2012 Edition, 105.1.1, 1051.2 are deleted in their entirety; 105.2 subparagraphs 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 8, 10 are deleted in their entirety; 903.2.8 shall not apply to one (1), two (2), three (3) and four (4) family dwelling units one story in height or split level units, however, it shall apply to multi-story units. 
(Ord. No. 93-03, 3-9-93; Ord. No. 2013-11, 5-14-13; Ord. No. 2015-01, 2-10-15) 
Secs. 7-18-7-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - GAS CODE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Plumbing, § 7-61 et seq.; Oil and gas, § 22-1 et seq.; tax on residential gas, § 27-10. 

Sec. 7-31. - Code adopted. 
    The specifications, rules and regulations entitled International Fuel Gas Code, 2012 Edition thereof, as published by the International Code Council, Inc., a copy of which is on file in the building official's office, is hereby enacted and adopted as the natural gas code for the city, and is hereby incorporated herein by reference and made part of this Code as fully if copied in length, except insofar as it may be inconsistent with the specific provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 93-03, 3-9-93; Ord. No. 2001-04, 5-8-01; Ord. No. 2008-02, 2-12-08; Ord. No. 2013-11, 5-14-13) 
Cross reference- Building code adopted, § 7-16; mechanical code adopted, § 7-46; plumbing code adopted, § 7-61; electrical code adopted, 9-196; fire prevention code adopted, § 10-1; housing code adopted, § 15-1. 
Sec. 7-32. - Changes and additions to adopted natural gas code. 
    The natural gas code adopted by the provisions of this article is hereby amended so as to include or, so as the following shall supersede when in contradiction thereof: 
(a)  Gas permit fees. Schedule of permit fees shall be established from time to time by the city commission. 
(b)  Stop work order. Section 7-5 applies. 
(c)  Bond or certificate of insurance. Before any person, firm or corporation shall engage in the business of natural gas piping in the city, such entity or person shall first be licensed by the Texas State Board of Plumbing Examiners as a master plumber. The master plumber shall provide the Texas State Board of Plumbing Examiners with certificate of insurance, written by a company licensed to do business in this state, which provides coverage of not less than three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00) for all claims arising in a one-year period and must be on file with the state; Or shall obtain with the City of Sweetwater a good sufficient bond in the sum of fifteen hundred dollars ($1,500.00) to be approved by the city attorney, conditioned that the person, firm or corporation engaged in the natural gas plumbing business will faithfully observe all laws pertaining to natural gas plumbing, blasting and excavating, further that the city shall be indemnified and saved harmless from all claims arising from accidents and damages of any character whatsoever caused by the negligence of such person, firm or corporation engaged in the natural gas plumbing business, or by any other unfaithful or inadequate work done, either by themselves or their agents or employees, and that such person, firm or corporation will maintain in a safe condition for a period of one (1) year all ditches and excavations which may be opened in the performance of any natural gas plumbing and future that all dirt and other material excavated will be replaced in good condition with similar materials. Where such excavation is made in an unpaved street, or any street, paved with chert or macadam, the word street as herein used shall apply to sidewalks, curbs, gutters and street paving. 
(d)  Consumer's natural gas piping. 
(1)  All natural gas piping extending from the point of delivery (metering device) and outside a structure (yard line) shall be installed at a minimum depth of eighteen (18) inches below grade level and shall be of type black steel pipe, corrugated stainless steel tubing, or polyethylene pipe (tube) utilizing approved metal risers. All metal piping, risers and fittings installed below grade level shall be protected against soil corrosion with an approved type protective coating. Yard service lines shall have an accessible cut-off located above grade level, outside and adjacent to the structure which it serves when the point of delivery is three (3) feet or more from the point where such piping enters a structure. 
(2)  The gas piping within structures shall be of type black steel pipe, corrugated stainless steel tubing, brass, or aluminum tubing and shall be located in accessible and ventilated spaces. No gas piping shall be imbedded in brick, stone, masonry or concrete and no such piping shall be installed on or in the ground under any building or structure. All exposed gas piping shall be kept at least six (6) inches above grade. 
(e)  Test and clearance required to connect gas supply. 
(1)  It shall be unlawful for any person or any public service company serving the city to connect a natural gas supply to a consumer's premises of any nature, kind or description without first obtaining a clearance from the city building official's office. This shall mean that any time the physical continuity between a purveyor's and consumer's gas piping system has yet to be established or has been disconnected, or continuity of the consumer's gas piping system is interrupted, a test of the consumer's gas piping system shall be performed for tightness and a certification from the building official's office verifying performance of a satisfactory test shall be required before gas is supplied to the system. 
(2)  The test on consumer's gas piping shall be made by closing all openings and subjecting the pipes to an air pressure of at least twenty (20) pounds-per-square-inch or an air pressure that will support a column of mercury ten (10) inches in height, for a period of at least fifteen (15) minutes with no evident drop in pressure. 
(Ord. No. 93-03, 3-9-93; Ord. No. 2001-04, 5-8-01; Ord. No. 2008-02, 2-12-08) 
Secs. 7-33-7-45. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - MECHANICAL CODE 

Sec. 7-46. - Code adopted. 
    The specifications, rules and regulations entitled International Mechanical Code, 2012 Edition thereof, as published by the International Code Council, Inc., a copy of which is on file in the building official's office is hereby enacted and adopted as the mechanical code for the city, and is and hereby incorporated herein by reference and made part of this Code, as fully as if copied at length, except insofar as it may be inconsistent with the specific provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 93-03, 3-9-93; Ord. No. 2001-04, 5-8-01; Ord. No. 2008-02, 2-12-08; Ord. No. 2013-11, 5-14-13)

Sec. 7-47. - Registration required. 
    All air conditioning and/or refrigeration contractors shall register with the city building official's office by providing a copy of the proper Texas State License and Certificate of Insurance, prior to doing any mechanical work within the corporate limits of the city. 
(Ord. No. 93-03, 3-9-93) 
Sec. 7-48. - Permit fees. 
    Schedule of permit fees shall be established from time to time by the city commission. 
(Ord. No. 93-03, 3-9-93) 
Sec. 7-49. - Maintenance of environmental air conditioning, commercial refrigeration, and process cooling or heating systems. 
(a)  Maintenance, as the term applies to this article, shall mean the keeping of existing environmental air conditioning, commercial refrigeration, and process cooling or heating systems in a safe repair and operating condition by means of repairing or replacing constituent parts, such as but not limited to: aquastats, blowers, burners, compressors, contractors, filters, gauges, pressure regulators, pumps, motors, switches, thermostats, or valves, with identical replacement parts. Such constituent parts shall be limited to parts and other appurtenances designed to be repairable or replaceable without disconnecting or replacing the entire assembled unit to which it is in, on, or subordinate. 
(b)  Maintenance shall not be construed to allow any extension, alteration, addition, modification, replacement, or installation of major components, equipment, unit assemblies, or other listed appliances, such as but not limited to: boilers, furnaces, condensing units, air handlers, heat pumps or any other work for which a permit and inspection is required. 
(Ord. No. 93-03, 3-9-93) 
Secs. 7-50-7-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - PLUMBING CODE[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) ---

Cross reference- Buildings generally, § 7-1 et seq.; gas code, § 7-31 et seq.; plumbing inspector to inspect all buildings moved into or from one place to another within the city, § 9-198; requirement that mobile homes be inspected by plumbing inspector, § 9-212; housing generally, § 15-1 et seq.; lakes and watercourses, § 16-1 et seq.; water and sewage installations in new subdivisions, § 26-48 et seq.; water and wastewater, § 29-1 et seq. 

Sec. 7-61. - Code adopted. 
    The specifications, rules and regulations entitled International Plumbing Code, 2012 Edition thereof, as published by the International Code Council, Inc., a copy of which is on file in the building official's office, is hereby enacted and adopted as the plumbing code for the city, and hereby incorporated herein by reference and made part of this Code as fully as if copied at length, except insofar as it may be inconsistent with the specific provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 93-03, 3-9-93; Ord. No. 2001-04, 5-8-01; Ord. No. 2008-02, 2-12-08; Ord. No. 2013-11, 5-14-13) 
Cross reference- Building code adopted, § 7-16; gas code adopted, § 7-31; mechanical code adopted, § 7-46. 
Sec. 7-62. - Changes and additions to adopted plumbing code. 
    The plumbing code adopted by the provisions of this article is hereby amended so as to include, or, so as the following shall supersede when in contradiction thereof: 
(a)  Stop work orders. Section 7-5 applies. 
(b)  Bond or certificate of insurance. Before any person, firm or corporation shall engage in the business of plumbing in the city, such entity or person shall first be licensed by the Texas State Board of Plumbing Examiners as a master plumber. The master plumber shall provide the Texas State Board of Plumbing Examiners with certificate of insurance, written by a company licensed to do business in this state, which provides coverage of not less than three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00) for all claims arising in a one-year period and must be on file with the state; or shall obtain with the City of Sweetwater a good and sufficient bond in the sum of fifteen hundred dollars ($1500.00) to be approved by the city attorney, conditioned that the person, firm or corporation engaged in the plumbing business will faithfully observe all laws pertaining to plumbing, drain laying, blasting and excavating, further that the city shall be indemnified and saved harmless from all claims arising from accidents and damages of any character whatsoever caused by the negligence of such person, firm or corporation engaged in the plumbing business, or by any other unfaithful or inadequate work done, either by themselves or their agents or employees, and that such person, firm or corporation will maintain in a safe condition for a period of one (1) year all ditches and excavations which may be opened in the performance of any plumbing and further that all dirt and other material excavated will be replaced in good condition with similar materials. Where such excavation is made in an unpaved street, or any street, paved with chert or macadam, the word street as herein used shall apply to sidewalks, curbs, gutters and street paving. 
(c)  Water service piping. 
(1)  Materials for consumers' underground water service pipe and lawn irrigation systems shall be copper water tube minimum type-M, brass, or a listed pressure-rated plastic. Galvanized steel pipe may only be used for vertical risers serving yard hose bibs in new service lines when the portion of the underground piping is fully insulated, and for minor repairs of existing galvanized service lines. 
(2)  All new or replaced consumers' water service pipe (yard lines) shall have an accessible main shut-off valve provided on the consumers' premises, located in the service pipe outside the building and ahead of the first outlet or branch connection to the service or distribution piping. The shut-off valve shall be accessible from a readily removable access cover which extends to grade level. 
(d)  Water distribution piping. 
(1)  Except when paragraph (d)(2) applies, materials for consumers' water distribution pipe shall be copper water tube minimum type-M, brass, stainless steel water tube minimum Grade H for above ground use only, or a listed pressure-rated plastic. 
(2)  Water distribution piping in or under concrete floor slabs shall be copper water tubing type-L or type-K, or cross-linked polyethylene (PEX) plastic tubing. Copper or PEX tubing shall be continuous through the floor, having no fittings or joints below the surface of the floor. Copper tubing shall be sleeved at all points where susceptible to abrasion, corrosion, or other physical damage. PEX tubing shall be sleeved with an approved material one (1) pipe size larger than the PEX tubing being utilized, for each full run in or under the slab, so that the PEX tubing may be pulled through the sleeve after the slab has been poured. 
(e)  Main vent stack or stack vent. 
(1)  Every building in which plumbing is installed shall have at least one (1) main vent stack or stack vent, of not less than three (3) inches in diameter, for each building drain, when connected separately to a building sewer, septic tank, or other disposal system approved by the plumbing official. Such vent shall run undiminished in size and as directly as possible from the building drain through to the open air above the roof. 
(Ord. No. 93-03, 3-9-93; Ord. No. 2001-04, 5-8-10; Ord. No. 2008-02, 2-12-08; Ord. No. 2013-11, 5-14-13) 
Sec. 7-63. - Permit fees. 
    Schedule of permit fees shall be established from time to time by the city commission. 
(Ord. No. 2001-04, 5-8-01) 
Secs. 7-64-7-75. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - SUBSTANDARD STRUCTURES[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Charter reference- Authority of city commission to direct removal of dilapidated buildings, Art. III, § 19. 
Cross reference- Unsightly, hazardous structures in the city cemetery, § 8-25; dilapidated buildings declared a nuisance, § 21-2. 

Sec. 7-76. - Minimum standards for continued use and occupancy. 
    Regardless of the date of their construction, all structures within the city shall meet the following standards for continued use and occupancy: 
(a)  Structural standards. An owner shall: 
(1)  Keep the doors, windows and other openings of a vacant structure or vacant portion of a structure securely closed to prevent unauthorized entry. A vacant structure or vacant portion of a structure is open if a door, window, or other opening is not securely closed to prevent unauthorized entry, and the structure is left unattended; 
(2)  Provide and maintain railings for stairs, steps, balconies, porches and elsewhere as specified in the Sweetwater Building Code; 
(3)  Protect the exterior of a structure which is subject to decay, by application of paint or other coating; 
(4)  Repair holes, cracks and other defects so that the structure is maintained in such a condition that persons coming in or about the structure are not in danger of injury; 
(5)  Maintain a structure intended for human occupancy in a weather-tight and water-tight condition. This standard shall be applicable regardless of whether there are actual inhabitants of the structure; 
(6)  Maintain floors, walls, ceilings, and all supporting structural members in a sound condition, capable of bearing imposed loads safely; 
(7)  Provide and maintain corrosion resistant screening of one-quarter-inch mesh over all exterior air ventilation openings of a structure to prevent birds and vermin from entering; 
(8)  Provide sufficient exterior doors and windows to meet egress requirements and maintain such means of egress in proper operating (easily openable) condition; 
(9)  Repair or replace chimney flue and vent attachments that do not function properly; 
(10)  Repair holes, cracks, breaks and loose surface materials that are health or safety hazards in or on floors, walls and ceilings; and 
(11)  Provide and maintain a moisture resistant finish or material for the flooring or subflooring of each bathroom, shower room and toilet room. 
(b)  Utility standards. An owner shall: 
(1)  Provide and maintain in operating condition a sanitary drain, waste and vent to discharge sewage from a structure requiring plumbing fixtures, into a public sewer system where available; 
(2)  Provide and maintain in operating condition a toilet connected to a water source and to a public sewer, where available, in each structure intended for human habitation; 
(3)  Provide and maintain in operating condition connections and pipes to supply potable water at adequate pressure to a structure intended for human habitation; 
(4)  Provide and maintain in operating condition a device to supply hot water of a minimum temperature of one hundred twenty (120) degrees Fahrenheit within each structure intended for human habitation; 
(5)  Provide and connect a kitchen sink, bathtub, or shower and lavatory to a hot and cold water source in each structure intended for human habitation; and 
(6)  Provide and maintain in safe operating condition electrical service equipment, circuits and appurtenances sufficient to carry a load imposed by normal use of appliances and fixtures in each structure intended for human habitation. 
(c)  Fire prevention. All structures shall be in such a condition, and must be maintained in such a condition, as not to constitute a fire hazard and in such a condition so not to constitute an unreasonable risk of fire. 
(d)  Health standards. An owner shall: 
(1)  Provide a structure intended for human habitation with a screen as specified in subsection (a)(7) of this section, for keeping out insects at each opening of a structure if the structure is not cooled with refrigerated air; 
(2)  Maintain the interior of a vacant structure or vacant portion of a structure free from rubbish and garbage; and 
(3)  Provide and maintain a structure in such a condition so as not to constitute a menace to health or safety, including all conditions conducive to the harboring of rats or mice or other disease-carrying animals or insects or birds that are likely to spread disease. 
(e)  Responsibilities of occupant. The occupant shall: 
(1)  Maintain those premises and portions of a structure under his/her supervision and control free from rubbish, garbage and other conditions that would encourage infestation of insects, rodents or vermin; 
(2)  Remove an animal or animals from a structure if the presence of the animal or animals is a health hazard to an occupant; and 
(3)  Not alter a structure or its facilities so as to create a nonconformity with subsections (a), (b), (c), or (d). 
Cross reference- Fire prevention and protection generally, § 10-1 et seq. 
(Ord. No. 93-03, 3-9-93) 
Sec. 7-77. - Inspections. 
    An inspection shall be made of every building located within the city which is suspected of being in violation of this article. Such inspection shall be conducted by the fire marshal or building official. 
(Ord. No. 93-03, 3-9-93) 
Sec. 7-78. - Notice of public hearing. 
    When, as a result of the inspection referred to in section 7-77, a structure is found to be in noncompliance with one (1) or more of the minimum standards of section 7-76 and the structure is an urban nuisance, the following actions shall apply: 
(1)  Written notification of the nature of the violation shall be made to the owner. The notice may be delivered in person to the owner or may be delivered by the United States Postal Service, certified mail, return receipt requested. If the identity or address of the owner cannot be determined, then such notice shall be directed to the person listed on the rolls of the city tax assessor as the person in charge of the premises and to whom tax notices are directed. The notice shall contain an identification of the structure and the property on which it is located and designate a time and place for a public hearing before the city commission for the purpose of determining whether the structure is, in fact, dilapidated, substandard, dangerously damaged or deteriorated, unfit for human habitation, or a hazard to public health, safety and welfare to the extent that it requires repair, securing, vacating, removal or demolition. 
(2)  Notice may also be given so as to inform all persons who may have legal interest in the structure or the property on which the structure is located, of the public hearing by publication three (3) times before the fifteenth day before the date of the hearing in a newspaper of general circulation in the municipality. In addition to the contents of the written notice, described in (a)(1) of this subsection, the publicized notice shall state that unless persons having interest in the structure or the property on which the structure is located make their identity, mailing address, and interest known to the city code enforcement office at or before the public hearing, then such person shall not receive notice of the city commission's order concerning the structure, if any, and furthermore, shall waive any right to any additional time to comply with any commission order in the event an owner fails to comply. 
(Ord. No. 93-03, 3-9-93) 
Sec. 7-79. - Public hearing. 
    A public hearing shall be held by the city commission after the notice required by section 7-78. At the public hearing, it shall be the duty of the city attorney to present evidence to the city commission concerning the condition of the structure in question. An owner, lessor, occupant, mortgagee, lienholder, as well as any interested person, may present evidence on relevant issues. All evidence shall be given under oath. At the conclusion of the hearing, the city commission shall make its findings and may: 
(a)  Find that the structure is not an urban nuisance and refer the matter to the city code enforcement officer for further appropriate action; or 
(b)  Find that the structure is an urban nuisance, and order: 
(1)  The structure be vacated; 
(2)  Relocation of the structure's occupants; 
(3)  Securing the structure; 
(4)  Repair of the structure; 
(5)  Demolition of the structure; 
(6)  Assessment of a civil penalty against the owner for each day or part of a day that the owner fails to repair, secure, remove, correct or demolish the structure; 
(7)  Any combination of orders listed above necessary to remedy the urban nuisance; or 
(8)  An action brought in district court in accordance with section 214.003 of the Texas Local Government Code for the appointment of a receiver of the property. 
    Regardless of the order issued under this subsection, the city commission shall specify a reasonable time, as determined by the commission, for the owner to comply with the order. Any mortgagee or lienholder who shall make their identity known at or before the hearing, shall be granted an additional reasonable time, not to exceed the specified time granted the owner, to comply with the order in the event the owner fails to comply. 
(Ord. No. 93-03, 3-9-93) 
Sec. 7-80. - Abatement; other remedies. 
(a)  Demolition of a structure in accordance with section 7-85 of this article may be accomplished by an owner, mortgagee or lienholder as compliance with this article, or by the city; 
(b)  Closure (securing) of an open (unsecured) structure in accordance with section 7-84 of this article may be accomplished by an owner, mortgagee or lienholder as compliance with this article, or by the city; 
(c)  Repair of a structure may be accomplished by an owner, mortgagee, or lienholder as compliance with this article, or by the city but, only to the extent necessary to bring the structure into compliance with minimum standards and only if the structure is a residential structure with less than ten (10) dwelling units. 
(d)  If, at the expiration of the time allotted to an owner to comply with an order issued under section 7-79, the order has not been fully accomplished, then the city code enforcement officer shall: 
(1)  Furnish all identified mortgagees and lienholders with a copy of the order so that such mortgagees or lienholders may comply with the order within a reasonable time, as specified by the city commission. No other notice is required to be given to any mortgagee or lienholder; 
(2)  Give notice of impending demolition or repair by the city, or the assessment of a civil penalty, to the owner, if the code enforcement officer determines that the owner has not complied with an order issued under section 7-79. If the order required the securing of a structure, an impending notice shall not be required prior to closure by the city; and 
(3)  Cause the structure to be vacated, secured, removed, repaired, demolished, or the occupants relocated, at the expense of the city. 
(Ord. No. 93-03, 3-9-93) 
Sec. 7-81. - Assessment of city's expenses; billing. 
    Expenses incident to the action taken by the city to correct any condition coming under the provisions of this article, including a service charge, as established from time to time by the city commission, to cover administrative costs, shall be assessed against the owners of all outstanding interests in the lot or parcel of land on which the structure stands or stood, or to which it is or was attached. An itemized bill of such costs shall be mailed by the city secretary to each such owner if such person's address is known. 
(Ord. No. 93-03, 3-9-93) 
Sec. 7-82. - City's expenses declared as lien; recovery. 
(a)  If the bill for the city's expenses in correcting any condition coming under the provisions of this article, including the administrative charges and the assessment of any civil penalty, shall remain unpaid for a period of thirty (30) days after the date of the mailing of such bill, the city accountant shall file a statement of such bill as a notice of lien with the county clerk. Such filing shall constitute a non-transferable lien against the real property on which the structure stands or stood, unless it is a homestead as protected by the Texas Constitution, and the lien runs with the land. The lien is extinguished if the property owner or another person having an interest in the legal title to the property reimburses the municipality for the expenses. The lien arises and attaches to the property at the time the notice of the lien is recorded and indexed in the office of the county clerk in the county in which the property is located. The notice must contain the name and address of the owner, if reasonably determinable; a legal description of the real property; the amount of expenses incurred by the city; and the balance due. The city's lien for abatement expenses is a privileged lien subordinate only to tax liens and all previously recorded bona fide mortgage liens attached to the property, if each mortgagee and lienholder is given notice and an opportunity to repair, remove, or demolish the structure. 
(b)  Any civil penalty or other assessment imposed under this article shall accrue interest at the rate of ten (10%) per annum from the date of the assessment until paid in full. 
(Ord. No. 93-03, 3-9-93) 
Sec. 7-83. - Additional authority regarding substandard structures. 
(a)  In accordance with Section 214.0011 of the Texas Local Government Code, the city may secure a structure without prior notification or city commission determination if the city code enforcement officer determines that the structure is: 
(1)  In noncompliance with one (1) or more of the minimum standards listed in section 7-76 of this article; and 
(2)  Unoccupied or occupied only by persons who do not have a right of possession to the building. 
(b)  Before the eleventh day after the date the structure is secured, the city code enforcement officer shall give notice to the owner by: 
(1)  Personally serving the owner with a written notice; 
(2)  Depositing the notice in the United States mail addressed to the owner at the owner's post office address; 
(3)  Publishing the notice at least twice within a ten-day period in a newspaper of general circulation in the county in which the structure is located if personal service cannot be obtained at the owner's post office address is unknown; or 
(4)  Posting the notice on or near the front door of the building if personal service cannot be obtained and the owner's post office address is unknown. 
(c)  The written notice must contain: 
(1)  An identification, which is not required to be a legal description, of the building and the property on which it is located; 
(2)  A description of the violation of the municipal standards that is present at the building; 
(3)  A statement that the municipality will secure, or has secured, as the case may be, the building; and 
(4)  An explanation of the owner's entitlement to request a hearing about any matter relating to the municipality's securing of the building. 
(d)  The city commission shall conduct a hearing at which the owner may testify or present witnesses or written information about any matter relating to the municipality's securing of the building if, within thirty (30) days after the date the municipality secures the building, the owner files with the city secretary a written request for the hearing. The city commission shall conduct the hearing within twenty (20) days after the date the request is filed. 
(e)  The city shall have the same authority to assess expenses under this section, and a lien is created under this section in the same manner that a lien is created under section 7-82 of this article and is subject to the same conditions as a lien created under that section. 
(f)  The following items are pursuant to Article 1175 of Vernon's Annotated Civil Statutes of Texas: 
(1)  An action may be brought under this act to compel the repair or demolition of a structure and, in the alternative, for a determination of the city's right to remove the structure and for recovery of the removal costs incurred by the city. The action may also include a claim for civil penalties as provided by Article 1175 of Vernon's Annotated Civil Statutes. 
In connection with the action, the city may file a notice of lis pendens in the office of the county clerk and, if the city files a notice, any subsequent purchaser or mortgagee who acquires an interest in the property takes the property subject to the enforcement proceeding and all subsequent orders of the court. 
(2)  The city may obtain, upon showing a substantial danger of injury or adverse health impact to any person or to any property of any person other than the defendant, an injunction against the owner or owner's representative with control over the premises that: 
a.  Prohibits specified future conduct in violation of the ordinance; and 
b.  Requires specific conduct necessary to achieve compliance with the ordinance. 
(3)  The city may recover in a suit against the owner or owner's representative with control over the premises a civil penalty not to exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) a day for a violation of an ordinance to which Article 1175 of Vernon's Annotated Civil Statutes applies, on proving that: 
a.  The defendant was actually notified of the provisions of the ordinance; and 
b.  The defendant thereafter committed acts that were in violation of the ordinance or failed to take actions that were necessary to achieve compliance with the order. 
(4)  The allegations required to be pleaded in any proceeding under Article 1175 of Vernon's Annotated Civil Statutes are limited to the identification of the real property involved in the violation, the relationship of the defendant to the real property or activity involved in the violation, a citation to the applicable ordinance, a description of the violation and a statement that the ordinance is one to which this act applies. 
a.  The standard for proof is the same as is otherwise applicable in suits for extraordinary relief. 
b.  The Texas Rules of Civil Procedure apply to the action except as otherwise provided by this act. All means of discovery set forth and provided for in those rules are available to the parties to the action. 
(Ord. No. 93-03, 3-9-93) 
Sec. 7-84. - Closure of a structure. 
    Pursuant to section 7-76 of this article, all vacant structures or vacant portions of a structure shall be maintained in a securely closed condition at all times to reduce the possibility of fire, infestation, injury, or unauthorized human habitation. 
    A vacant structure or vacant portion of a structure shall be considered secured if all doors, windows or other openings are securely closed in the following manner: 
(1)  All entrance doors in such condition to suit their intended manufactured use, and locked in the closed position or in compliance with subsection (3) of this section; 
(2)  All windows in such condition to suit their intended manufactured use and locked in the closed position or in compliance with subsection (3) of this section; 
(3)  As an alternative to subsections (1) and (2) above and for all other openings, the openings shall be secured by means of installing one-half-inch or thicker exterior plywood in and flush with the opening and attached with screws at least two and one-half (2-1/2) times longer than the plywood is thick, eight (8) inches on center. 
(Ord. No. 93-03, 3-9-93) 
Sec. 7-85. - Demolition of a structure. 
    Demolition of a structure shall not be considered complete until fully dismantled, torn down, brought down smooth and level with the ground, including the proper removal and disposal of debris or other remnants of the act of demolition. 
(Ord. No. 93-03, 3-9-93) 
Sec. 7-86. - Savings clause. 
    If any provision, section, subsection, sentence, clause or phrase of the chapter, or the application of the same to any person or set of circumstances, is for any reason held to be unconstitutional, void or invalid, the validity of the remaining portions of this chapter or their application to other persons or sets of circumstances shall not be affected thereby, it being the intent of the city commission in adopting this chapter that no portion thereof or provision or regulation contained therein shall become inoperative or fail to reason of any unconstitutionality, voidness or invalidity of any other portion hereof, and all provisions of this chapter are declared to be servable for that purpose. 
(Ord. No. 93-03, 3-9-93) 
Secs. 7-87-7-94. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - ELECTRICAL CODE 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 7-95. - Code adopted. 
    The specifications, rules and regulations entitled NFPA 70, National Electrical Code, 2011 Edition thereof, prepared by the National Code committee, acted on by the National Fire Protection Association, Inc., and approved as an American National Standard, a copy of which is on file in the building official's office, is hereby enacted and adopted as the electrical code for the city, and is hereby incorporated herein by reference and made part of this Code as fully as if copied at length, except insofar as it may be inconsistent with the specific provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2001-04, 5-8-01; Ord. No. 2008-02, 2-12-08; Ord. No. 2013-11, 5-14-13) 
Sec. 7-96. - Scope of authority. 
    The building official shall be endowed with all the public powers necessary for the enforcement of, and is hereby authorized to render interpretations of this Code. The building official may delegate any authority to such appointed electrical inspector(s) which he/she deems appropriate for the enforcement of the electrical code. 
(Ord. No. 2001-04, 5-8-01) 
Sec. 7-97. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this article, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section. 
    Apprentice electrician shall mean a person engaged as an apprentice, helper or trainee. 
    Approved shall mean conformity with the applicable standards of the National Electrical Code, the Board of Fire Underwriters', the National Electrical Safety Code or approved by the building official. 
    Electrical contractor shall mean any person who is registered with the city and who has complied with the requirements for electrical contractor as set out in this article. 
    Electrical inspector shall mean a qualified individual appointed to enforce the provisions of the electrical article of this Code. 
    Journeyman electrician shall mean a person holding a valid journeyman electrician's license with the city. 
    Maintenance electrician shall mean a person holding a valid maintenance electrician's license with the city. 
    Master electrician shall mean any individual who has complied with the requirements for a master electrician as set out in this chapter and whose business is the act or supervision of erecting, installing, altering, repairing, servicing or maintaining electrical wiring devices, appliances or apparatus and who holds a valid master electrician's license with the city. 
    Premises shall mean any piece of real estate, a house or building and its land. 
(Ord. No. 2001-04, 5-8-01) 
Sec. 7-98. - Service enclosures, conductors, and other electrical equipment. 
    Only persons who have received authorization, as set forth in this article, may perform electrical installations, alterations, or repairs. 
(Ord. No. 2001-04, 5-8-01) 
Sec. 7-99. - Dangerous, loose wire prohibited. 
    No person shall permit pieces of wire or dead ends to dangle from poles or buildings, or in any manner leave old or new wiring in a condition that is dangerous to life or property. 
(Ord. No. 2001-04, 5-8-01) 
Sec. 7-100. - Additional penalties. 
    Upon conviction of the second violation of this article by a person who holds an occupational license from the City of Sweetwater, such license shall thereafter be suspended and vest no rights for a period of twelve (12) months from the date of conviction. His/her license may be reinstated after the suspension period by paying the appropriate license fee. Upon conviction of a third violation such license shall permanently be revoked, permanently barring such person from working as a master electrician, journeyman electrician or maintenance electrician within the corporate limits of the City of Sweetwater. If for any reason, the master electrician's, journeyman electrician's or maintenance electrician's license is suspended or revoked, no portion of the license fee will be refunded. 
(Ord. No. 2001-04, 5-8-01) 
Sec. 7-101. - Buildings moved into city. 
    All buildings or structures moved into the city shall be required to meet the requirements of this chapter. If any building or structure, in the jurisdiction of the City of Sweetwater, is moved from one (1) location to another, it shall also conform to the requirements of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2001-04, 5-8-01) 
Sec. 7-102. - City-owned property. 
    All wiring on or in any building or on any equipment that is owned or leased by the city, that is located either inside or outside the limits of the city, shall conform to the requirements of this chapter and the electrical code adopted in section 7-95. 
(Ord. No. 2001-04, 5-8-01) 
Sec. 7-103. - Exemptions. 
    The provisions of this article shall not apply to governmental entities operating under federal or state charter or law which are specifically exempted from municipal regulation. Public service companies operating under franchise from the city are also exempted insofar and only insofar as it applies to the operation, installation, maintenance, removal, repair or replacement of equipment or facilities which may be considered as a normal conduct of their business, otherwise the provisions of this article applies. 
(Ord. No. 2001-04, 5-8-01) 
Secs. 7-104-7-110. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - ELECTRICAL INSPECTOR 

Sec. 7-111. - Appointment. 
    The building official, with the approval of the applicable governing authority, may appoint a chief electrical inspector or assistant electrical inspector(s) in accordance with the provisions of the adopted building code. 
(Ord. No. 2001-04, 5-8-01) 
Sec. 7-112. - Qualifications. 
    Electrical inspectors shall have adequate knowledge of current approved methods and practices relating to electrical installations. Qualifications may be obtained by any combination of on-the-job training, completion of approved training courses, work as a licensed electrician, or previous electrical inspector experience. 
(Ord. No. 2001-04, 5-8-01) 
Sec. 7-113. - Inspections of premises generally. 
(a)  Electrical inspector(s) are hereby given the authority to inspect and reinspect the wiring of all premises within the city limits at any time he/she has reason to believe that defects exist that may be dangerous to life or property and shall notify, in writing, the owner of such premises to repair such defects. Any person, firm or corporation refusing to or failing to make such repairs in a reasonable time, as set by the inspector, shall be subject to the penalties prescribed by this chapter. 
(b)  When electrical wiring is found to be in a condition dangerous to life or property and a clear and present danger exists, the building official shall have the authority to order electrical service disconnected immediately. The building official shall then notify the owner of the premise of his/her order to disconnect, in writing, as soon as practical thereafter. 
(Ord. No. 2001-04, 5-8-01) 
Sec. 7-114. - Inspection of consumer installations; approval or disapproval. 
(a)  The electrical inspector shall inspect and approve or disapprove all installations, alterations, and repairs of electrical work in consumer premises as hereinafter set out. 
(b)  The electrical inspector shall be allowed forty-eight (48) hours to make such inspection; Saturday, Sunday, and holidays recognized by the City of Sweetwater excluded. 
(c)  For an approved installation, the electrical inspector shall attach an appropriate tag or card. For a disapproved installation, the electrical inspector shall attach an appropriate tag or card or immediately notify the owner or agent, or the electrician performing the work on said premises, if any, specifying the exact deficiency existing and shall allow a reasonable time, as determined by the electrical inspector, to correct said deficiency. 
(d)  If this corrective action is not begun immediately, or the deficiency is not corrected within the prescribed time, the electrical inspector shall notify the owner(s) or their agents in writing, stating the deficiency and any previous notice to the master electrician and shall allow a reasonable, as determined by the electrical inspector, to correct the deficiency. If the deficiency is not corrected within the prescribed time, such owner or agents shall be deemed guilty of a violation of this article and if electrical service is active to the premises in question, then the building official may order the electrical service disconnected without further notice. 
(Ord. No. 2001-04, 5-8-01) 
Sec. 7-115. - Removal, mutilation of tags on electrical installations. 
    It shall be a violation of this chapter to remove, deface, damage or mutilate a tag or card which the electrical inspector has attached to an inspection. 
(Ord. No. 2001-04, 5-8-01) 
Sec. 7-116. - Right of entry. 
    When, in the performance of his/her duties and as may be necessary for the performance of his/her duties, the electrical inspector shall have the right to enter any consumer's premises at all reasonable hours for the purpose of making test or inspections of the electrical wiring, appliances or apparatus contained therein. When on duty, the electrical inspector shall have adequate identification to indicate his position. 
(Ord. No. 2001-04, 5-8-01) 
Sec. 7-117. - Duty to keep records. 
    The electrical inspector shall keep, or cause to be kept, a written record of all permits, licenses, and inspections which are required under this article. He/she shall also keep a written record of all condemnations and disconnects of electrical installations resulting from condemnations. 
(Ord. No. 2001-04, 5-8-01) 
Sec. 7-118. - Duty to stop installations in violation; procedure. 
(a)  The electrical inspector may stop the installation, alteration, operations, or repair of any electrical work on or in any consumer's premises, when in the inspector's opinion, the work is being done in a reckless, careless or unsafe manner, or in any manner which violates the provisions of this article. 
(b)  When a violation of this article is found to exist, the building official, or any electrical inspector, may issue a stop-work order. When such stop-work is issued, then the provisions of sections 7-5 and 7-6 of this chapter shall apply. 
(Ord. No. 2001-04, 5-8-01) 
Sec. 7-119. - Conflict of interest. 
    Electrical inspectors shall not have any monetary interest in any electrical business or be employed for any private party or company in an electrical capacity within the city's jurisdiction while he/she is in the employment of the City of Sweetwater, Texas. 
(Ord. No. 2001-04, 5-8-01) 
Sec. 7-120. - Duty to turn over monies. 
    The electrical inspector shall turn over to the City of Sweetwater all monies and payments received by his office. 
(Ord. No. 2001-04, 5-8-01) 
Sec. 7-121. - Appeal from inspector's ruling. 
    Section 7-6 of this chapter shall apply. 
(Ord. No. 2001-04, 5-8-01) 
Sec. 7-122. - Liability. 
    Electrical inspector(s) shall not be liable for damage arising by reason of duties performed under the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2001-04, 5-8-01) 
Sec. 7-123. - Inspector's functions. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to interfere with an electrical inspector in the discharge of their duties or to prevent or in any manner attempt to prevent them from carrying out the provisions of this code. 
(Ord. No. 2001-04, 5-8-01) 
Secs. 7-124-7-133. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - PERMITS 

Sec. 7-134. - Required; exceptions. 
(a)  No person shall begin any electrical installation or begin any work of installing, erecting or altering material, wiring, fixtures or any other apparatus to be used for the generation, transmission or utilization of electricity for light, heat or power in or on any building or premises in the city without first securing a permit therefor from the office of the building official. 
(b)  The permit required by subsection (a) shall not be required for minor work, such as repairing flush switches, replacing fuses, changing lamp sockets, ballasts and receptacles. 
(c)  The permit required by subsection (a) shall not apply to those exempted in section 7-103. 
(Ord. No. 2001-04, 5-8-01) 
Sec. 7-135. - Persons entitled to permits. 
    Permits required by this article shall be issued to master electricians who qualify under the provisions of this chapter or to his duly authorized representatives and to homeowners who qualify as set forth in section 7-4 of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2001-04, 5-8-01) 
Sec. 7-136. - Temporary permits. 
(a)  Permits may be granted for temporary service to any licensed master electrician for a predetermined and limited time. 
(b)  A permit may be granted for a temporary meter pole for construction to a homeowner who qualifies as set forth in section 7-4, provided the homeowner has secured a building permit from the building official's office. This temporary service permit shall also be for a predetermined and limited time and the proper inspection fee shall be required. 
(c)  The electrical inspector may cause the electric supply company to disconnect any temporary service on the expiration date of the temporary service. 
(Ord. No. 2001-04, 5-8-01) 
Sec. 7-137. - Add-on permits. 
    Additional work during construction and before final inspection may be added to the original permit as an add-on at the regular item price by obtaining and paying for an add-on permit. 
(Ord. No. 2001-04, 5-8-01) 
Sec. 7-138. - Fees. 
    The fees for permits, inspections and reinspections required by this article shall be established from time to time by the city commission. 
(Ord. No. 2001-04, 5-8-01) 
Secs. 7-139-7-148. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - INSPECTIONS 

Sec. 7-149. - Rough-in and final inspections; notice. 
    There shall be a rough-in inspection where required and a final inspection of each installation. For inspections, the permit holder whose installation is ready for inspection shall notify the building official's office. Electrical inspectors shall be allowed up to forty-eight (48) hours, holidays recognized by the City of Sweetwater excepted, to perform the inspection and the requester shall be required to be present during the inspection. 
(Ord. No. 2001-04, 5-8-01) 
Sec. 7-150. - Reinspections. 
(a)  When any electrical work covered by this article is reported to the electrical inspector as ready for inspection, and upon such inspection the electrical work does not meet all requirements of this article, the permitted individual shall correct the defects promptly and request the electrical inspector to reinspect. The permit holder shall pay any required re-inspection fee. 
(b)  If for any reason of faulty work, negligence or omission, changes or additions are required by the electrical inspector or if an incorrect address given on the permit necessitates an additional trip by the electrical inspector, a reinspection shall be taken and the reinspection fee paid for each extra trip. 
(Ord. No. 2001-04, 5-8-01) 
Sec. 7-151. - When wiring, etc., is to be concealed. 
(a)  When electrical wiring or apparatus is to be hidden from view by permanent placement of parts of a building or is otherwise concealed, the permit holder shall notify the electrical inspector and have an inspection made and such wiring or apparatus shall not be concealed by any person until it has been inspected and approved. 
(b)  In the event wiring and apparatus has been concealed, the electrical inspector may require the removal of the concealing parts in order to inspect and require a reinspection fee. 
(c)  No person shall lath, seal or in any manner conceal any wiring appurtenances until they have been informed that such has been approved by the electrical inspector. 
(Ord. No. 2001-04, 5-8-01) 
Sec. 7-152. - Tagging inspected premises. 
    When the electrical inspector completes an inspection of any premises, he shall leave a tag or notice attached to the service entrance switch. This notice shall clearly state whether the wiring is approve or is to be kept open for further inspection. 
(Ord. No. 2001-04, 5-8-01) 
Sec. 7-153. - Clearance required to connect or disconnect service. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person or any public service company serving the city to connect electricity to any premises of any nature, kind or description, without first obtaining a clearance from the electrical inspector's department. Whenever service is disconnected to any premises, except private residences and duplex apartments where service is carried over for a continuing occupancy or nonpayment of bill, a clearance will be required before reconnecting. This shall mean any time a premises is vacated, the electrical inspector must satisfy himself that no code violation exists, or the connected wiring and equipment is in a safe condition. There will be no charge made for a clearance covering such premises and clearance will be issued as often as necessary. The building official shall have the authority to withhold electrical service to any premises until the building official is satisfied that no other violation of this chapter exists. 
(Ord. No. 2001-04, 5-8-01) 
Sec. 7-154. - When current is turned on prior to final inspection. 
    If for any reason electrical current is supplied to any building or structure of any nature, before the electrical construction work has been completed and final inspection made, the electrical inspector must satisfy himself that wiring is in a safe condition. All disconnects and panels shall be made up as well as all junction boxes, complete with switches and receptacles. If for any reason all junction boxes, complete with switches and receptacles cannot be installed, all current carrying wire shall be properly capped and taped. When work has been completed, the electrical inspector shall be notified and final inspection will be made. Failure to call for final inspection will be just cause for electrical service to be discontinued. 
(Ord. No. 2001-04, 5-8-01) 
Secs. 7-155-7-164. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - ELECTRICIANS, GENERALLY 

Sec. 7-165. - Authority with respect to examination, registration required. 
(a)  All electrical examination and licensing requirements shall be in accordance with the Texas Electrical Safety and Licensing Act. 
(b)  All electrical contractors shall register with the city building official's office by providing a copy of the proper Texas State License and certificate of insurance, prior to doing any electrical contracting within the corporate limits of the city. 
(Ord. No. 2001-04, 5-8-01; Ord. No. 2008-02, 2-12-08) 
Sec. 7-166. - Qualification. 
    Experience and qualification requirements for electricians and electrical contractors shall be in accordance with the Texas Electrical Safety and Licensing Act. 
(Ord. No. 2001-04, 5-8-01; Ord. No. 2008-02, 2-12-08) 
Sec. 7-167. - Apprentices, trainees or helpers. 
    Apprentices or trainees, or helpers, shall be supervised in the presence of a master electrician or journeyman electrician at all times. Nothing shall justify an apprentice electrician in performing any phase of electrical installations unless a master or journeyman electrician is actually present during the installation. 
(Ord. No. 2001-04, 5-8-01) 
Sec. 7-168. - Maintenance work by master and journey electricians. 
    Nothing in this division shall be construed to prevent a master electrician or journeyman electrician from performing electrical maintenance on any premises. 
(Ord. No. 2001-04, 5-8-01) 
Sec. 7-169. - Electrical contractors-Registration requirements; identification of vehicles. 
(a)  Any person desiring to engage in the business of electrical contracting within the city shall register with the building official's office, the correct name, address and telephone number under which he/she will be doing business. 
(b)  Any person engaged in the electrical contracting business, within the city, shall be a qualified master electrician and shall file with the office of the code enforcement officer the correct name, address and license number of such master electrician, who shall have actual supervision of the installation, maintenance and/or repair of any electrical wiring device, material and/or equipment within the city, and shall be responsible for carrying out the provisions of this chapter in its entirety. 
(c)  Any person engaged in the electrical contracting business in the city shall display in a permanent way, on its trucks, vans or any other vehicles used in transporting materials and tools to and from any electrical job, the correct name or company name and address registered under this division. The display shall be in lettering no smaller than three (3) inches in height, readily visible and clearly legible at all times. 
(Ord. No. 2001-04, 5-8-01) 
Sec. 7-170. - Exercise of licenses restricted to license holder. 
    It shall be unlawful for the holder of any license issued pursuant to this article to allow his/her name or license to be used by any other person directly or indirectly for the purpose of obtaining a permit for performing work under his/her license. 
(Ord. No. 2001-04, 5-8-01) 
Sec. 7-171. - Education in lieu of experience. 
    The holder of an Associate Degree in Applied Science from an accredited technical school or college, with a minimum of ninety (90) total credit hours, which curriculum contains at least sixty (60) hours of laboratory time in addition to at least forty-five (45) credit hours of courses related to the electrical trades such as, but not limited to: Electrical theory, solid state relays; contactors; AC/DC synchronous induction and step motors; generators; industrial, commercial and residential wiring; and the requirements specified by the National Electrical Code; shall receive two (2) years credit applied toward the experience requirements contained within this article. 
(Ord. No. 2001-04, 5-8-01) 
Secs. 7-172-7-181. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - MAINTENANCE ELECTRICIANS 

Sec. 7-182. - Maintenance electrician-License required, prerequisites. 
    No person shall operate as a maintenance electrician within the city, without first obtaining a license pursuant to this division. A person desiring a maintenance electrician license shall make application in writing on an appropriate form provided by the building official, setting forth his name, address; type, name and location of business of his employer if employed. He shall further provide a record of his experience, two (2) years of which shall be actual experience in the electrical field. Upon verification of sufficient work experience and conclusive proof of successfully passing the SBCCI Maintenance Electrician Examination and paying the appropriate license fee, the applicant shall be licensed as a maintenance electrician, subject to the following: 
(1)  The building official shall sign and issue a license which the maintenance electrician shall have on his or her person at all times when engaged in the duties of maintenance electrician. 
(2)  The license shall permit the holder to perform the duties of a maintenance electrician only on the premises of the owner by whom he or she is employed full time (one (1) employer only). Any violation of this requirement shall result in cancellation of the license. 
(3)  Each license issued to a maintenance electrician shall specify the name and address of the person to whom the license was issued; the location of the premises in or on which the maintenance work is to be done; the date the license was issued, and no work shall be done at any location except that named on the license. 
(4)  Every holder of a maintenance electrician's license shall notify the building official immediately when such holder makes any change in employment, giving in such notice the name of his or her new employer and the location of the premises in or on which such person is to be employed to perform electrical maintenance work. 
(5)  Such license shall be held in suspense when such person is not employed as a maintenance electrician. 
(Ord. No. 2001-04, 5-8-01) 
Sec. 7-183. - Same-Registration fee; filing deadline. 
    The initial and renewal fees for licensing of a maintenance electrician shall be established from time to time by the city commission and renewals shall be paid no later than 5:00 p.m. on the last day of December of each expiring year. 
(Ord. No. 2001-04, 5-8-01) 
Sec. 7-184. - Same-Restrictions on work performed. 
    The licensing of maintenance electricians coming within the terms of this division shall not be construed to allow such maintenance electrician to make any extensions, additions, new installations, or to perform any work for which a permit is required, or to perform any work required by this Code to be performed by a master electrician or journeyman electrician. The work to be performed by a licensed maintenance electrician shall be limited to: The keeping in safe repair and operating condition any and all electrical installations, apparatus and equipment in or on any building or structure or located in or upon any lot or premises owned by the employer of such maintenance electrician for whom he or she is a full time employee. 
(Ord. No. 2001-04, 5-8-01) 
Secs. 7-185-7-194. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 7. - MASTER ELECTRICIANS 

Sec. 7-195. - License required. 
    No person shall operate as a master electrician, within the city, without first obtaining a license pursuant to this division and without complying with the requirements hereinafter set forth. 
(Ord. No. 2001-04, 5-8-01) 
Sec. 7-196. - Application for license. 
    A person desiring a master electrician's license shall be eligible to work in the United States, shall have reached the age of twenty-one (21) years and shall make application in writing on an appropriate form provided by the building official. Upon verification of meeting the requirements of section 7-197 and conclusive proof of successfully passing the SBCCI Master Electrician Examination, and paying the appropriate license fee, the applicant shall be licensed as a master electrician, subject to the requirements of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2001-04, 5-8-01) 
Sec. 7-197. - Experience requirements; falsification. 
(a)  An applicant for a license required by this division shall furnish to the building official evidence that such applicant holds a valid journeyman electrical license (City of Sweetwater or other city or state) and has held such valid journeyman electrical license for twelve (12) months; or has held or presently holds a master electricians license (City of Sweetwater or another city or state), and in addition, conclusive proof of at least five (5) years experience in the electrical construction industry or any combination of equivalent experience of at least five (5) years, to the satisfaction of the building official. 
(b)  The application shall include dates and locations of experience in the business or practice of master or journeyman electrician along with names and addresses of such employers and any other documentation which will assure the building official of pertinent electrical experience.
