(c)  Falsification of an experience record shall be justification for the refusal to issue a license or for the cancellation of a license. If a license is cancelled due to falsification of an experience record, no refund of any portion of the license fee shall be made. 
(Ord. No. 2001-04, 5-8-01) 
Sec. 7-198. - License fee. 
    The original and renewal fees for licenses required by this division shall be established from time to time by the city commission. 
(Ord. No. 2001-04, 5-8-01) 
Sec. 7-199. - Insurance required. 
    Prior to doing any work, all master electricians shall obtain insurance with an insurance company doing business in the State of Texas and provide proof of insurance to the city in the amount of not less than one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) of comprehensive general liability insurance, per occurrence, including coverage for bodily injury, property damage and completed operations. The insurance policy shall provide for notice to the city in the event of cancellation. 
(Ord. No. 2001-04, 5-8-01) 
Sec. 7-200. - Issuance of license; term. 
    Qualified applicants who comply with the provisions of this division shall be issued a license signed by the building official. The license shall be valid for the remainder of the calendar year in which it was issued. 
(Ord. No. 2001-04, 5-8-01) 
Sec. 7-201. - Renewal of license. 
    Licenses issued pursuant to this division shall be renewed no later than 5:00 p.m. on the last day of December of each year and shall be accompanied by the fee established pursuant to section 7-198. Licenses not renewed on or before the last day of December automatically become suspended. Licenses suspended due to nonpayment may be renewed anytime prior to the lapse of thirty-one (31) days without penalty. After January 31 st of each year all licenses not renewed become null and void. 
(Ord. No. 2001-04, 5-8-01) 
Sec. 7-202. - Failure to renew license. 
    Any person failing to renew a license within the time period prescribed in section 7-201 shall be required to make a new application for licensing pursuant to this division and pay all fees pertaining thereto. 
(Ord. No. 2001-04, 5-8-01) 
Sec. 7-203. - Information to be filed. 
    All master electricians shall file their correct address, telephone number and any changes of the same with the building official. 
(Ord. No. 2001-04, 5-8-01) 
Sec. 7-204. - Employment of unlicensed workers. 
    It shall be unlawful for a master electrician to send any person on any job in the capacity of an electrician unless such person is the holder of and in possession of a journeyman electrician's license, or is accompanied and supervised by a person holding and in the possession of a master's or journeyman electrician's license. 
(Ord. No. 2001-04, 5-8-01) 
Secs. 7-205-7-214. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 8. - JOURNEYMEN ELECTRICIANS 

Sec. 7-215. - License required. 
    No person shall operate as a journeyman electrician, within the city, without first having obtained a license pursuant to this division. 
(Ord. No. 2001-04, 5-8-01) 
Sec. 7-216. - Scope of license. 
    A license issued pursuant to this division shall entitle the holder to perform any type of electrical work under the general supervision of a master electrician. A journeyman electrician shall not contract for or engage in the business of electrical work of any nature, except in the employment of and under the supervision of a master electrician. 
(Ord. No. 2001-04, 5-8-01) 
Sec. 7-217. - Application for license. 
    A person desiring a journeyman electrician's license shall be eligible to work in the United States, have reached the age of twenty-one (21) years and shall make application in writing on an appropriate form provided by the building official. Upon verification of meeting the requirements of section 7-218 and conclusive proof of successfully passing the SBCCI Journeyman Electrician Examination, and paying the appropriate license fee, the applicant shall be licensed as a journeyman electrician. 
(Ord. No. 2001-04, 5-8-01) 
Sec. 7-218. - Experience requirements; falsification. 
    An applicant for a license required by this division shall furnish the building official conclusive proof of at least four (4) years' actual experience, giving the dates, locations and the employer's names. The experience shall include, but not be limited to, the installation of electrical materials and equipment or the equivalent thereof, in or on private, residential, commercial, industrial and public properties. Falsification of an experience record shall be justification for the cancellation of a license. If a license is canceled due to falsification of an experience record, no refund of any portion of the license fee shall be made. 
(Ord. No. 2001-04, 5-8-01) 
Sec. 7-219. - License fee. 
    The original and renewal fees for licenses required by this division shall be established from time to time by the city commission. 
(Ord. No. 2001-04, 5-8-01) 
Sec. 7-220. - Issuance of license; term. 
    Qualified applicants who comply with the provisions of this division shall be issued a license signed by the building official. The license shall be valid for the remainder of the calendar year in which it was issued. 
(Ord. No. 2001-04, 5-8-01) 
Sec. 7-221. - Renewal of license. 
    Licenses issued pursuant to this division shall be renewed no later than 5:00 p.m. on the last day of December of each year and shall be accompanied by the fee established pursuant to section 7-219. Licenses not renewed on or before the day of December automatically become suspended. Licenses suspended due to nonpayment may be renewed prior to the lapse of thirty-one (31) days without penalty. After January 31 st , of each year, all licenses not renewed shall become null and void. 
(Ord. No. 2001-04, 5-8-01) 
Sec. 7-222. - Failure to renew license. 
    Any person failing to renew a license within the time period prescribed in section 7-221 shall be required to make a new application for licensing pursuant to this division and pay all fees pertaining thereto. 
(Ord. No. 2001-04, 5-8-01) 
Secs. 7-223-7-232. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 9. - TECHNICAL STANDARDS 

Sec. 7-233. - Changes and additions to adopted electrical code. 
    The provisions of this division shall supersede when in contradiction to the adopted electrical code. 
(Ord. No. 2001-04, 5-8-01) 
Sec. 7-234. - Minimum standards for materials generally. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to install or use any electrical apparatus, material, appliance or fixture for use in connection with wiring of any kind in the city, unless such electrical apparatus, materials or fixtures has been tested, listed, and labeled for it's intended use by an nationally recognized organization in the business of product evaluation. 
(Ord. No. 2001-04, 5-8-01) 
Sec. 7-235. - Safety standards generally. 
    All installations of electrical equipment made within the city shall be so made that they will be in a safe condition, and shall be made in conformity with the provisions of this article and the electrical code adopted by section 9-196, and applicable state law, and all orders, rules and regulations issued by the authority thereof. 
(Ord. No. 2001-04, 5-8-01) 
Sec. 7-236. - Wiring in fire limits. 
    Wiring on all premises and in all buildings hereafter erected, and all changes and additions to existing buildings within the fire limits of the city, except private residences, duplex apartments and dwellings for three (3) or four (4) family units which are no more than one (1) story in height, in which noncombustible materials are required or which require special precautions, shall be installed in a complete and continuous metal raceway system and twenty (20) ampere capacity copper wire shall be the minimum size conductor used, except low voltage conductors. 
(Ord. No. 2001-04, 5-8-01) 
Sec. 7-237. - Wiring in mercantile, commercial and public buildings. 
(a)  All buildings hereinafter erected, and all changes and additions to existing buildings in the city for assembly, business, educational, factory-industrial, institutional, mercantile, residential, storage, automobile parking or repair garages, or any commercial purpose what so ever, including any building where the occupancy classification is changed to suit such use, shall have all electrical wiring, for any purpose, installed in an approved, complete and continuous, raceway system and twenty (20) ampere capacity copper wire shall be the minimum size conductor used, except low voltage conductors. 
(b)  The raceway provision of subsection (a) shall not apply to private residences, duplex apartments and dwellings for three (3) or four (4) family units which are no more than one (1) story in height. 
(c)  The raceway provision of subsection (a) shall not be mandatory for existing buildings or structures identified and classified by the state or local jurisdiction as historic buildings, or any other building or structure where the building official deems that compliance with subsection (a) is infeasible, that such buildings or structures comply with the requirements of the National Electrical Code and are judged to be safe and in the public interest of health, safety and welfare. 
(Ord. No. 2001-04, 5-8-01) 
Sec. 7-238. - Open wire on insulators. 
    Open wiring on insulators as a wiring method, and wiring supported on cleats, shall not be permitted. 
(Ord. No. 2001-04, 5-8-01) 
Sec. 7-239. - Armored cable (BX). 
    The use of armored cable (BX) is prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 2001-04, 5-8-01) 
Sec. 7-240. - Temporary lighting and power installations. 
    Temporary lighting and power installations on premises used for the display of merchandise or for public or private gatherings shall have all wiring and equipment completed before connection is made to the temporary service equipment by the electricity agency. All such wiring shall meet clearance requirements and other requirements of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2001-04, 5-8-01) 
Sec. 7-241. - Temporary meter installations for new construction. 
    Temporary meter poles shall be no smaller than four-inch by four-inch construction properly braced; of sufficient height to meet the National Electrical Code and local power and light company clearance requirements, and shall be not less than three (3) feet in the ground. Service disconnect equipment and associated electrical hardware shall be suitable for wet locations. 
    Ground fault circuit interrupter protection for personnel shall be required on all 125-volt, single phase, 15- and 20-ampere receptacles which are not part of the permanent wiring of the building or structure unless such temporary electrical power and lighting installation is permitted by a licensed master electrician and its use is monitored by said licensed master electrician in accordance with National Electrical Code requirements. 
(Ord. No. 2001-04, 5-8-01) 
Sec. 7-242. - Branch circuit conductors. 
    All general-use and small appliance branch circuit conductors shall be of a minimum twenty (20) ampere capacity copper wire and protected by an approved twenty (20) ampere overcurrent device. Designated branch circuit conductors shall be of a sufficient size corresponding to the name-plate rating of the designated appliance for which they are installed. Where branch circuit conductors are installed in areas subject to high ambient temperature, such conductors shall have a temperature rating suitable for the installation. 
(Ord. No. 2001-04, 5-8-01) 
Sec. 7-243. - Mobile homes. 
    Mobile homes shall meet the requirements of Article 550 of the National Electrical Code, except that poles for individual mobile home meter loops shall not be less than five (5) feet in the ground and shall be of sufficient height to meet the requirements of the National Electrical Code in addition to the requirements of the local power and light company. All associated equipment and fittings shall be suitable for the conditions of use and shall comply with the provisions of section 7-247. All feeders extending from the service disconnect equipment, where subject to physical contact or damage, shall be installed in an approved raceway system. 
(Ord. No. 2001-04, 5-8-01) 
Sec. 7-244. - Underground services. 
    A service lateral shall be installed in accordance with the requirements of the National Electrical Code in addition to the requirements of the local power and light company and shall comply with the applicable provisions as set forth in section 7-247. A service lateral which must cross a designated alley shall be installed in rigid metal conduit and have warning tape placed in the ditch for that portion of lateral in the right of way. 
(Ord. No. 2001-04, 5-8-01) 
Sec. 7-245. - Service mast. 
    The service mast, where adequately supported and used as a means of attachment for the service drop, shall be of a minimum two-inch trade size rigid steel electrical conduit. It shall be installed according to the requirements of the local power and light company in addition to the National Electrical Code requirements. The roofline penetration shall be sealed in an approved manner. 
(Ord. No. 2001-04, 5-8-01) 
Sec. 7-246. - Bathroom heaters. 
    Bathroom heating units shall be installed on separate circuits of proper wire size. 
(Ord. No. 2001-04, 5-8-01) 
Sec. 7-247. - Services. 
(a)  Any structure hereafter erected at which a separately derived electrical service will be supplied, shall have an approved grounding electrode system. 
(b)  Any building at which a separately derived electrical system is hereafter supplied, installed, altered or replaced shall have a minimum ungrounded service entrance conductor and associated service equipment capacity rating of one hundred (100) amperes unless otherwise approved by the electrical inspector. In no case shall the grounded service entrance conductor be reduced more than two (2) sizes smaller than that of the ungrounded service entrance conductor. 
(Ord. No. 2001-04, 5-8-01) 
Sec. 7-248. - Low voltage wiring. 
    Low voltage control wiring carrying twenty-four (24) volts or less installed in conjunction with heating and air conditioning systems shall be installed in an approved raceway system where subject to physical damage. 
(Ord. No. 2001-04, 5-8-01) 
Sec. 7-249. - Residences. 
    In residences not more than eight (8) current consuming outlets shall be connected to nay 120-volt, 20-ampere general use branch circuit. Not more than four (4) current consuming outlets shall be connected to any 120-volt, 20-ampere small appliance branch circuit. There shall be at least one (1) 120-volt, 20-ampere branch circuit to a laundry room for laundry equipment. 
(Ord. No. 2001-04, 5-8-01) 
Sec. 7-250. - Commercial. 
    In commercial buildings, not more than five (5) current consuming outlets shall be connected to any branch circuit unless designed by a licensed electrical engineer. 
(Ord. No. 2001-04, 5-8-01) 
Sec. 7-251. - Location of service switches or panels. 
    Where changes or additions to service or service equipment are being made, all connected wiring and equipment shall be changed to conform to the provisions of this article, unless the connected wiring and equipment is acceptable to the electrical inspector. Service entrance switches, panels or service equipment shall not be installed within a bathroom, closet or cabinet. 
(Ord. No. 2001-04, 5-8-01) 
Sec. 7-252. - Brackets for service wires; sealed meter bases; auxiliary gutters. 
(a)  Brackets or other means of attachment installed on buildings for service drop conductors shall be installed in accordance with the requirements of the National Electrical Code and the local power and light company. 
(b)  All sealed type meter bases shall be installed so as to meet the requirements of the National Electrical Code and the local power and light company. 
(Ord. No. 2001-04, 5-8-01) 
Sec. 7-253. - Grounding conductors under concrete. 
    Grounding conductors shall not be run under or through a concrete foundation or slab unless it is encased in an approved raceway or in cable armor. 
(Ord. No. 2001-04, 5-8-01) 
Sec. 7-254. - Wiring on finished surfaces. 
    All electrical wiring installed on the finished surface of any building or structure where susceptible to physical contact or damage, including any private residence, shall be installed in an approved raceway system. 
(Ord. No. 2001-04, 5-8-01) 
Sec. 7-255. - Service conductors. 
(a)  Service entrance conductors installed within a service riser shall be installed within an approved metal raceway system not smaller than one-inch trade size. 
(b)  Service entrance conductors, within or on any and all buildings hereafter erected or altered, which extend from the meter base to the service disconnect, shall be installed in an approved raceway system not smaller than one-inch trade size. 
(Ord. No. 2001-04, 5-8-01) 
Secs. 7-256-7-264. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - ENERGY CONSERVATION CODE 

Sec. 7-265. - Code adopted. 
    The specifications, rules and regulations entitled International Energy Conservation Code, 2012 Edition thereof, as published by the International Code Council, Inc., a copy of which is on file in the building official's office, is hereby enacted and adopted as the energy code for the city, and is and hereby incorporated herein by reference and made part of this Code, as fully as if copied at length, except insofar as it may be inconsistent with the specific provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2008-02, 2-12-08; Ord. No. 2013-11, 5-14-13) 
Chapter 8 - CITY CEMETERY[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Cemeteries, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 912a et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 8-1. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings ascribed to them by this section: 
    Cemetery shall mean the cemetery owned and operated by the city. 
    Interment shall mean the burial of the remains of a deceased person. 
    Memorial shall mean any marker, monument, headstone, tablet, or other structure placed upon or in any lot for identification or in memory of the interred. 
    Perpetual care shall mean to keep the sod in repair, keep all places where interments have been made in proper order and to care for trees and shrubs. 
    Perpetual care cemetery shall mean a cemetery for the benefit of an established perpetual care fund. 
    Superintendent shall mean the person duly appointed by the city for the purpose of supervising and administering cemetery functions. 
(Ord. of 10-25-83, § 1) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 8-2. - City cemetery established. 
    The cemetery existing in the city and owned and operated by the city is established as the city cemetery. 
Sec. 8-3. - Trust fund created; funding. 
(a)  There is hereby created a trust fund to be used for the purpose of providing for care of the city cemetery grounds. 
(b)  The trust fund created by this section shall be funded from donations and from the sale of lots in the city cemetery at prices to be established from time to time by the city commission. 
(Ord. No. 83-05-12/III, 2-22-83) 
Cross reference- Funding by cemetery board, § 8-52. 
Sec. 8-4. - Use. 
    The city cemetery is for the exclusive use of the burial of human remains and any person burying any animal in the cemetery shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
Sec. 8-5. - Interment, disinterment and reinterment procedures. 
(a)  The city cemetery office shall be notified a reasonable period of time prior to interment so that space can be staked for the opening and closing of the grave. 
(b)  The opening and closing of graves in the city cemetery shall be contracted by the funeral director in charge of interment arrangements. 
(c)  Disinterments and reinterments in the city cemetery shall be contracted by the person requesting the same at his own expense. 
(d)  Any contractor performing duties in the city cemetery shall be responsible for any damage which may occur as a result of the performance of his duties. 
(e)  The cemetery superintendent shall be notified prior to disinterments. 
(Ord. of 10-25-83, § 3) 
Sec. 8-6. - Lots-Payment, transfer. 
(a)  No burial shall be permitted on any lot in the city cemetery until the space that is to be used is paid for in full. 
(b)  The cemetery superintendent shall be notified prior to any sale or transfer of any cemetery lot. 
(Ord. of 10-25-83, § 4) 
Sec. 8-7. - Above ground memorials. 
(a)  In areas of the city cemetery not specifically designated for flush-type memorials, either above ground or flush type memorials may be used. 
(b)  All above ground memorials shall be made of marble, granite or similar permanent stones. 
(Ord. of 10-25-83, § 5) 
Sec. 8-8. - Monumental work and grave markers. 
(a)  All monumental work and grave markers placed in the city cemetery shall have a suitable foundation which must be put in at the lot owner's expense. 
(b)  The city reserves the right to prohibit the erection of any monument, headstone or marker that may be considered inappropriate in material, design or workmanship. 
(Ord. of 10-25-83, § 5) 
Sec. 8-9. - Flush-type memorials. 
(a)  Flush-type memorials shall be required in blocks 113, 114, 115, 116, 117, 118, 121, 122, 123, 124, 125, 126, 127, 128, 129, 132, 133 and 134 of the city cemetery. 
(b)  Flush-type memorials shall be constructed of granite, marble or cast bronze on a granite, marble or concrete base. 
(c)  All memorials, grave markers or foot markers coming within the terms of this section shall be flush with the ground. 
(d)  In the sections enumerated in subsection (a), no grave shall be covered with a concrete slab or covering. 
(Ord. of 10-25-83, §§ 5, 6) 
Sec. 8-10. - Visiting. 
(a)  The city cemetery will be open from sunrise to sunset to all lot owners and visitors. 
(b)  No person shall be permitted to enter or leave the cemetery except through the public gate located in the south end of the cemetery. 
(c)  Any unauthorized person found on the cemetery grounds after sunset will be considered a trespasser. 
(Ord. of 10-25-83, § 2) 
Sec. 8-11. - Prior approval for lot improvements. 
    Any work and improvements on lots in the city cemetery, made without prior approval of the cemetery superintendent, may be removed and the lot brought back to grade at the expense of the lot owner. 
(Ord. of 10-25-83, § 6) 
Sec. 8-12. - Grade and turf improvements. 
(a)  The grade of lots in the city cemetery shall not be changed by lot owners and no person shall remove turf from any lot. 
(b)  The city shall have the right to level and fill graves in the city cemetery and plant grass thereon. 
(c)  All graves in the sections of the city cemetery designated for flush-type memorials shall be flush enough to permit the mowing machine to pass over the graves without difficulty. 
(Ord. of 10-25-83, § 6) 
Sec. 8-13. - "Babyland" lots. 
(a)  Block 120 of the city cemetery is hereby designated as "Babyland." 
(b)  The size of grave spaces in the above designated block shall be three (3) feet by four (4) feet. 
(c)  Grave spaces in the above designated block will be sold for amounts determined from time to time by the city commission with all receipts to be placed in the nonspendable trust fund created in section 8-3. 
(Ord. of 9-13-83) 
Sec. 8-14. - Operation of vehicles. 
(a)  Motor vehicles shall be driven slowly through the cemetery and shall not turn around in the avenues. 
(b)  Driving or riding of vehicles shall not be allowed on the cemetery lots or grounds, other than on the avenues. 
(c)  Heavy trucks or any motor vehicles with an unusual or heavy load shall not enter the city cemetery grounds until permission has been secured from the cemetery superintendent. 
(Ord. of 10-25-83, § 2) 
Sec. 8-15. - Signs prohibited. 
    No signs other than those installed by city personnel shall be placed on the city cemetery grounds. 
(Ord. of 10-25-83, § 6) 
Sec. 8-16. - Alcoholic beverages prohibited. 
    The use of alcoholic beverages is prohibited in the city cemetery. 
(Ord. of 10-25-83, § 6) 
Sec. 8-17. - Use of profane, boisterous language prohibited. 
    No person shall use profane or boisterous language or in any way disturb the quiet and good order of the cemetery. 
(Ord. of 10-25-83, § 6) 
Sec. 8-18. - Firearms prohibited. 
    No person, except peace officers or a military guard of honor, shall be permitted to bring or carry firearms within the city cemetery. 
(Ord. of 10-25-83, § 6) 
Sec. 8-19. - Pets prohibited. 
    Pets shall not be allowed in the city cemetery. 
(Ord. of 10-25-83, § 6) 
Sec. 8-20. - Benches, fencing, etc., prohibited. 
    No construction is permitted on cemetery lots. This includes items such as fencing, curbing, wood or brick coverings. In addition there shall be no placing of any bench, chair, table, trellis or other similar obstructions on cemetery lots. This shall not include customary headstones or grave markers. 
(Ord. of 10-25-83, § 6; Ord. No. 2014-11, 9-16-14) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2014-11, adopted Sept. 16, 2014, changed the title of § 8-20 from "Benches, fencing, etc., prohibited; exception" to read as herein set out. 
Sec. 8-21. - Removal of unsightly, damaged floral designs, shrubs, etc. 
(a)  Floral designs and other decorations placed on graves in the city cemetery will be removed as soon as they become wilted or unsightly. The cemetery superintendent shall have the authority to enter upon any space to remove any objectionable thing that may have been placed there. 
(b)  The cemetery superintendent shall remove dead or damaged flowers, trees, shrubs, vines or anything prohibited by this article. 
(Ord. of 10-25-83, § 6) 
Sec. 8-22. - Discarded materials prohibited. 
    No boxes, shells, toys, discarded glassware, sprinkler cans, water hoses or similar articles will be permitted to remain on any grave or walkway in the city cemetery. 
(Ord. of 10-25-83, § 6) 
Sec. 8-23. - Planting and trimming of trees, shrubs, etc. 
(a)  The planting of ivy, flowers, shrubs, trees, or bushes is prohibited in areas of the city cemetery designated for flush-type memorials. 
(b)  The city reserves the right to trim or prune any shrub or tree. 
(Ord. of 10-25-83, § 6) 
Sec. 8-24. - Defacing cemetery grounds. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to break or injure any tree or shrub, or mar any landmark, marker or memorial or in any way deface the grounds of the cemetery. 
(Ord. of 10-25-83, § 6) 
Sec. 8-25. - Unsightly, hazardous structures. 
    Should any monument, curbing or fence in the city cemetery become unsightly, dilapidated or a hazard to the public, the city shall have the right at the expense of the lot owner either to correct the condition or to remove the same. 
(Ord. of 10-25-83, § 6) 
Sec. 8-26. - Acceptance of money by personnel prohibited. 
    Persons employed by the cemetery shall not solicit or accept money or other compensation from any person for maintenance performed within the cemetery. 
(Ord. of 10-25-83, § 6) 
Sec. 8-27. - General care by city; special care prohibited. 
(a)  Care shall be furnished to the city cemetery by the city, which shall include sufficient maintenance of the buildings and grounds to reasonably preserve a pleasing appearance of the cemetery. 
(b)  Special care by cemetery employees of any grave or space located within the city cemetery is prohibited. 
(Ord. of 10-25-83, § 6) 
Sec. 8-28. - Strict enforcement. 
The  city cemetery grounds are sacredly devoted to the burial of human remains and the provisions of this Code and applicable state law shall be strictly enforced. 
(Ord. of 10-25-83, § 6) 
Sec. 8-29. - Disclaimer of liability. 
    The city shall take reasonable precautions to protect the property rights of owners, within the cemetery, from loss or damage, but it disclaims all responsibility for loss or damage caused by the elements, vandals or other unavoidable accidents. 
(Ord. of 10-25-83, § 6) 
Sec. 8-30. - Statements of cemetery employees not binding. 
    The statement of any employee of the city cemetery shall not be binding upon the city, except when such statement agrees with the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. of 10-25-83, § 6) 
Sec. 8-31. - Rights reserved to the city. 
    In addition to the rights contained in this chapter, the city reserves the right to: 
(a)  Revise and add to the cemetery, including the right to modify or change the location of any part thereof or remove or regrade roads. 
(b)  To lay, maintain and operate or alter or change pipe lines for water sprinkling systems and drainage. 
(c)  To use cemetery property not sold to individual owners for cemetery purposes. 
(d)  To change, amend, alter, repeal, rescind or add to the provisions of this chapter and to provide for temporary exceptions with respect to the city cemetery or anything pertaining thereto. 
(e)  In all matters not specifically covered by this chapter, to do anything which in its judgment is deemed reasonable pertaining to the city cemetery and such determination shall be binding upon all parties concerned. 
(Ord. of 10-25-83, §§ 6, 7) 
Secs. 8-32-8-45. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CEMETERY BOARD 

Sec. 8-46. - Created. 
    There is hereby created a cemetery board for the city. 
Sec. 8-47. - Appointments; terms. 
(a)  The city commission shall initially appoint nine (9) members of such board from among the citizens of the city and the term of such appointments shall be for a period of two (2) years, except as provided in subsection (b). 
(b)  After the appointment of the initial nine (9) members of the cemetery board, the members shall draw by lot to determine which five (5) appointees shall serve the full two (2) years and which four (4) appointees shall serve only one (1) year. After the initial appointees have completed their terms, members shall serve the full two (2) year term and shall be eligible for reappointment. 
(Ord. No. 83-04-11/III, 2-22-83) 
Sec. 8-48. - Election of chairman; term. 
    The cemetery board shall, upon its original organization and annually thereafter, elect a chairman. 
(Ord. No. 83-04-11/III, 2-22-83) 
Sec. 8-49. - Optional offices. 
    The cemetery board shall have the authority to designate a vice-chairman and secretary, if such officers are deemed to be appropriate. 
(Ord. No. 83-04-11/III, 2-22-83) 
Sec. 8-50. - Compensation, reimbursement for expenses. 
    Members of the cemetery board shall receive no compensation, but may be reimbursed for actual expenses incurred for activities authorized by the city commission. 
(Ord. No. 83-04-11/III, 2-22-83) 
Sec. 8-51. - Meetings. 
    Meetings of the cemetery board shall be held at such time and places as are convenient to the board and shall be held at the call of the chairman, a majority of the board members or of the city commission. 
(Ord. No. 83-04-11/III, 2-22-83) 
Sec. 8-52. - Purpose, duties. 
    The purposes, duties and authorities of the cemetery board shall be as follows: 
(1)  To oversee the maintenance and upkeep of all city property devoted to city cemetery purposes and to make recommendations to the city commission with regard to all problems relating to upkeep and maintenance of city cemetery property and to the hiring, discharge, payment, and other related policy matters concerning personnel involved in the maintenance and upkeep of city cemetery property. 
(2)  To make plans for the generation of gifts and bequests and the establishment of funds from those and other sources. The fund shall be under the control of the city commission, but is to be devoted exclusively to the care and upkeep of city cemetery property and the cemetery board shall propose specific rules for the development and use of such funds. 
(Ord. No. 83-04-11/III, 2-22-83) 
Cross reference- Trust fund created, § 8-3. 
Chapter 9 - CIVIL EMERGENCIES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2001-04, adopted May 8, 2001, repealed former Ch. 9, Arts. I-IV, § 9-1-9-229, which pertained to electricity, and derived from an ordinance adopted March 24, 1970; Ord. No. 86-04, adopted February 11, 1986; Ord. No. 88-14, adopted November 7, 1988; an ordinance adopted September 29, 1981; and Ord. No. 91-04, adopted May 7, 1991. 
Subsequently, Ord. No. 2003-04, §§ 1-8, adopted March 11, 2003, enacted provisions which were not specifically amendatory of this Code, but which have been included herein as a new ch. 9, art. II, §§ 9-26-9-33, at the discretion of the editor. This new chapter has been placed herein to preserve the alphabetical chapter order of the Code. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 9-1. - National incident management system. 
    The city commission of the City of Sweetwater, hereby adopts the National Incident Management System (NIMS) dated March 1, 2004. 
(Ord. No. 2005-07, 8-9-05) 
Secs. 9-2-9-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT 

Sec. 9-26. - Organization. 
    There exists the office of emergency management director of the city, which shall be held by the mayor in accordance with state law. 
(1)  An emergency management coordinator may be appointed by and serve at the pleasure of the director; 
(2)  The director shall be responsible for a program of comprehensive emergency management within the city and for carrying out the duties and responsibilities set forth in this chapter. He/she may delegate authority for execution shall remain with the director. 
(3)  The operational emergency management organization of the city shall consist of the officers and employees of the city so designated by the director in the emergency management plan, as well as organized volunteer groups. The functions and duties of this organization shall be distributed among such officers and employees in accordance with the terms of the emergency management plan. 
(Ord. No. 2003-04, § 1, 3-11-03) 
Sec. 9-27. - Emergency management director-Powers and duties. 
    The duties and responsibilities of the emergency management director shall include the following: 
(1)  Surveying actual or potential hazards which threaten life and property within the city and identifying and requiring or recommending the implementation of measures which would tend to prevent the occurrence or reduce the impact of such hazards if a disaster did occur. 
(2)  Supervision of the development and approval of an emergency management plan for the city, and shall recommend for adoption by the city council all mutual aid arrangements deemed necessary for the implementation of such plan. 
(3)  Authority to declare a local state of disaster. The declaration may not be continued or renewed for a period in excess of seven (7) days except by or with the consent of the city council. Any order or proclamation declaring, continuing, or terminating a local state of disaster shall be given prompt and general publicity and shall be filed promptly with the city secretary. 
(4)  Issuance of necessary proclamations, regulations, or directives which are necessary for carrying out the purposes of this chapter. Such proclamations, regulations, or directives shall be disseminated promptly by means calculated to bring its contents to the attention of the general public and, unless circumstances attendant on the disaster prevent or impede, promptly filed with the city secretary. 
(5)  Direction and control of the operations of the emergency management organization as well as the training of emergency management personnel. 
(6)  Determination of all questions of authority and responsibility that may arise within the emergency management organization of the city. 
(7)  Maintenance of liaison with other municipal, county, district, state, regional or federal emergency management organizations. 
(8)  Marshaling of all necessary personnel, equipment, or supplies from any department of the city to aid in the carrying out of the provisions of the emergency management plan. 
(9)  Supervision of the drafting and execution of mutual aid agreements, in cooperation with the representatives of the state and of other local political subdivisions of the state, and the drafting and execution, if deemed desirable, of an agreement with the county in which said city is located and with other municipalities within the county, for the county-wide coordination of emergency management efforts. 
(10)  Supervision of, and final authorization for the procurement of all necessary supplies and equipment, including acceptance of private contributions which may be offered for the purpose of improving emergency management within the city. 
(11)  Authorizing of agreements, after approval by the city attorney, for use of private property for public shelter and other purposes. 
(12)  Surveying the availability of existing personnel, equipment, supplies, and services which could be used during a disaster, as provided for herein. 
(13)  Other requirements as specified in the Texas Disaster Act (Chapter 418 of the Government Code). 
(Ord. No. 2003-04, § 2, 3-11-03) 
Sec. 9-28. - Emergency management plan. 
    A comprehensive emergency management plan shall be developed and maintained in a current state. The plan shall set forth the form of the organization; establish and designate divisions and functions; assign responsibilities, tasks, duties, and powers; and designate officers and employees to carry out the provisions of this chapter. As provided by state law, the plan shall follow the standards and criteria established by the State Division of Emergency Management of the State of Texas. Insofar as possible, the form of organization, titles, and terminology shall conform to the recommendations of the state division of emergency management. When approved, it shall be the duty of all departments and agencies to perform the functions assigned by the plan and to maintain their portion of the plan in a current state of readiness at all times. The emergency management plan shall be considered supplementary to this chapter and have the effect of law during the time of a disaster. 
(Ord. No. 2003-04, § 3, 3-11-03) 
Sec. 9-29. - Interjurisdictional program. 
    The mayor is hereby authorized to join with the County Judge of the County of Nolan and the mayors of the other cities in said county in the formation of an inter-jurisdictional emergency management program for the county, and shall have the authority to cooperate in the preparation of an inter-jurisdictional emergency management plan and in the appointment of a joint emergency management coordinator, as well as all powers necessary to participate in a county-wide program of emergency management insofar as said program may affect the city. 
(Ord. No. 2003-04, § 4, 3-11-03) 
Sec. 9-30. - Override. 
    At all times when the orders, rules, and regulations made and promulgated pursuant to this chapter shall be in effect, they shall supersede and override all existing ordinances, orders, rules, and regulations insofar as the latter may be inconsistent therewith. 
(Ord. No. 2003-04, § 5, 3-11-03) 
Sec. 9-31. - Liability. 
    This chapter is an exercise by the city of its governmental functions for the protection of the public peace, health, and safety and neither the city, the agents and representatives of said city, nor any individual, receiver, firm, partnership, corporation, association, or trustee, nor any of the agents thereof, in good faith carrying out, complying with or attempting to comply with, any order, rule, or regulation promulgated pursuant to the provisions of this chapter shall be liable for any damage sustained to persons as the result of said activity. Any person owning or controlling real estate or other premises who voluntarily and without compensation grants to the city a license of privilege, or otherwise permits the city to inspect, designate, and use the whole or any part or parts of such real estate or premises for the purpose of sheltering persons during an actual, impending, or practice enemy attack or natural or man-made disaster shall, together with his successors in interest, if any, not be civilly liable for the death of, or injury to, any person on or about such real estate or premises under such license, privilege or other permission or for loss of, or damage to, the property of such person. 
(Ord. No. 2003-04, § 6, 3-11-03) 
Sec. 9-32. - Commitment of funds. 
    No person shall have the right to expend any public funds of the city in carrying out any emergency management activity authorized by this chapter without prior approval by the city council, nor shall any person have any right to bind the city by contract, agreement, or otherwise without prior and specific approval of the city council unless during a declared disaster. During a declared disaster, the mayor may expend and/or commit public funds of the city when deemed prudent and necessary for the protection of health, life, or property. 
(Ord. No. 2003-04, § 7, 3-11-03) 
Sec. 9-33. - Offenses; penalties. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person willfully to obstruct, hinder, or delay any member of the emergency management organization in the enforcement of any rule or regulation issued pursuant to this chapter. 
(b)  It shall likewise be unlawful for any person to wear, carry, or display any emblem, insignia, or any other means of identification as a member of the emergency management organization of the city, unless authority to do so has been granted to such person by the proper officials. 
(c)  Convictions for violations of the provisions of this chapter shall be punishable by fine not to exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) and for confinement in jail for up to one hundred eighty (180) days. 
(Ord. No. 2003-04, § 8, 3-11-03) 
Chapter 10 - FIRE PREVENTION AND PROTECTION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Authority of city commission to provide for fire prevention, Art. III, § 21; authority to provide for fire department, Art. III, § 19. 
Cross reference- Fire prevention at municipal airport, § 3-28 et seq.; fire districts, § 7-3; fire prevention, § 7-76(c); electricity, § 9-1 et seq.; drilling and operating rules in connection with drilling for oil and gas, § 22-51 et seq. 
State Law reference- Fire prevention powers of city, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 1175(25), (34), 1011. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 10-1. - Code adopted. 
    The specifications, rules and regulations entitled International Fire Prevention Code, 2012 Edition thereof, as published by the International Code Council, Inc., a copy of which is on file in the in the fire marshal's office, is hereby enacted and adopted as the fire prevention code for the city, and is hereby incorporated herein by reference and made part of this Code as fully copied in length, except insofar as it may be inconsistent with the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 89-05, 2-14-89; Ord. No. 2003-01, 2-11-03; Ord. No. 2013-12, 5-14-13) 
Cross reference- Building code adopted, § 7-16; gas code adopted, § 7-31; mechanical code adopted, § 7-46; electrical code adopted, § 9-196; housing code adopted, § 15-1; plumbing code adopted, § 7-61. 
Sec. 10-2. - Amendment to adopted fire prevention code. 
(a)  The Fire Prevention Code adopted by section 10-1 is amended by deleting Chapter 4 entitled "Permits and Certificates." 
(b)  The Standard Fire Prevention Code of the City of Sweetwater, Texas, is amended by adding Section 603.6.4 through Section 603.6.9 to read as follows: 
    603.6.4. No single-family dwelling, or multiple occupancy dwelling shall be built, or constructed, and no structural changes, repairs, or additions of a value in excess of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) shall be made thereto unless and until the structure has installed therein an approved products of combustion detection system. 
All single- or multiple-family dwelling units, hotel units, and motel units built or constructed after October 15, 1990, shall be provided with a detector of products of combustion detector wired to a proper unswitched 120 volt electrical circuit, and be equipped with a battery backup. 
The detectors shall be capable of sensing visible or invisible particles of combustion. Detectors sensitive only to heat are not acceptable. Alarm signaling devices shall be rated at not fewer than 85 decibels at 10 feet, and shall be clearly audible in adjacent rooms when all intervening doors are closed. For the purpose of installation and maintenance only, the applicable section of the National Fire Protection Association No. 74 shall be considered accepted engineering practices. All detectors shall be listed by Underwriters Laboratories. 
    603.6.5. No single-family dwelling or multiple occupancy dwelling built before October 15, 1990, shall be sold, rented or leased until the structure has installed therein an approved products of combustion detection system. 
    603.6.6. For all single- or multiple-family dwelling units, hotel units, and motel units constructed after October 15, 1990, the required smoke detectors must be wired directly to the building's power supply. The detectors must be permanently wired to a proper unswitched 120-volt electrical circuit, and be equipped with a battery backup to insure the signal level is sufficient to awaken the sleeping occupants when all intervening doors are closed. 
    603.6.7. All single or multiple occupancy dwelling units meeting the requirements of 603.6.5 must have installed a products of combustion detector that operates by battery or 120-volt power supply. 
    603.6.8. All devices, combinations of devices, and equipment required by this section are to be installed in conformance with the City of Sweetwater Building Code 903.2. 
    603.6.9. Penalty-Any owner of a building or structure who fails to comply with the provisions of this ordinance shall be fined not more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). 
(Ord. of 6-12-79; Ord. No. 89-05, 2-14-89; Ord. No. 90-22, § 1, 10-9-90) 
Sec. 10-3. - Arson reward. 
    Any person furnishing information or assistance leading to the arrest and conviction of any person found guilty of arson within the city shall be paid a reward of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00). 
(Ord. of 7-22-57) 
Sec. 10-4. - Sale of fireworks prohibited; use restricted. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, within the city, any firecracker, Roman candle, skyrocket or any other fireworks. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to discharge, ignite or explode anywhere within the city, any firecracker, Roman candle, skyrocket or any other character of fireworks. 
(c)  Reserved. 
(d)  Property which was not a part of the city on December 29, 1983 shall be exempt from the provisions of subsection (a) until January 10, 1990. 
(Ord. of 12-10-56; Ord. No. 83-50-218/III, 12-29-83; Ord. No. 86-28, 6-19-86; Ord. No. 87-13, 12-8-87) 
Sec. 10-5. - Violations. 
    Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of the code hereby adopted or who fails to comply therewith shall severally for each and every such violation and noncompliance be guilty of a misdemeanor punishable by a fine of not less than ten dollars ($10.00) nor more than two hundred dollars ($200.00), provided, however, that each day a violation exists shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 89-05, 2-14-89) 
Sec. 10-6. - Liability for clean-up costs associated with hazardous material spill. 
(a)  Any party(ies) who accidentally, negligently, or intentionally causes or is responsible for a spill of hazardous material(s) affecting property within the city shall be liable for the payment of all costs incurred by the fire department, and the other departments and agencies which assist it, to abate such an event. The remedy provided by this section shall be in addition to any other remedies provided by law. 
(b)  For purposes of this section "hazardous materials" shall be defined as any substances or materials in a quantity or from which, in the determination of the fire chief or his authorized representative, poses an unreasonable and imminent risk to the life, health or safety of persons or property or to the ecological balance of the environment, and shall include, but not be limited to, such substances as explosives, radioactive materials, petroleum or petroleum products or gases, poisons, ebiologic (biologic) agents, flammables and corrosives. 
(c)  For purposes of this section, costs incurred by the fire department or other departments of the city shall include, but shall not be limited to, all actual out-of-pocket expenses attributable to the abatement or clean-up of any hazardous materials incident including costs of equipment operations, costs of material utilized, costs of specialists, experts or other contract labor not in the full-time employment of the city, overtime costs and any other incidental costs incurred by the City of Sweetwater result of said incident. 
(d)  The authority to recover costs under this section shall not include actual fire suppression, rescue, medical, etc. services which are normally or usually provided by the fire department and other city departments and are unrelated to a particular hazardous material(s) incident. 
(Ord. No. 89-23, §§ I-IV, 10-10-89) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 89-23, §§ I-IV, adopted Oct. 10, 1989, did not specifically amend the Code and at the discretion of the editor said provisions have been included herein as § 10-6. 
Secs. 10-7-10-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - FIRE PREVENTION DIVISION 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 10-16. - Composition. 
    The fire prevention division shall consist of a fire marshal and all fire department personnel who may be assigned fire prevention duties. 
Sec. 10-17. - Right of entry. 
    The fire chief, fire marshal, or any officer or member of the fire department designated by the fire chief or fire marshal, shall have right or authority to enter any building or upon any premises in the city at any reasonable business hours for the purpose of making investigations consistent with the duties imposed by this article. 
Sec. 10-18. - Authority to examine premises where fire occurs. 
    The fire chief or fire marshal shall have the authority at all times, day or night, when necessary in the performance of their duties, to enter upon and examine buildings or premises where any fire has occurred or any adjoining buildings or premises, when in their judgment it is proper to do so. 
Secs. 10-19-10-30. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - FIRE MARSHAL 

Sec. 10-31. - Position created. 
    The position of city fire marshal is hereby created. 
(Code 1956, § 7-10) 
Sec. 10-32. - Appointment; responsibility to fire chief. 
    The fire marshal shall be appointed by the city manager and shall have immediate supervision over all activities of the fire prevention division. He shall be directly responsible to the chief of the fire department for the proper operation of the fire prevention division. 
(Code 1956, § 7-17) 
Sec. 10-33. - General duties. 
    In addition to the other duties prescribed by this Code or by state law, the fire marshal shall perform such duties as may be prescribed by the city manager or the fire chief. 
Sec. 10-34. - Personnel and equipment. 
    Under the direction of the fire chief, the fire marshal shall have control and supervision over all employees, cars, and equipment assigned to fire prevention duties. 
Sec. 10-35. - Investigation of causes of fires. 
    The fire marshal shall cause to be investigated the origin and circumstances of every fire occurring in the city by which life was jeopardized or lost, or property has been damaged or destroyed. 
Sec. 10-36. - Periodic inspection of buildings. 
    The fire marshal shall cause to be inspected regularly all business buildings and public buildings for the purpose of correcting life and fire hazards. 
Sec. 10-37. - Records to be kept. 
    The fire marshal shall see that proper records of the functions of his office are made and kept on file. 
Sec. 10-38. - Reports. 
    The fire marshal shall promptly make any reports required by state or local law, the fire chief, city manager, or state board of insurance. 
Sec. 10-39. - Duty to study fire hazard provisions, etc. 
    It shall be the duty of the fire marshal to study ordinances regarding fire hazards and fire prevention and all matters relating thereto and to hear suggestions and complaints from all persons. 
Sec. 10-40. - Response time requirements for fire department personnel. 
    The city commission hereby legislates that all fire suppression personnel, hired on or after July 10, 2007, must certify, prior to being hired by the city, that each resides within a 20-minute response time. Additionally, each firefighter must affirm that he or she will continue to reside within a 20-minute response time while he or she remains employed as a City of Sweetwater firefighter. Failure to comply with this pre-employment agreement will result in dismissal from the City of Sweetwater Fire Department. 
(Ord. No. 2007-3, § 2, 7-10-07) 
Chapter 11 - FLOOD DAMAGE PREVENTION[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 87-03, adopted Feb. 10, 1987, repealed former Ch. 11, relative to flood hazard prevention, and enacted in lieu thereof a new Ch. 11 to read as herein set out in §§ 11-1-11-16. The provisions of former Ch. 11 derived from §§ 1, 2, 5-13, and 15-21 of an ordinance adopted Dec. 9, 1980, and from original codification. 
Cross reference- Water and wastewater, Ch. 29. 
State Law reference- Authority to enact flood-insurance ordinance, V.T.C.A., Water Code, § 16.315. 

Sec. 11-1. - Statutory authorization. 
    The Legislature of the State of Texas has in Vernon's Texas Code Annotated, Water Code, Section 16.315, delegated the responsibility to local government units to adopt regulations designed to minimize flood losses. Therefore, the City Commission of Sweetwater, Texas, does ordain as follows. 
(Ord. No. 87-03, 2-10-87) 
Sec. 11-2. - Findings of fact. 
(1)  The flood hazard areas of the City of Sweetwater are subject to periodic inundation which results in loss of life and property, health and safety hazards, disruption of commerce and governmental services, and extraordinary public expenditures for flood protection and relief, all of which adversely affect the public health, safety and general welfare. 
(2)  These flood losses are created by the cumulative effect of obstructions in floodplains which cause an increase in flood heights and velocities, and by the occupancy of flood hazards areas by uses vulnerable to floods and hazardous to other lands because they are inadequately elevated, flood-proofed or otherwise protected from flood damage. 
(Ord. No. 87-03, 2-10-87) 
Sec. 11-3. - Statement of purpose. 
    It is the purpose of this chapter to promote public health, safety and general welfare and to minimize public and private losses due to flood conditions in specific areas by provisions designed to: 
(1)  Protect human life and health; 
(2)  Minimize expenditure of public money for costly flood control projects; 
(3)  Minimize the need for rescue and relief efforts associated with flooding and generally undertaken at the expense of the general public; 
(4)  Minimize prolonged business interruptions; 
(5)  Minimize damage to public facilities and utilities such as water and gas mains, electric, telephone and sewer lines, streets and bridges located in floodplains; 
(6)  Help maintain a stable tax base by providing for the sound use and development of floodprone areas in such a manner as to minimize future flood blight areas; and 
(7)  Insure that potential buyers are notified that the property is in a flood area. 
(Ord. No. 87-03, 2-10-87) 
Sec. 11-4. - Methods of reducing flood losses. 
    In order to accomplish its purposes, this chapter uses the following methods: 
(1)  Restrict or prohibit uses that are dangerous to health, safety or property in times of flood, or cause excessive increases in flood heights or velocities; 
(2)  Require that uses vulnerable to floods, including facilities which serve such uses, be protected against flood damage at the time of initial construction; 
(3)  Control the alteration of natural floodplains, stream channels, and natural protective barriers, which are involved in the accommodation of flood waters; 
(4)  Control filling, grading, dredging and other development which may increase flood damage; 
(5)  Prevent or regulate the construction of flood barriers which will unnaturally divert flood waters or which may increase flood hazards to other lands. 
(Ord. No. 87-03, 2-10-87) 
Sec. 11-5. - Definitions. 
    Unless specifically defined below, words or phrases used in this chapter shall be interpreted to give them the meaning they have in common usage and to give this chapter its most reasonable application. 
    Appeal means a request for review of the floodplain administrator's interpretation of any provision of this chapter or a request for a variance. 
    Area of shallow flooding means a designated AO, AH, or VO zone on a community's flood insurance rate map (FIRM) with a one (1) percent chance or greater annual chance of flooding to an average depth of one (1) to three (3) feet where a clearly defined channel does not exist, where the path of flooding is unpredictable and where velocity flow may be evident. Such flooding is characterized by ponding or sheet flow. 
    Area of special flood hazard is the land in the floodplain within a community subject to a one (1) percent or greater chance of flooding in any given year. The area may be designated as Zone A on the flood hazard boundary map (FHBM). After detailed ratemaking has been completed in preparation for publication of the FIRM, Zone A usually is refined into Zones A, AE, AH, AO, A1-99, VO, V1-30, VE or V. 
    Base flood means the flood having a one (1) percent chance of being equalled or exceeded in any given year. 
    Critical feature means an integral and readily identifiable part of a flood protection system, without which the flood protection provided by the entire system would be compromised. 
    Development means any manmade change in improved and unimproved real estate, including but not limited to buildings or other structures, mining, dredging, filling, grading, paving, excavation or drilling operations. 
    Elevated building means a nonbasement building (i) built, in the case of a building in Zones A1-30, AE, A, A99, AO, AH, B, C, X, and D, to have the top of the elevated floor, or in the case of a building in Zones V1-30, VE, or V, to have the bottom of the lowest horizontal structure member of the elevated floor elevated above the ground level by means of pilings, columns (posts and piers), or shear walls parallel to the floor of the water and (ii) adequately anchored so as not to impair the structural integrity of the building during a flood of up to the magnitude of the base flood. In the case of Zones A1-30, AE, A, A99, AO, AH, B, C, X, D, "elevated building" also includes a building elevated by means of fill or solid foundation perimeter walls with openings sufficient to facilitate the unimpeded movement of flood waters. In the case of Zones V1-30, VE, or V, "elevated building" also includes a building otherwise meeting the definition of "elevated building," even though the lower area is enclosed by means of breakaway walls if the breakaway walls meet the standards of Section 60.3(e)(5) of the National Flood Insurance Program regulations. 
    Existing construction means for the purposes of determining rates, structures for which the "start of construction" commenced before the effective date of the FIRM on February 18, 1980. "Existing construction" may also be referred to as "existing structures." 
    Flood or flooding means a general and temporary condition or partial or complete inundation of normally dry land areas from: 
(1)  The overflow of inland or tidal waters; 
(2)  The unusual and rapid accumulation or run-off of surface waters from any source. 
    Flood insurance rate map (FIRM) means an official map of a community on which the Federal Emergency Management Agency has delineated both the areas of special flood hazards and the risk premium zones applicable to the community. 
    Flood insurance study is the official report provided by the Federal Emergency Management Agency. The report contains flood profiles, water surface elevation of the base flood, as well as the flood boundary-floodway map. 
    Floodplain or flood-prone area means any land area susceptible to being inundated by water from any source (see definition of flooding). 
    Flood protection system means those physical structural works for which funds have been authorized, appropriated, and expended and which have been constructed specifically to modify flooding in order to reduce the extent of the areas within a community subject to a "special flood hazard" and the extent of the depths of associated flooding. Such a system typically includes hurricane tidal barriers, dams, reservoirs, levees or dikes. These specialized flood modifying works are those constructed in conformance with sound engineering standards. 
    Floodway (regulatory floodway) means the channel of a river or other watercourse and the adjacent land areas that must be reserved in order to discharge the base flood without cumulatively increasing the water surface elevation more than a designated height. 
    Functionally dependent use means a use which cannot perform its intended purpose unless it is located or carried out in close proximity to water. The term includes only docking facilities, port facilities that are necessary for the loading and unloading of cargo or passengers, and ship building and ship repair facilities, but does not include long-term storage or related manufacturing facilities. 
    Habitable floor means any floor usable for the following purposes; which includes working, sleeping, eating, cooking or recreation, or a combination thereof. A floor used for storage purposes only is not a "habitable floor." 
    Highest adjacent grade means the highest natural elevation of the ground surface prior to construction next to the proposed walls of a structure. 
    Levee means a manmade structure, usually an earthen embankment, designed and constructed in accordance with sound engineering practices to contain, control, or divert the flow of water so as to provide protection from temporary flooding. 
    Levee system means a flood protection system which consists of a levee, or levees, and associated structures, such as closure and drainage devices, which are constructed and operated in accordance with sound engineering practices. 
    Lowest floor means the lowest floor of the lowest enclosed area (including basement). An unfinished or flood resistant enclosure, usable solely for parking or vehicles, building access or storage in an area other than a basement area is not considered a building's lowest floor; provided that such enclosure is not built so as to render the structure in violation of the applicable nonelevation design requirement of Section 60.3 of the National Flood Insurance Program regulations. 
    Manufactured home means a structure transportable in one or more sections, which is built on a permanent chassis and is designed for use with or without a permanent foundation when connected to the required utilities. For floodplain management purposes the term "manufactured home" also includes park trailers, travel trailers, and other similar vehicles placed on a site for greater than one hundred eighty (180) consecutive days. For insurance purposes the term "manufactured home" does not include park trailers, travel trailers, and other similar vehicles. 
    Mean sea level means, for purpose of the National Flood Insurance Program, the National Geodetic Vertical Datum (NGVD) of 1929 or other datum, to which base flood elevations shown on a community's flood insurance rate map are referenced. 
    New construction means, for floodplain management purposes, structures for which the "start of construction" commenced on or after the effective date of a floodplain management regulation adopted by a community. 
    Start of construction (for other than new construction or substantial improvements under the Coastal Barrier Resources Act (Pub. L 97-348), includes substantial improvement and means the date the building permit was issued, provided the actual start of construction, repair, reconstruction, placement, or other improvement was within one hundred eighty (180) days of the permit date. The actual start means either the first placement of permanent construction of a structure on a site, such as the pouring of slab or footings, the installation of piles, the construction of columns, or any work beyond the stage of excavation; or the placement of a manufactured home on a foundation. Permanent construction does not include land preparation, such as clearing, grading, and filling; nor does it include the installation of streets and/or walkways; nor does it include excavation for basement, footings, piers or foundations or the erection of temporary forms; nor does it include the installation on the property of accessory buildings, such as garages or sheds not occupied as dwelling units or not part of the main structure. 
    Structure means a walled and roofed building, including a gas or liquid storage tank, that is principally above ground, as well as a manufactured home. 
    Substantial improvement means any repair, reconstruction, or improvement of a structure, the cost of which equals or exceeds fifty (50) percent of the market value of the structure either (1) before the improvement or repair is started, or (2) if the structure has been damaged and is being restored, before the damage occurred. For the purpose of this definition "substantial improvement" is considered to occur when the first alteration of any wall, ceiling, floor or other structural part of the building commences, whether or not that alteration affects the external dimensions of the structure. The term does not, however, include either (1) any project for improvement of a structure to comply with existing state or local health, sanitary or safety code specification which are solely necessary to assure safe living conditions, or (2) any alteration of a structure listed in the Natural Register of Historic Places or a State Inventory of Historic Places. 
    Variance is a grant of relief to a person from the requirements of this chapter when specific enforcement would result in unnecessary hardship. A variance, therefore, permits construction or development in a manner otherwise prohibited by this chapter. (For full requirements see Section 60.6 of the National Flood Insurance Program regulations.) 
    Violation means the failure of a structure or other development to be fully compliant with the community's floodplain management regulations. A structure or other development without the elevation certificate, other certifications, or other evidence of compliance required in Section 60.3(b)(5), (c)(4), (c)(10), (d)(3), (e)(2), (e)(4), or (e)(5) is presumed to be in violation until such time as that documentation is provided. 
    Water surface elevation means the height, in relation to the National Geodetic Vertical Datum (NGVD) of 1929 (or other datum, where specified), of floods of various magnitudes and frequencies in the floodplains of coastal or riverine areas. 
(Ord. No. 87-03, 2-10-87) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 11-6. - General provisions. 
(1)  Lands to which this chapter applies. This chapter shall apply to all areas of special flood hazard within the jurisdiction of the City of Sweetwater, Texas. 
(2)  Basis for establishing the areas of special flood hazard. The areas of special flood hazard identified by the Federal Emergency Management Agency in a scientific and engineering report entitled "The Flood Insurance Study for City of Sweetwater," dated November 5, 1980, with accompanying flood insurance rate maps and flood boundary-floodway maps (FIRM and FBFM) and any revisions thereto are hereby adopted by reference and declared to be a part of this chapter. 
(3)  Establishment of development permit. A development permit shall be required to ensure conformance with the provisions of this chapter. 
(4)  Compliance. No structure or land shall hereafter be located, altered, or have its use changed without full compliance with the terms of this chapter and other applicable regulations. 
(5)  Abrogation and greater restrictions. This chapter is not intended to repeal, abrogate, or impair any existing easements, covenants, or deed restrictions. However, where this chapter and another conflict or overlap, whichever imposes the more stringent restrictions shall prevail. 
(6)  Interpretation. In the interpretation and application of this chapter, all provisions shall be (1) considered as minimum requirements; (2) liberally construed in favor of the governing body; and (3) deemed neither to limit nor repeal any other powers granted under state statutes. 
(7)  Warning and disclaimer or liability. The degree of flood protection required by this chapter is considered reasonable for regulatory purposes and is based on scientific and engineering considerations. On rare occasions greater floods can and will occur and flood heights may be increased by manmade or natural causes. This chapter does not imply that land outside the areas of special flood hazards or uses permitted within such areas will be free from flooding or flood damages. This chapter shall not create liability on the part of the community or any official or employee thereof for any flood damages that result from reliance on this chapter or any administrative decision lawfully made thereunder. 
(Ord. No. 87-03, 2-10-87) 
Sec. 11-7. - Designation of the floodplain administrator. 
    The building official is hereby appointed the floodplain administrator to administer and implement the provisions of this chapter and other appropriate sections of 44CFR (National Flood Insurance Program regulations) pertaining to floodplain management. 
(Ord. No. 87-03, 2-10-87) 
Sec. 11-8. - Duties and responsibilities of the floodplain administrator. 
    Duties and responsibilities of the floodplain administrator shall include, but not be limited to, the following: 
(1)  Maintain and hold open for public inspection all records pertaining to the provisions of this chapter. 
(2)  Review permit applications to determine whether proposed building site will be reasonably safe from flooding. 
(3)  Review, approve or deny all applications for development permits required by adoption of this chapter. 
(4)  Review permits for proposed development to assure that all necessary permits have been obtained from those federal, state or local governmental agencies (including Section 404 of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act Amendments of 1972, 33 U.S.C. 1334) from which prior approval is required. 
(5)  Where interpretation is needed as to the exact location of the boundaries of the areas of special flood hazards (for example, where there appears to be a conflict between a mapped boundary and actual field conditions) the floodplain administrator shall make the necessary interpretation. 
(6)  Notify, in riverine situations, adjacent communities and the state coordinating agency which is the Division of Emergency Management prior to any alteration or relocation of a watercourse, and submit evidence of such notification to the Federal Emergency Management Agency. 
(7)  Assure that the flood carrying capacity within the altered or relocated portion of any watercourse is maintained. 
(8)  When base flood elevation data has not been provided in accordance with section 11-6(2), the floodplain administrator shall obtain, review and reasonably utilize any base flood elevation data and floodway data available from a federal, state or other source, in order to administer the provisions of sections 11-1 through 11-16. 
(9)  When a regulatory floodway has not been designated, the floodplain administrator must require that no new construction, substantial improvements or other development (including fill) shall be permitted within Zones A1-30 and AE on the community's FIRM, unless it is demonstrated that the cumulative effect of the proposed development, when combined with all other existing and anticipated development, will not increase the water surface elevation of the base flood more than one foot at any point within the community. 
(10)  A semiannual inspection shall be made of all floodways designated in accordance with section 11-6(2). Results of the inspections will be provided to the city manager or his designee for appropriate action. 
(Ord. No. 87-03, 2-10-87; Ord. No. 91-01, 1-8-91) 
Sec. 11-9. - Permit procedures. 
(1)  Application for a development permit shall be presented to the floodplain administrator on forms furnished by him/her and may include, but not be limited to, plans in duplicate drawn to scale showing the location, dimensions, and elevation of proposed landscape alterations, existing and proposed structures, and the location of the foregoing in relation to areas of special flood hazard. Additionally, the following information is required: 
(a)  Elevation (in relation to mean sea level), of the lowest floor (including basement) of all new and substantially improved structures; 
(b)  Elevation in relation to mean sea level to which any nonresidential structure shall be floodproofed; 
(c)  A certificate from a registered professional engineer or architect that the nonresidential floodproofed structure shall meet the floodproofing criteria of the applicable sections 11-11 through 11-16; 
(d)  Description of the extent to which any watercourse or natural drainage will be altered or relocated as a result of proposed development; 
(e)  Maintain a record of all such information in accordance with section 11-8. 
(2)  Approval or denial of a development permit by the floodplain administrator shall be based on all of the provisions of this chapter and the following relevant factors: 
(a)  The danger to life and property due to flooding or erosion damage. 
(b)  The susceptibility of the proposed facility and its contents to flood damage and the effect of such damage on the individual owner. 
(c)  The danger that materials may be swept onto other lands to the injury of others. 
(d)  The compatibility of the proposed use with existing and anticipated development. 
(e)  The safety of access to the property in times of flood for ordinary or emergency vehicles. 
(f)  The costs of providing governmental services during and after flood conditions including maintenance and repair of streets and bridges, and public utilities and facilities such as sewer, gas, electrical and water systems. 
(g)  The expected heights, velocity, duration, rate of rise and sediment transport of the flood waters and the effects of wave action, if applicable, expected at the site. 
(h)  The necessity to the facility of a waterfront location, where applicable. 
(i)  The availability of alternative locations, not subject to flooding or erosion damage, for the proposed use. 
(j)  The relationship of the proposed use to the comprehensive plan for that area. 
(Ord. No. 87-03, 2-10-87) 
Sec. 11-10. - Variance procedures. 
(1)  The board of adjustment as established by the city zoning ordinance shall hear and render judgment on requests for variances from the requirements of this chapter. 
(2)  The board of adjustment shall hear and render judgment on an appeal only when it is alleged there is an error in any requirement, decision, or determination made by the floodplain administrator in the enforcement or administration of this chapter. 
(3)  Any person or persons aggrieved by the decision of the board of adjustment may appeal such decision to a court of competent jurisdiction pursuant to Vernon's Annotated Civil Statute, Article 1011a et. seq. 
(4)  The floodplain administrator shall maintain a record of all actions involving an appeal and shall report variances to the Federal Emergency Management Agency upon request. 
(5)  Variances may be issued for the reconstruction, rehabilitation or restoration of structures listed on the National Register of Historic Places or the State Inventory of Historic Places, without regard to the procedures set forth in the remainder of this chapter. 
(6)  Variances may be issued for new construction and substantial improvements to be erected on a lot of one-half (1/2) acre or less in size contiguous to and surrounded by lots with existing structures constructed below the base flood level, providing the relevant factors in section 11-9(2) of this chapter have been fully considered. As the lot size increases beyond the one-half (1/2) acre, the technical justification required for issuing the variances increases. 
(7)  Upon consideration of the factors noted above and the intent of this chapter, the board of adjustment may attach such conditions to the granting of variances as it deems necessary to further the purpose and objectives of this chapter (section 11-3). 
(8)  Variances shall not be issued within any designated floodway if any increase in flood levels during the base flood discharge would result. 
(9)  Prerequisites for granting variances: 
(a)  Variances shall only be issued upon a determination that the variance is the minimum necessary, considering the flood hazard, to afford relief. 
(b)  Variances shall only be issued upon, (i) showing a good and sufficient cause; (ii) a determination that failure to grant the variance would result in exceptional hardship to the applicant, and (iii) a determination that the granting of a variance will not result in increased flood heights, additional threats to public safety, extraordinary public expense, create nuisances, cause fraud on or victimization of the public, or conflict with existing local laws or ordinances. 
(c)  Any applicant to whom a variance is granted shall be given written notice that the structure will be permitted to be built with the lowest floor elevation below the base flood elevation, and that the cost of flood insurance will be commensurate with the increased risk resulting from the reduced lowest floor elevation. 
(10)  Variances may be issued for new construction and substantial improvements and for other development necessary for the conduct of a functionally dependent use provided that (i) the criteria outlined in section 11-10, (1) through (9) are met, and (ii) the structure or other development is protected by methods that minimize flood damages during the base flood and create no additional threats to public safety. 
(Ord. No. 87-03, 2-10-87) 
Sec. 11-11. - Provisions for flood standard reduction; general standards. 
    In all areas of special flood hazards the following provisions are required for all new construction and substantial improvements: 
(1)  All new construction or substantial improvements shall be designed (or modified) and adequately anchored to prevent flotation, collapse or lateral movement of the structure resulting from hydrodynamic and hydrostatic loads, including the effects of buoyancy;
