ARTICLE II. - HUMAN RELATIONS COMMITTEE 

Sec. 15.5-21. - Public policy declared. 
    It is hereby declared to be the public policy of the City of Sweetwater that all of its residents and persons subject to its jurisdiction should enjoy equal freedom to pursue their aspirations and that discrimination against any individual or group because of race, creed, color, sex or national origin or handicap status is detrimental to the peace, progress and welfare of the city. 
(Ord. No. 93-07, § 1, 6-8-93) 
Sec. 15.5-22. - Human Relations Committee created; composition; compensation of members. 
    It is hereby created a committee on human relations to be composed of nine (9) members appointed by the city commission. Each member of the committee shall be a resident of the city. As nearly as is reasonably possible, the membership shall be fairly representative of all the several economic, religious, cultural, ethnic and racial groups comprising the population of the city. The human relations committee shall serve without compensation. 
(Ord. No. 93-07, § 2, 6-8-93) 
Sec. 15.5-23. - Terms of members; filling vacancies. 
    Each member of the committee shall be appointed to serve a term of two (2) years or until a successor is appointed and qualified; provided, however, that on the initial committee four (4) members shall be appointed for a term of one (1) year; five (5) members shall be appointed for a term of two (2) years. Four (4) alternate members shall be appointed to the committee to serve in the absence of members. On the initial committee, two (2) alternate members shall be appointed for a term of one (1) year; two (2) alternate members shall be appointed for a term of two (2) years. Each year thereafter the city commission shall appoint to fill expiring terms, each of such appointments to be for a term of two (2) years. In the event any member of the committee resigns or terminates his service for any cause, the city commission shall appoint a qualified successor to fill such unexpired term. 
(Ord. No. 93-07, § 3, 6-8-93) 
Sec. 15.5-24. - Powers and duties. 
    The human relations committee shall have the following duties: 
(1)  To advise and consult with the city commission, school trustees, hospital district board, county commissioners, and others on matters involving racial, religious, ethnic or other discrimination. 
(2)  To recommend measures designed to eliminate prejudice and discrimination. 
(3)  To promote and encourage communications between and cooperation of all groups interested in bettering community relations. 
(Ord. No. 93-07, § 4, 6-8-93) 
Sec. 15.5-25. - Organization. 
    Members of the committee shall be sworn to uphold the constitution and the laws of the United States and the state and charter of the city. Immediately following their appointment and annually thereafter the members of the committee shall meet to elect a chairman, vice-chairman and secretary. The committee shall adopt rules and regulations, subject to the approval of the city commission, pertaining to the performance of its duties and the time and frequency of its meetings. 
(Ord. No. 93-07, § 5, 6-8-93) 
Sec. 15.5-26. - Source of funds for expenditures. 
    The city's human relations committee shall not make any expenditures of any money nor incur any liability during any current year beyond the amount of money appropriated or set apart in the annual budget of the city's human relations committee as authorized and approved by the city commission for such purpose. 
(Ord. No. 93-07, § 6, 6-8-93) 
Chapter 16 - LAKES AND WATERCOURSES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Plumbing code, § 7-61 et seq.; flood hazard prevention, § 11-1 et seq.; parks and recreation, § 23-1 et seq.; water and wastewater, § 29-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 16-1. - Adoption of state laws and the rules of Texas Resource Conservation Commission on abatement and prevention of pollution. 
    The Texas Water Safety Act being V.T.C.A. Parks and Wildlife Code, Section 31.001 et seq. and the Texas Game and Fish, being V.T.C.A. Parks and Wildlife Code, Section 1.001 et seq., the Texas Water Quality Act, being V.T.C.A. Water, Section 21.001 et seq., and the Texas Health and Safety Code, Chapter 366, entitled "On-Site City Sewage Disposal Systems," and the Texas Natural Resource Conservation Commission's rules on abatement and prevention of pollution and the prevention of injury to the public health are hereby adopted, as fully as if set forth at length in this Code and are hereby incorporated herein by reference and made a part of this Code. 
(Ord. of 4-13-76; Ord. No. 92-13, 9-8-92) 
Sec. 16-2. - Harming domesticated animals and fowl prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to kill or harm any animal or water fowl which has been domesticated and which is on property of the city at any city lake. 
(Ord. of 8-8-78) 
Sec. 16-3. - Flotation devices. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to use empty metal barrels as flotation devices at Lake Sweetwater or Sweetwater Oak Creek Reservoir. Metal barrels completely filled with styrofoam or any similar material, or barrels made of styrofoam or similar material shall not constitute a violation of this section but may be used as flotation devices. 
(Ord. of 1-10-78) 
Sec. 16-4. - Dumping prohibited. 
    No waste of any kind shall be dumped or discharged into the waters or on the shoreline of any city-owned lake or lake property. 
(Ord. of 4-13-76) 
Sec. 16-5. - Glass containers prohibited on lakes. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to possess or use glass containers, glass receptacles, or articles made of glass while on the premises of designated beach areas at any city lake. 
(Ord. of 7-8-75) 
Sec. 16-6. - Swimming restricted to designated areas. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to swim in any city-owned lake or reservoir, except in those areas specifically designated as swimming areas. 
Sec. 16-7. - Lake site leases. 
    The annual lease fee for all campsites at Lake Sweetwater and at Oak Creek Lake in Nolan County and Coke County, respectively, shall be in the amount of six hundred dollars ($600.00) per year for all campsite leases. 
    A fee of seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) shall be charged by the city for the transfer of all campsite leases from one (1) lessee to another lessee. 
    The policy of the City of Sweetwater, Texas as to all campsite leases at Lake Sweetwater and at Oak Creek Lake shall be: 
(1)  The city will not be obligated to establish or maintain any roads servicing campsites at either lake. 
(2)  The city will not be obligated to furnish any city services including, but not limited to, the collection of trash and garbage at campsites at either lake. 
(3)  The city will not be obligated to furnish any police protection or fire protection for improvements erected on campsites at either lake. 
    The annual leases may be adjusted annually. 
(Ord. of 9-11-79; Ord. No. 2008-01, 2-12-08) 
Sec. 16-8. - Rates for use of recreational facilities. 
    The rates for permits to use the recreational facilities owned by the city at Lake Sweetwater shall be as established from time to time by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 83-06-13/III, 2-22-83) 
Sec. 16-9. - Restrictions on the construction and maintenance of docks, boathouses and other structures in Lake Sweetwater. 
(a)  The construction and maintenance of docks, boathouses, and other structures in the waters of Lake Sweetwater affect the public safety and the public health and, after the effective date of this section (July 10, 1984), all docks, rafts, or other structures maintained within the waters of Lake Sweetwater shall be subject to the following rules and limitations: 
(1)  All boathouses, docks, and other structures which are placed in the waters of Lake Sweetwater may be maintained only by a registered campsite leaseholder on the shores of such lake and shall be positioned or located in such twenty-five (25) feet on either side on the center of the cabin or lease and shall be constructed in such a manner as not to affect the enjoyment of adjacent or nearby campsite leases owned by other persons. 
(2)  Any structure which is the subject matter of this section shall be located in the waters of Lake Sweetwater so as not to extend further than one hundred twenty-five (125) feet into the lake as such distance is measured from the high water line. 
(3)  All structures contemplated by this section shall be constructed in such a fashion as to permit them to be relocated in conformity with this section as the lake level rises or falls. 
(4)  Enforcement shall be conducted by the city only after a signed complaint is presented to the city manager. 
(b)  Any structures maintained in the waters of Lake Sweetwater and which structures are in violation of the requirements of this section are deemed to constitute a public nuisance and may be summarily abated by the City of Sweetwater. 
(c)  The violation of this section shall constitute a misdemeanor punishable by a fine not to exceed two hundred dollars ($200.00). Provided, further, that each day that a structure is maintained in violation of this section shall constitute a separate offense. Provided, however, that there shall be no prosecution of violations of this section until thirty (30) days after the effective date (July 10, 1984). 
(Ord. No. 84-11-277/III, 7-10-84) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 84-11-277/III, adopted July 10, 1984 did not specifically amend the Code, hence codification of said ordinance as § 16-9, was at the discretion of the editor. 
Sec. 16-10. - Fireworks prohibited. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to discharge, ignite or explode anywhere on city-owned lakes or on property owned by the city adjacent to said lakes, any firecracker, Roman candle, skyrocket or any other character of fireworks. 
(b)  The annual pyrotechnic display sponsored by the Sweetwater Junior Chamber of Commerce shall be an exception to this section provided such display is conducted by a licensed pyrotechnician and comports with the laws of the State of Texas in all respects. 
(Ord. No. 90-15, 8-14-90) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 90-15, adopted Aug. 14, 1990, amended the Code by the addition of § 16-10 and provided further that any violation of any provision of this ordinance shall constitute a misdemeanor punishable by a fine not to exceed $200.00. 
Sec. 16-11. - On-site sewage disposal systems, Oak Creek Reservoir or city-owned property surrounding or adjacent to Oak Creek Reservoir. 
(a)  The provisions of Chapter 366 of the Texas Health and Safety Code and the Rules of the Texas Natural Resource Conservation Commission promulgated for the regulation of on-site sewage facilities and for the abatement or prevention of pollution and the prevention of injury to the public health, as now promulgated or hereafter amended, are hereby adopted by the City of Sweetwater and shall apply to the construction, modification, installation, evaluation or enforcement of on-site sewage disposal systems located on city-owned land in the vicinity of Oak Creek Reservoir or on city-owned leases adjacent to Oak Creek Reservoir. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to begin to construct, alter, repair, or extend an on-site sewage disposal system that is owned by another person unless the owner or owner's representative shows proof of a permit and approved plan from the authorized agent of the City of Sweetwater. 
(c)  The fees for permits for construction or operation of an on-site sewage facility shall be two hundred dollars ($200.00) for a conventional design and four hundred dollars ($400.00) for a professional design. The application procedure for permits shall be as promulgated by the city manager of the City of Sweetwater. 
(d)  The city manager shall appoint a designated representative who is qualified pursuant to the provisions of Chapter 366 of the Texas Health and Safety Code to issue permits, make percolation tests, system designs and inspections subject to the approval of the City of Sweetwater. 
(e)  The designated representative may routinely inspect on-site sewage facilities to assure continued compliance with the rules promulgated by the Texas Natural Resource Conservation Commission. A person who violates any of these rules shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction shall be punished by a fine of not less than ten dollars ($10.00) nor more than two hundred dollars ($200.00). Each day that a violation occurs shall constitute a separate offense. 
(f)  The jurisdiction for the prosecution of a suit instituted under this section is in the Justice of the Peace Court in the precinct in which the violation is alleged to have occurred. 
(g)  Whenever it appears that a violation or the threat of a violation of any of the terms and conditions of the rules promulgated by the Texas Natural Resource Conservation Commission has occurred or is occurring, the City of Sweetwater may institute a suit in district court for injunctive relief or civil penalties or both against the person who committed, is committing or is threatening to commit the violation. Such suits may not be instituted unless authorized by resolution of the city commission. 
(Ord. No. 92-13, 9-8-92) 
Sec. 16-12. - Hours of operation. 
(a)  The city beach shall be closed to the general public from 9:00 p.m. to 5:00 a.m. each day. It shall be unlawful for any person to use, loiter or be present on the area of the city beach of the City of Sweetwater from the hours of 9:00 p.m. to 5:00 a.m. each day. 
(b)  A violation of this section shall constitute a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof, be punishable by a fine not to exceed two hundred dollars ($200.00). 
(Ord. No. 98-09, 4-14-98) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 98-09, adopted April 14, 1998, amended the Code by adding provisions designated as § 16-11. Inasmuch as there were already provisions so designated, the provisions have been redesignated as § 16-12, at the discretion of the editor. 
Secs. 16-13-16-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - HUNTING AND FISHING 

Sec. 16-21. - Hunting, discharge of firearms, prohibited; an exception. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to discharge any firearm on any property adjacent to a city-owned lake or reservoir. It shall be unlawful for any person to hunt on any property adjacent to a city-owned lake or reservoir except Lake Trammell. Bow hunting only will be permitted on the city-owned property adjacent to Lake Trammell and such bow hunting shall be conducted pursuant to the regulations promulgated by the Texas Parks and Wildlife Commission and the Sweetwater Bow Hunters Association. The rules and regulations promulgated by the Sweetwater Bow Hunters Association shall be approved by the City Manager and shall be prominently displayed at the Lake Trammell Concession Stand. 
(Code 1956, §§ 14-7, 14-8, Ord. No. 89-24, 10-16-89) 
Sec. 16-22. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 95-07, adopted June 6, 1995, deleted § 16-22 in its entirety. Formerly, § 16-22 pertained to the requirement of a fishing permit and derived from § 14-2 of the 1956 Code. 
Sec. 16-23. - Same-Fees. 
(a)  For each permit required by the preceding section, the person receiving the same shall pay to the city such fees as may be prescribed by the city commission. 
(b)  The city secretary is hereby authorized to receive and collect such fees for the city. 
(Code 1956, § 14-3) 
Sec. 16-24. - Same-Issuance. 
    The city secretary is hereby authorized to issue the permit required by section 16-22 of this Code to any person, upon payment by such person of the prescribed fee. 
(Code 1956, § 14-4) 
Sec. 16-25. - Same-Display on demand. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person fishing in the areas regulated by this chapter to fail or refuse, on demand of any enforcement officer, to show his fishing permit. 
(Code 1956, § 14-5) 
Sec. 16-26. - Use of spears, gigs, etc. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to kill or capture any fish in the waters of Oak Creek Reservoir, Lake Sweetwater or Lake Trammell by the use of spears, gigs, spear guns, or any like or similar device. 
(Ord. of 4-13-76) 
Sec. 16-27. - Commercial fishing prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to sell or buy, or to offer to sell or buy, or to take or possess for commercial purposes fish from the waters of Oak Creek Reservoir, Lake Sweetwater or Lake Trammell. 
(Ord. of 4-13-76) 
Sec. 16-28. - Use of trot lines. 
    All trot lines used in any city-owned lake or reservoir shall be ten (10) feet or more below the top surface when put outside of buoys or in open water. The name of the owner shall be on the trot line and it shall be dated every ninety (90) days. The maximum number of hooks on a trot line shall be fifty (50) hooks per line and they shall be a minimum of three (3) feet apart. 
(Ord. of 4-13-76) 
Secs. 16-29-16-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - RULES AND REGULATIONS FOR BOATING, WATER SKIING, AND OTHER WATER RELATED ACTIVITIES ON CITY-OWNED LAKES AND WATERCOURSES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 88-12, adopted Sept. 13, 1988, repealed former Art. III, §§ 16-41-16-46, relative to boating and skiing regulations, and enacted a new Art. III to read as herein set out. The provisions of former Art. III derived from an ordinance adopted April 13, 1976. 

Sec. 16-41. - Authority to promulgate rules and regulations. 
    The city manager shall have the authority to promulgate temporary rules and regulations necessary to operate the lakes and watercourses owned by the city in a safe and efficient manner for the health, safety and welfare of the general public. This authority may be exercised during construction periods, water conservation periods, flooding, or the threat of flooding, and other emergency conditions. 
(Ord. No. 88-12, 9-13-88) 
Sec. 16-42. - Permit required. 
    Any person or persons desiring to participate in water skiing activities or to operate a boat on Lake Sweetwater, Oak Creek Lake or Lake Trammell, shall secure from the city a recreation permit. Possession of a valid recreation permit shall entitle the bearer to participate in any and all water-related activities at the above-mentioned lakes. 
(Ord. No. 88-12, 9-13-88; Ord. No. 95-07, 6-6-95) 
Sec. 16-43. - Life preserver requirements for boats. 
    All boats shall, at all times, be equipped with one life preserver for each occupant. Life preservers shall be of an approved type, adequate to sustain afloat any occupant of the boat. 
(Ord. No. 88-12, 9-13-88) 
Sec. 16-44. - Boat capacity limit. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to cause, suffer, permit, or allow any boat to be occupied by more persons than the rated capacity. 
(Ord. No. 88-12, 9-13-88) 
Sec. 16-45. - Paddle requirement; muffler system. 
    All boats shall carry at least one paddle in good condition. All inboard motor boats shall be equipped with an approved baffle-type muffler system. No over-the-transom exhaust boats will be permitted to operate on the city-owned lakes. 
(Ord. No. 88-12, 9-13-88; Ord. No. 92-08, 7-7-92) 
Sec. 16-46. - Size, type of boats. 
    No boat or barge twenty-six (26) feet or longer, nor any houseboat of any size shall be permitted on any of the city-owned lakes. 
(Ord. No. 88-12, 9-13-88) 
Sec. 16-47. - Right-of-way rules for watercraft. 
    Right-of-way of boats, rafts and devices shall be as follows: 
(a)  Rowboats, rafts, and canoes shall have the right-of-way over all other craft; 
(b)  Sailboats shall have the right-of-way over all power boats; and 
(c)  Outboard power boats shall have the right-of-way over inboard power boats. 
(Ord. No. 88-12, 9-13-88) 
Sec. 16-48. - Reckless driving; driving while under the influence of intoxicants, etc. 
    Reckless driving, driving while under the influence of intoxicants and driving at speeds greater than is prudent for the conditions are strictly prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 88-12, 9-13-88) 
Sec. 16-49. - Wake restrictions. 
    All operators of power boats shall, upon approach to other boats, reduce speed and pass in such a manner as to prevent damage from wake. All operators of power boats shall be directly responsible for any damage, whatsoever, caused by the wake of their craft. 
(Ord. No. 88-12, 9-13-88) 
Sec. 16-50. - Lighting requirements for watercraft. 
    All boats, rafts, and other devices operating upon the waters of Lake Sweetwater, Oak Creek Lake, or Lake Trammell after sunset and before sunrise shall be equipped with a red light on the port side and a green light on the starboard side and a white light at each end of the craft. 
(Ord. No. 88-12, 9-13-88) 
Sec. 16-51. - Skiing at Lake Sweetwater and Oak Creek Lake. 
    All skiing at Lake Sweetwater and Oak Creek Lake shall be done on the main body of the lakes. Skiing in creeks and narrow waterways shall be strictly prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 88-12, 9-13-88) 
Sec. 16-52. - Speed boats, skiing and swimming prohibited at Lake Trammell. 
    Water skiing and swimming is expressly prohibited in or on the waters of Lake Trammell. All boats shall be operated at trolling speed only, with Lake Trammell being designated as a "no wake lake." 
(Ord. No. 88-12, 9-13-88; Ord. No. 92-08, 7-7-92) 
Sec. 16-53. - Boats not to operate in restricted areas; exceptions. 
    No person shall operate a boat within a water area which has been clearly marked by buoys or some other distinguishing device as a fishing, swimming or otherwise restricted area by the city, provided, that this restriction shall not apply in case of an emergency or to patrol or rescue craft. 
(Ord. No. 88-12, 9-13-88) 
Sec. 16-54. - Speed limit when entering or leaving a no skiing or no wake area. 
    All boats, when entering or leaving a no skiing or no wake area shall observe a five (5) mile per hour speed limit. 
(Ord. No. 88-12, 9-13-88) 
Sec. 16-55. - Removal of watercraft from lakes upon direction of lake patrolman. 
    A lake patrolman may require the removal of any boat, raft or device from the waters of Lake Sweetwater, Oak Creek Lake or Lake Trammell if: 
(a)  Said boat, raft, or device is in an unsafe operation condition; or 
(b)  Said boat, raft, or device is in violation of any of the applicable provisions of the Texas Water Safety Act or City of Sweetwater ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 88-12, 9-13-88) 
Chapter 17 - LICENSES AND BUSINESS REGULATIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- License fees, Art. X, § 10 et seq. 
Cross reference- License for sale of alcoholic beverages, § 5-16 et seq.; licensing of dogs and cats, § 6-42 et seq.; gas fitters licenses, § 7-32; licensing of electricians, § 9-121 et seq.; permit for employment as a food handler, § 12-16 et seq.; regulation of ambulance services, § 14-61 et seq.; permit requirements for drilling oil and gas, § 22-1 et seq.; authority of city to levy occupational taxes, § 27-3; hotel occupancy tax, § 27-21 et seq.; taxicab and bus franchises, § 28-31 et seq. 
State Law reference- Authority to license business, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 1175(23). 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 17-1. - Centralized fee schedule. 
(a)  The central fee schedule, appended hereto as Exhibit "A" and incorporated herein by reference as if fully copied and set forth at length, is ratified and confirmed as the central fee schedule for the assessment of fees and charges for licenses, permits and the setting of rates and services for the City of Sweetwater for the fiscal year 1991. 
(b)  The fee schedule shall be reviewed by the city commission annually and necessary revisions made prior to October first of each year hereafter. 
(Ord. No. 91-03, § 1, 4-9-91) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 91-03, § 1, adopted April 9, 1991, did not specifically amend the Code; therefore, inclusion as § 17-1 was at the discretion of the editor. The rate schedule shall be maintained in the office of the city secretary. 
Sec. 17-2-17-13. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PEDDLERS AND SOLICITORS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 88-15, adopted Dec. 13, 1988, amended Art. II in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Art. II, §§ 17-26-17-32, relative to permits for peddlers and solicitors, derived from Code 1956, §§ 20-1, 20-3-20-6, 20-8, 20-9 and § 1 of an ordinance adopted Sept. 25, 1973. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2018-15, adopted Nov. 13, 2018, has been treated as superseding the former provisions of div. 1, §§ 17-14, 17-15, and div. 2, §§ 17-26-17-32. Said ordinance enacted provisions designated as §§ 17-1-17-6, 17-8-17-20. At the discretion of the editor, said provisions have been redesignated as §§ 17-14-17-32, in order to avoid duplication and to retain the Code format. 

Sec. 17-14. - Purpose of article. 
    The purpose of this article is to protect against criminal activity, including fraud and burglary, minimize the unwelcome disturbance of citizens and the disruption of privacy and to otherwise preserve the public health, safety, and welfare by regulating, controlling, and licensing canvassers, solicitors and peddlers. 
(Ord. No. 2018-15, 11-13-18) 
Sec. 17-15. - City license officer. 
    For the purposes of this chapter, the city secretary shall act as the city license officer and as such shall administer the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2018-15, 11-13-18) 
Sec. 17-16. - Definitions. 
    The following words and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them by this section: 
    Business day means any calendar day except Saturday, Sunday or any city holiday. 
    Canvasser means any person who attempts to make personal contact with a resident at his/her residence without prior specific invitation or appointment from the resident, or in the public right-of-way for the primary purpose of (1) attempting to enlist support for or against a particular religion, philosophy, ideology, political party, issue, or candidate, even if incidental to such purpose the canvasser accepts the donation for money for or against such cause, or (2) distributing a handbill or flyer advertising a non-commercial event or service. 
    Chief of police means the chief of police of the City of Sweetwater or designee. 
    Official shall mean City of Sweetwater Peace Officers, City Secretary, or City Manager or designee who administers, implements, and enforces the provisions of this chapter. 
    Peddler means any person who goes upon the premises of any private residence in the city, not having been invited by the occupant thereof, or upon the public right-of-way, carrying or transporting goods, wares, merchandise or personal property of any nature and offering the same for sale. Peddler does not include a person who distributes handbills or flyers for a commercial purpose, advertising an event, activity, good, or service that is offered to a resident for purchase at different location or time. 
    Peddle and any form of the word means all activities ordinarily performed by a peddler. 
    Solicitation, soliciting, solicited , or any form of the word solicit means any activities ordinarily performed by a solicitor. 
    Solicitor means any person who goes upon the premises of any private residence in the city, not having been invited by the occupant thereof, or upon the public right-of-way for the purpose of taking or attempting to take orders for the sale of goods, merchandise, wares, or other personal property of any nature for future delivery, or for services to be performed in the future. This definition includes any person who, without invitation, goes upon private property, or in the public right-of-way to request contribution of funds or anything of value, or sell goods or services for educational, political, charitable, religious, or other non-commercial purposes. 
(Ord. No. 2018-15, 11-13-18) 
Sec. 17-17. - Hours of canvassing, solicitation and peddling at private residences. 
    It shall be unlawful for persons, licensed or unlicensed, to canvass, solicit or peddle at private residences between the hours of 7:00 p.m. and 9:00 a.m. unless otherwise posted by the private property owner or by someone with apparent authority to act for the owner. This provision does not apply where the canvasser, solicitor or peddler is on the property by express, prior invitation of the owner of the property or a person residing on the premises. 
(Ord. No. 2018-15, 11-13-18) 
Sec. 17-18. - Entry upon premises unlawful. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to canvass, solicit, or peddle upon any private property in the city where the owner, occupant, or person legally in charge of the premises has posted at the entry to the premises, or at the entry to the principal building on the premises, a sign bearing the words "No Peddlers," "No Solicitors," or words of similar import. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to canvass, solicit, or peddle at any entrance to a residence other than the front door. 
(Ord. No. 2018-15, 11-13-18) 
Sec. 17-19. - Penalty for violation. 
    Any person, firm, partnership, corporation, association, agent or employee thereof who violates any of the provisions of this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be fined in an amount not less than seventy-five dollars ($75.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense. Each and every hour that such violation shall continue shall be deemed to constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 2018-15, 11-13-18) 
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT 

Sec. 17-20. - Permit requirements and exemptions. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in peddling or solicitation activities within the city without first obtaining a permit issued by the city license officer; provided the following are exempted from the provisions of this section. 
(1)  Any solicitation made upon premises owned or occupied by an organization upon whose behalf the solicitation is made; 
(2)  Any solicitation in the form of a collection at a regular meeting, assembly, or service of a charitable person; 
(3)  A canvasser as defined by the chapter; 
(4)  A solicitor or peddler already licensed by the state to engage in the activity. 
(Ord. No. 2018-15, 11-13-18) 
Sec. 17-21. - Exhibition of permit required. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any solicitor or peddler to fail to conspicuously display on or about their person the permit issued by the city. 
(b)  "Conspicuously displayed" shall mean displayed to the front and visible to whomever the permit holder is conversing at all times they are engaged in a permitted activity. 
(Ord. No. 2018-15, 11-13-18) 
Sec. 17-22. - Permits for minor peddlers or solicitors. 
(a)  No person under the age of eighteen (18) shall be permitted to engage in peddling or soliciting except as provided in this section. 
(b)  A permit shall be obtained by a sponsoring person, company, or organization for the conduct of any peddling or solicitation activities involving in whole or in part a sales force of one (1) or more persons under the age of eighteen (18) years of age. 
(c)  The sponsor shall be responsible for supervising and controlling all persons peddling under the sponsor's permit. 
(d)  The sponsor shall provide to each individual in its sales force a badge or other easily readable form of identification that identifies the name of the sponsor and the name of the individual. The sponsor shall require all individuals in their sales force to wear the identification so that it is clearly visible at all times while peddling or soliciting. 
(Ord. No. 2018-15, 11-13-18) 
Sec. 17-23. - Application. 
    Applicants for permits under this chapter must file with the city license officer an application in writing on a form obtained from the license officer and provide the following: 
(1)  A valid Texas Driver's License or state issued photo identification. 
(2)  The number of the limited sales tax permit issued to the business by the state comptroller's office, if applicable. 
(3)  A brief description of the activity or business to be conducted. 
(4)  The appropriate fee. 
(5)  Proof of status necessary to receive an exception under section 17-8 or 17-13 of this chapter. 
    Any application made pursuant to the provisions of this chapter may be presented to the Better Business Bureau of Sweetwater or the Sweetwater Police Department for investigation. 
(Ord. No. 2018-15, 11-13-18) 
Sec. 17-24. - Required fee. 
    The fees and charges for permits furnished by the city shall be determined from time to time and placed on file in the office of the city license officer. No application for a permit will be processed until the required fees are tendered to the city license officer. Permit fees are nonrefundable and shall not be prorated. 
(Ord. No. 2018-15, 11-13-18) 
Sec. 17-25. - Exceptions to fee. 
    The payment of the permit fee shall not be held to be applicable to the following organizations, however, all solicitors and peddlers are required to comply with all other applicable provisions of this chapter unless otherwise exempted: 
(1)  Any local church or other religious group, or to ministers or agents thereof soliciting funds for the support of such religious group; 
(2)  Any established society, association or corporation that is organized and operated exclusively for educational, philanthropic, benevolent, fraternal or charitable purposes, not operated for pecuniary profit, where no part of the net earnings inures to the benefit of any person, private shareholder, or individual, where the solicitation of such organization is: 
a.  Conducted among the members thereof by other members or officers thereof, voluntarily and without remuneration for such solicitation; or 
b.  In the form of collections or contributions at the regular exercises or services of any society, lodge, benevolent order or fraternity or similar organization, or any branch thereof. 
(3)  Vendors of farm produce, poultry, stock or agricultural products in their natural state if raised on land owned or leased by the vendor, or such products may be sold by any member of the owner's or lessee's household. 
(4)  Sales of goods, wares, and merchandise donated by the owners thereof, the proceeds of which are to be used and applied to some charitable, religious or philanthropic purposes. 
(5)  Sales of goods, wares, and merchandise by any bonafide charitable, religious or philanthropic organization. 
(Ord. No. 2018-15, 11-13-18) 
Sec. 17-26. - Issuance. 
    Upon completion and presentation of the application, the city license officer shall issue a permit to the applicant within five (5) business days unless grounds for denial exist under section 17-30. 
(Ord. No. 2018-15, 11-13-18) 
Sec. 17-27. - Contents. 
(a)  Each permit issued under this article shall show the name of the permitted individual, business address, a description of the type of solicitation, product, or activity, the date of issuance, and the expiration date of such permit. 
(b)  The permit shall be numbered and printed in black; except, that the following shall be printed prominently thereon in red: "The issuance of this license is not an endorsement by the City of Sweetwater, or any of its officers or employees, and expires thirty (30) days from the date of execution." 
(Ord. No. 2018-15, 11-13-18) 
Sec. 17-28. - Expiration. 
    All permits issued under the provisions of this article shall expire thirty (30) days from the date of issuance. 
(Ord. No. 2018-15, 11-13-18) 
Sec. 17-29. - Transfer 
    No permit issued under the provision of this article shall be transferred or assigned. 
(Ord. No. 2018-15, 11-13-18) 
Sec. 17-30. - Denial. 
    An application for permit may be denied to a person under this article for the following reasons: 
(1)  Because of a person's conviction of a felony or misdemeanor if the crime directly relates to the conduct of a peddler's business or results from an assault against person. 
(2)  An investigation reveals that the applicant falsified information on the application. 
(3)  The applicant is a registered sex offender. 
(4)  The applicant has had a permit revoked for any reason within the past three (3) years. 
(Ord. No. 2018-15, 11-13-18) 
Sec. 17-31. - Revocation. 
(a)  Permits issued under the provision of this article may be revoked for any of the following causes by any official of the City of Sweetwater: 
(1)  Fraud, misrepresentation or false statement contained in the application for permit. 
(2)  Fraud, misrepresentation or false statement made in the course of carrying on his business. 
(3)  Any violation of this chapter. 
(4)  Conviction of a misdemeanor or any felony if the crime directly relates to the conduct of the business. 
(5)  Conducting the business of peddling in an unlawful manner or in such a manner as to constitute a breach of the peace or to constitute a menace to the health, safety, and general welfare of the public. 
(b)  Notice of revocation of a permit shall be given verbally or in writing, and specify the grounds of the revocation. 
(c)  When the solicitor receives notice that their permit has been revoked, they shall immediately surrender their permit to the revoking official. 
(Ord. No. 2018-15, 11-13-18) 
Sec. 17-32. - Appeals. 
(a)  An appeal from any act of denial or revocation of any permit shall be filed with the chief of police or designee within five (5) business days from the date of denial or revocation. 
(b)  Such appeal shall be taken by filing with the chief of police or designee a written statement setting forth fully the grounds for the appeal. 
(c)  The chief of police shall issue a decision on the denial or revocation in writing within five (5) business days of receipt of the appeal. 
(d)  The revocation or denial is not stayed pending the chief of police's decision. 
(e)  The decision and order of the chief of police on such appeal shall be final and conclusive. 
(Ord. No. 2018-15, 11-13-18) 
Sec. 17-33. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - PAWN SHOPS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2013-17, adopted July 23, 2013, amended the Code by adding new provisions designated as Art. VI, § 17-34; however, said provisions have been redesignated as Div. 3, § 17-34, at the editor's discretion, for purposes of maintaining Code format, and to avoid duplication. 

Sec. 17-34. - Hold period for personal property purchased by pawn shops. 
    Each item of personal property purchased from the general public by any local pawn shop under the regulation of the Texas Pawn Shop Act and the consumer credit commissioner must be held at the licensed pawn shop location for a period from the purchase date before being modified, changed, sold, or disposed of in any manner for at least eleven (11) days. 
    The City of Sweetwater Police Department shall have the authority to extend the hold period on any particular personal property if the interest of justice so requires, from eleven (11) days, to a period not exceeding twenty (20) days, by providing written notice to the local pawn shop, (under the regulation of the consumer credit commissioner,) in possession of the personal property on or before the eleventh day of the hold period. 
(Ord. No. 2013-17, 7-23-2013) 
Secs. 17-35-17-45. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - JUNK AND SECONDHAND DEALERS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference- Junked and abandoned vehicles, § 19-251 et seq. 

Sec. 17-46. - Definitions. 
    Unless it appears from the context that a different meaning is intended, the words defined in this chapter shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section: 
    Junk shall mean and include those articles which may be reasonably classified as junk in the usual trade meaning of that term, to wit: The purchase, storage or sale of scrap iron, tin, brass, copper, lead, zinc, tinfoil, aluminum, metal alloys; unserviceable items such as wrecked, worn-out or nonoperative automobiles, trucks, trailers or plumbing, electrical or gas fixtures or appliances purchased, stored or handled for the purpose of dismantling and selling usable parts therefrom or selling the remainder thereof; and other commodities not ordinarily usable in their existing condition such as scrap paper, cloth, rags, rubber, boxes or cartons. 
    Junk dealer shall mean any person engaged in collecting, handling or selling any of the articles defined as junk, and all persons engaged in the buying and selling of secondhand goods, wares and merchandise. 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 17-47. - Registration required. 
    No junk dealer or dealer in secondhand merchandise shall transact or engage in such business within the corporate limits of the city unless he shall first register his intention of engaging in such business with the city secretary. 
(Code 1956, § 13-2) 
Sec. 17-48. - Records to be kept by city. 
    A permanent record of each registration under the preceding section showing the name, trade name, business address, residence and type of proposed business shall be maintained by the city secretary. 
(Code 1956, § 13-3) 
Sec. 17-49. - Records to be kept by dealers. 
    Each junk dealer or dealer in secondhand material or other person who shall purchase any kind of junk or secondhand material shall keep in a well-bound book an accurate daily record of each article purchased, the date purchased and the amount paid by the dealer for each of such articles, and also an accurate description of the person selling or pawning the article, giving the name, color, sex, age and residence. If the dealer or pawnbroker is not personally acquainted with the person offering such article for sale, he shall require such person to be identified. The dealer or pawnbroker shall also make an entry in the book of the disposition made by him of the article and, if sold, he shall state to whom sold and the price paid therefor. All of such entries shall be made at the time of the purchase or sale. The book shall be securely kept by the dealer or pawnbroker and any person who fails or refuses to comply with this section shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1956, § 13-4) 
Sec. 17-50. - Accessibility of records to police. 
    The book or record specified in the preceding section shall be accessible at all times to the city police or any other law enforcement officer, and all such officers shall have the right at all times to examine such record when searching or looking for lost or stolen articles, or in determining whether or not the provisions of this chapter are being faithfully kept and observed. Any person who fails to permit any police or law enforcement officer to inspect the book or record shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1956, § 13-5) 
Sec. 17-51. - Restrictions as to purchases made within forty-eight hours. 
    No junk or secondhand dealer shall sell or remove from his place of business, within forty-eight (48) hours of purchase or receipt, any goods purchased or received by him. The articles purchased or received shall be kept separate and apart from all other articles so that the same may be fully identified, for a full forty-eight (48) hours after received; provided, that this provision shall not apply to scrap iron, old tin, rags and bones. 
(Code 1956, § 13-6) 
Sec. 17-52. - Purchases from intoxicated persons or minors. 
    No person registered under this chapter shall receive or purchase any goods, wares or merchandise from any intoxicated person or from any person under the age of eighteen (18) years, except upon the written consent of the parent or guardian of such minor, and, in that event, such writing shall be preserved by the purchaser for a period of not less than six (6) months thereafter for public inspection. When any such purchase is made from any minor with such consent, a notation of the same shall be made on the book or register required to be kept by the registrant. 
(Code 1956, § 13-7) 
Sec. 17-53. - Screening requirement for junkyards. 
    All junk and automotive wrecking and salvage yards within the city or its extraterritorial jurisdiction shall, except as to the point of entry and exit into and out of such junkyard or any railway switch or spur, be screened by natural objects, plantings, fences or other appropriate means, so that the screen is at least six (6) feet in height alongside that portion of the junkyard or automotive wrecking and salvage yard that faces a public road or family residence. Fences must be painted a natural earthtone color and may not have any signs appear on their surface other than signage indicating the business name. 
(Ord. No. 95-15, 11-14-95) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 95-15, adopted Nov. 14, 1995, deleted §§ 17-53 and 17-54 in their entirety. Formerly, §§ 17-53 and 17-54 pertained to fences required for junk yards and copy of chapter to be posted and derived from §§ 13-9 and 13-10 of the 1956 Code. 
Annotation- Texas H.B. 452, Sec. 3(a) requires earthtone color on solid barrier eight-foot fences (in areas of unspecified population density). H.B. 452 was passed by the House on May 16, 1991, and by the Senate on May 21, 1991. 
Sec. 17-54. - Location of junkyards. 
    A junkyard or an automotive wrecking and salvage yard, other than a junkyard or automotive wrecking and salvage yard used exclusively for farm equipment, may not be located within fifty (50) feet of the right-of-way of a public street or state highway or a residence. 
    Materials associated with a junkyard or an automotive wrecking and salvage yard, other than a junkyard or automotive wrecking and salvage yard used exclusively for farm equipment, may not be allowed to accumulate or be stacked to a height above six (6) inches below the top of such screen. 
(Ord. No. 95-15, 11-14-95) 
Note- See the editor's note following § 17-53. 
Annotation- Texas H.B. 452, Sec. 3A(b) requires contents of a junkyard to be stacked no higher than eight feet from ground level. H.B. 452 was passed by the House on May 16, 1991, and by the Senate on May 21, 1991. 
Sec. 17-55. - Penalty. 
    If any person fails or refuses to comply with the provisions of this article, such failure or refusal shall constitute a class C misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be punishable by a fine not to exceed two hundred dollars ($200.00) per day, per violation, for each day the violation(s) exist. 
(Ord. No. 95-15, 11-14-95) 
Sec. 17-56. - Application of this article. 
    This article applies to a junkyard or an automotive wrecking and salvage yard other than a junkyard or salvage yard used exclusively for farm equipment. 
(Ord. No. 95-15, 11-14-95) 
Sec. 17-57. - Copy of chapter to be posted. 
    Every junk dealer and dealer in secondhand material within the city and its extraterritorial jurisdiction shall keep a copy of this chapter, sections 17-53 through 17-56 of this Code excepted, posted in a conspicuous place at his/her place of business. 
(Ord. No. 95-15, 11-14-95) 
Secs. 17-58-17-65. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - PUBLIC AMUSEMENTS[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate location and control of places of public amusement, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 1175(22). 

Sec. 17-66. - Permit required. 
    Every person desiring to operate or exhibit any circus, wild west show, dramatic or theatrical show, medicine show, vaudeville show, minstrel show, or any carnival or any merry-go-round, ferris wheel, whip, sky ride, hobby horse, flying-jenny, bat-a-ball, tilt-a-whirl, pony ride, kiddy train or other riding or skill device of such character, with or without name shall first obtain a permit from the city manager. 
Sec. 17-67. - Term of permit. 
    The term of the permit required by this article shall in no case be for a longer period of time than: 
(1)  One (1) day and one (1) night in any one (1) year in the case of a circus or wild west show; 
(2)  Four (4) weeks in any one (1) year in the case of a dramatic or theatrical show; 
(3)  One (1) week in any one (1) year in the case of a medicine show, vaudeville show, minstrel show, moving picture show; 
(4)  One (1) week in any one (1) year, unless sponsored for compensation by one (1) or more civic, charitable or other local organizations in which event for a period of time no longer than two (2) weeks in any one (1) year, in the case of a carnival, merry-go-round, ferris wheel, whip, sky ride, hobby horse, flying-jenny, bat-a-ball, tilt-a-whirl, pony ride, kiddy train or other riding or skill device of such character. 
Sec. 17-68. - Fee. 
    A permit shall not be issued pursuant to the provisions of this article until the applicant pays to the city such fee as is established by the city commission from time to time. 
Sec. 17-69. - Restrictions on issuance. 
    No permit shall be issued pursuant to the provisions of this article to any amusement which has attached thereto a concession, and operated in connection therewith, any game of chance. 
Sec. 17-70. - Revocation. 
    Upon complaint filed with the city commission by any person, or upon its own notice, the city commission may revoke or suspend the permit of any person holding a permit under this article, for good cause shown, after notice and hearing. Good cause shall include: 
(a)  Any material misrepresentation in the application for a permit or any fraud in its procurement. 
(b)  Any cause which would have prevented the granting of the permit in the first place. 
(c)  Misconduct of the permittee such as the violation of any of the requirements of this article, the commission of any unlawful act prohibited by this article, or any other law involving honesty, good faith, integrity, responsibility or moral turpitude. 
(d)  The violation of any of the conditions of the permit issued under this article. 
ARTICLE V. - ADULT ENTERTAINMENT ENTERPRISES AND ESTABLISHMENTS 

Sec. 17-71. - Purpose and intent. 
    It is the purpose and intent of this article to provide for the orderly regulation of adult entertainment enterprises and establishments, as defined in this article, in the interests of public health, safety and welfare, and to prevent solicitation for acts of prostitution in adult entertainment enterprises and establishments by providing certain minimum standards and regulations for adult entertainment enterprises and establishments, and by providing standards for operators and employees of adult entertainment enterprises and establishments. 
(Ord. No. 89-19, 8-8-89) 
Sec. 17-72. - Definitions. 
(a)  Generally. The following terms, words, phrases, whenever used in this article, shall be construed as defined in this section unless in context it appears that a different meaning is intended: 
    Words used in the present tense include the future; words in the singular number include the plural number, and words used in the plural number include the singular number. 
    The word building includes the word structure. 
    "Adult entertainment enterprise" includes adult entertainment establishment. 
    "Adult entertainment establishment" includes adult entertainment enterprise. 
    The word "shall" is mandatory and not directory. 
    A variance from the definitions included in this section may permit, within a district, activities which would otherwise not be permitted within that district. Such a variance, therefore, is not within the powers and duties of the board of adjustments. 
(b)  Terms defined. 
    Accessory building: A building for the use subordinate to the use of the principal building which subordinate use is, by custom of the neighborhood, incidental to the use of the principal building. An accessory building may never be used for living quarters. 
    Accessory building, attached: For the purpose of this article, an accessory building may only be considered as detached. If a building is structurally part of and shares a common wall and roof with the principal building, it is subject to the same codes and ordinances which apply to principal structures. 
    Accessory building, detached: A building, as defined herein this section, which is wholly separate and independent of the principal building, is not structurally part and sharing a common wall and roof with the principal building, or is corrected by any means other than common wall and roof. 
    Accessory use: Is clearly incidental to, customary to, and associated with a permitted right-of-use (conforming use); is operated and maintained under the same ownership and on the zoning lot as the right-of-use (except for accessory off-street parking facilities); and, does not include structures or structural feature which are inconsistent with the right-of-use. 
    Adult bookstore/film store: An establishment or commercial enterprise having ten (10) percent or more of its stock in trade; videos, tapes, cassettes, photographs, books, magazines and other periodicals which are distinguished by a predominant emphasis on matter(s) depicting, describing, or relating to "specified sexual activities" or "specified anatomical areas" as defined below. 
    Adult cabaret: An establishment whose portion of business is the offering to customers of live entertainment which is intended to provide sexual stimulation or sexual gratification to such customers, including but not limited to dancing, posing, modeling, acting, and which is distinguished by or characterized by a predominant emphasis on matter depicting, describing, or relating to "specified sexual activities" or "specified anatomical areas." 
    Adult drive-in theatre: A drive-in theatre used for presenting motion picture films, video cassettes, cable television, or any other such visual media, distinguished or characterized by a predominant emphasis on matter depicting, describing or relating to "specified sexual activities" or "specified anatomical areas." 
    Adult encounter parlor: An establishment whose business consists of premises where customers either congregate, associate, or consort with employees who engage in "specified sexual activities" with or in the presence of such customers, or who display "specified anatomical areas" in the presence of such customers, with the intent of providing sexual stimulation or sexual gratification to such customers. 
    Adult entertainment enterprise: Any business activity whether in public, semi-public or private premises, which offers the opportunity to feel, handle, touch, paint, be in the presence of, be entertained by the unclothed body or the unclothed portion of the body of another person, or to observe, view or photograph any such activity. Except as specifically provided herein, nothing in this section is intended to regulate: 
(1)  Any business operated by or employing psychologists, physical therapists, athletic trainers, licensed masseuse, cosmetologists, or barbers, licensed by the State of Texas, performing functions authorized under the licenses held. 
(2)  Any business operated by or employing physicians, osteopaths, chiropractors or nurses, licensed by the State of Texas, engaged in practicing the healing arts. 
(3)  Any retail establishment whose major business is the offering of wearing apparel for sale to customers. 
(4)  Adult entertainment enterprises further-more include, but are not limited to, the following: Any establishment or place of business where an individual, firm, association, partnership, corporation, joint venture or combination of individuals engages in, conducts, operates, carries on or permits to be engaged in, conducted, operated or carried on any adult entertainment enterprise regardless of whether any other activity is also conducted on the premises. 
    Adult lounge: An "adult cabaret" as defined above which is permitted or licensed pursuant to the Alcoholic Beverage Code where alcoholic beverages may be served or sold. 
    Adult modeling studio: An establishment whose portion of business is the providing to customers, figure models who are so provided with the intent of providing sexual stimulation or sexual gratification to such customers and who engage in "specified sexual activities" or display "specified anatomical areas" while being observed, painted, painted upon, sketched, drawn, sculptured, photographed, or otherwise depicted by such customers. 
    Adult retail store: This is a retail establishment in which: 
(1)  Ten (10) percent or more of the "stock in trade" consists of items, products or equipment distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on "specified sexual activities" or "specified anatomical areas;" or 
(2)  Any person is excluded by virtue of age from all or part of this premises generally held open to the public where products or equipment distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on "specified sexual activities" or "specified anatomical areas." 
    Customers: 
(1)  Any person who is allowed to enter an establishment in return for the payment of an admission fee or any form of consideration or gratuity; or 
(2)  Any person who enters an establishment for the purpose of purchasing or renting a commodity or service therein. 
    Employee: Every owner, partner, manager, supervisor, or worker, whether paid or not, who renders personal services of any nature in the conduct of an adult entertainment enterprise. It includes any person who renders any service whatsoever to the customers of an establishment regulated by this section or who works in or about such an establishment and who receives compensation or consideration for such service or work from the operator or owner of such establishment or from the customers therein. 
    Entertainment: Any act or performance such as a play, skit, reading, revue, pantomime, scene, song, dance, musical rendition or striptease, whether performed by employees or customers. The term "entertainment" shall also mean bartenders, waiters, waitresses, or other employees exposing "specified anatomical areas" or engaging in "specified sexual activities" in the presence of customers. 
    Movie arcade: 
(1)  Any business wherein is operated a film or videotape viewing device. 
(2)  A film or videotapes viewing device or booth subject to these provisions is defined as: An establishment or commercial enterprise which has an enclosed building with a capacity of more than five (5) persons and is used for presenting material distinguished or characterized by a predominant emphasis on matter depicting, describing or relating to "specified sexual activities" or "specified anatomical areas" for observation by patrons. 
    Specified anatomical areas: 
(1)  Less than completely and opaquely covered: 
a.  Human genitals, pubic region, 
b.  Buttock, 
c.  Female breast below a point immediately above the top of the areola; and 
(2)  Human genitals in a discernibly erect state, even if completely and opaquely covered. 
    Specified sexual activities: 
(1)  Human genitals in a state of sexual stimulation or arousal; or 
(2)  Acts of human masturbation, sexual intercourse, sodomy, acts of bestiality; 
(3)  Fondling or other erotic touching of human genitals, pubic region, buttock or female breast. 
    Stock in trade: The total volume or number of items, products or equipment available for purchase, rental, viewing or use by patrons of the establishment, excluding material located in any storeroom or other portion of the premises not regularly open to patrons. 
    Unclothed portion of the body: A state of dress of such a manner that the nipple and areola are not firmly covered by a fully opaque material, or the lower part of the torso, consisting of the private parts or anal cleft or cleavage of the buttocks, is not covered by a fully opaque material. 
(Ord. No. 89-19, 8-8-89) 
Sec. 17-73. - Exemptions. 
    The following are specifically excluded from the meaning of the term "adult entertainment" and "adult entertainment enterprise" and are exempt from the application of all provisions of this article. 
(a)  Physicians, surgeons, chiropractors, osteopaths or physical therapists who are duly licensed to practice their respective professions in the State of Texas; 
(b)  Nurses registered under the laws of the State of Texas; 
(c)  Trainers of any amateur, semi-professional or professional athlete or athletic team; 
(d)  Barbers or cosmetologists who are duly licensed under the laws of the State of Texas; 
(e)  Any activity conducted or sponsored by any school district or other public agency; 
(f)  Any activity conducted by a person pursuant to any license issued by the State of Texas or any agency thereof or political subdivision which licenses, prescribes standards for and supervises such activity or profession; 
(g)  Portions of performances on theater, concert hall, music hall or auditorium stages wherein such displays are an integral part of a dramatic or comedic presentation; 
(h)  Private schools providing a course of instruction in photography, or photography studios which do not provide for consideration photography equipment, models and a studio; 
(i)  Modeling agencies, schools or services, except those which provide live modeling services for consideration in which a customer may obtain an exclusive modeling exhibition at which he or she is the only observer. 
(Ord. No. 89-19, 8-8-89) 
Sec. 17-74. - Adult entertainment activities locations. 
    Adult entertainment enterprises to be included in the "M" First Manufacturing District. 
(1)  All structures housing adult entertainment enterprises (as defined in this chapter and in Appendix A, Zoning Ordinance, Section 15 definitions) shall be located as follows: 
a.  At least six hundred (600) feet from any dwelling zoned lot or any lot used for school, church, park, or hospital purposes; 
b.  At least six hundred (600) feet north of Broadway/Highway 80 and at least six hundred (600) feet south of Broadway/Highway 80; 
c.  At least one thousand (1,000) feet from another structure housing an adult entertainment enterprise; and 
d.  At least two thousand (2,000) feet from any lot for school purposes. 
(2)  Said measurements are to be in a straight line in all directions from the structure housing the adult entertainment enterprise to the nearest property line on any lot in any dwelling zoned district, or any lot used for church, school, or hospital purposes, or any park, Broadway/Highway 80, and any structure housing an adult entertainment enterprise. 
(3)  The measurements for a structure shall be taken from the farthest point that a structure extends in any direction, including overhanging roofs and all other projections or portions of said structure. 
(4)  Should said adult entertainment enterprise be located in conjunction with other buildings in a manner where said adult entertainment enterprise is clearly separated from other portions of the structure, (for example, an adult bookstore in a shopping center) the adult entertainment enterprise structure's measurements shall be taken from the boundaries of the space in which the adult entertainment enterprise is housed or confined (not the entire shopping center, motel, or structure). 
(5)  Should said adult entertainment enterprise be located in conjunction with other buildings in a manner where said adult entertainment enterprise is situated above or below the ground level of a multi-story structure and is clearly separate from other activities within the structure (for example, an adult bookstore on an upper level of an office tower or hotel), the adult entertainment enterprise measurements shall be taken from the nearest entry to that portion of the structure housing the adult entertainment enterprise, thence to the nearest point of egress (elevator or stairs), thence to the nearest point on any lot in a dwelling district, or any lot or tract used for church, school, hospital or park purposes, Broadway/Highway 80 and any structure housing an adult entertainment enterprise. 
(Ord. No. 89-19, 8-8-89) 
Sec. 17-75. - Premises used; access. 
(1)  No premises used as an adult entertainment establishment or used for an adult entertainment enterprise shall be used as living quarters or as a residence in any capacity, temporarily or permanently. 
(2)  No adult entertainment establishment or enterprise shall use an entrance or exit that also provides a direct passageway to any other type of business, residence or living quarters. 
(3)  No adult entertainment establishment or enterprise shall during business hours, lock the doors to the exits or entrances of such establishment or place of enterprise, or in any way obstruct so as to prevent ingress or egress of persons through such passageways; provided, however, that such doors may be closed. 
(4)  The permittee or individual designated under section 17-77 shall remain upon the premises at all times said establishment or enterprise is open. 
(5)  The permittee and the person designated under section 17-77 by the permittee to manage, direct and control the establishment or enterprise, shall at all times be legally responsible for the conduct in the establishment or enterprise of each employee. 
(Ord. No. 89-19, 8-8-89) 
Sec. 17-76. - Permit/registration required. 
(1)  It shall be unlawful for any person, association, partnership, firm or corporation to open or operate or be employed by an adult entertainment establishment or enterprise, or to conduct business as such, or to manage an adult entertainment establishment or enterprise, without first obtaining and maintaining in effect an adult entertainment establishment or enterprise permit or registration as provided for in this article, and paying the appropriate permit or registration fees. 
(2)  The provisions of this article, except insofar as amended by section 17-81 shall apply to existing adult entertainment establishments and enterprises. 
(3)  Any person, association, partnership, firm or corporation operating or doing business as an adult entertainment establishment or enterprise permitted or registered under this article shall include and prominently display their permit or registration number on all printed or written advertising used by said establishment or enterprise. 
(Ord. No. 89-19, 8-8-89) 
Sec. 17-77. - Application. 
(1)  Applications for an adult entertainment enterprise shall be applied for and obtained from the building official of the city and any permit or license issued under the terms of this article shall be subject to revocation and cancellation as hereinafter provided. 
(2)  Each applicant for an adult entertainment enterprise must submit a site plan setting out the dimensions and locations for such adult entertainment enterprise and shall sign a certified and notarized application for such adult entertainment enterprise to be attached to the site plan and shall state: 
(a)  The location by street and number of the premises of such adult entertainment enterprise; 
(b)  The name, date of birth and address of the applicant; 
(c)  If the premises are leased, the name of the lessor and the lessee; 
(d)  If the applicant is an individual: 
1.  That he is a resident of the state and length of his residence in the city; 
2.  The location by street and number of applicant's residence; 
3.  If the applicant, or the spouse of such applicant, has at any time during the three (3) years next preceding the filing of such application been finally convicted of a felony or any of the offenses listed in section 17-79 of this chapter; 
4.  The previous occupation or employment of the applicant and the spouse of such applicant for a period of five (5) years next preceding the filing of such application. 
(e)  If the application is by a firm, association or partnership, all of the information required in subsection (2)(d) of this section regarding individual applicants shall be given as to each member of the firm association or partnership; 
(f)  If the application is made in behalf of a corporation, then all of the information required in subsection (2)(d) of this section regarding individual applicants shall be given as to the manager, officer, trustee, receiver or person who is primarily responsible for the management of the premises and in addition shall state when and where the corporation has been chartered and if requested by the building official shall give the name of each and every stockholder of such corporation; 
(g)  That the proposed adult entertainment enterprise complies with the requirements set forth herein above; 
(h)  Such other additional information that the city commission may from time to time deem proper and necessary as shall be determined by resolution of the city commission. 
(3)  It shall be the duty of the applicant to prepare the site plan and to ensure compliance with the distance requirements. The information given in such application required in this section is for the purpose of determining whether or not a permit or license shall be granted, and any misrepresentation of any fact or statement made in such application shall be cause for revocation and cancellation in addition to other grounds for revocation and cancellation as hereinafter provided. 
(Ord. No. 89-19, 8-8-89) 
Sec. 17-78. - Investigations. 
(1)  Upon the filing of an application for an adult entertainment enterprise permit, the building official shall promptly investigate the premises for which such application is made to determine that such premises meet the requirements of the ordinances of the city concerning construction, plumbing, electricity, fire, sanitation and zoning. 
(2)  Upon the filing of an application for an adult entertainment enterprise, the building official shall promptly notify the chief of police who shall investigate the applicant and the spouse of such applicant to determine that either of them have not been convicted of any of the offenses listed in paragraph (2) of section 17-79 of this article, and the chief of police shall notify the building official of his findings and shall note thereon his recommendation for approval or disapproval. 
(Ord. No. 89-19, 8-8-89) 
Sec. 17-79. - Issuance or denial of permits. 
Issuance  or denial is governed by the following provisions. 
(1)  The building official, after making his on-premises investigation and receiving the report of the chief of police, shall determine whether or not the applicant and premises of the proposed adult entertainment enterprise complies with the requirements of this article and then shall approve or disapprove the application. 
(2)  The building official of the city shall refuse any original application or renewal for an adult entertainment enterprise permit unless the applicant shall supply a certificate evidencing payment of all taxes owed to the city or any taxing authority whose taxes are levied, assessed and collected by the city or if he finds that there is any delinquent indebtedness due the city against the premises, or if he finds that the applicant or the spouse of any applicant has at any time during the three (3) years next preceding the filing of such application been convicted of a felony or of any of the following offenses: 
(a)  Prostitution; 
(b)  A crime involving moral turpitude; 
(c)  Bookmaking; 
(d)  Gambling (gaming); 
(e)  Any offense involving narcotics or any other dangerous drugs; 
(f)  Violations of V.T.C.A., Alcoholic Beverage Code resulting in the cancellation of a license or permit or a fine of five hundred dollars ($500.00) or more; 
(g)  More than three (3) violations of V.T.C.A., Alcoholic Beverage Code relating to minors; 
(h)  Bootlegging; 
(i)  Violations of penal laws involving firearms or other deadly weapons. 
(3)  The building official shall refuse an original application or renewal of an adult entertainment enterprise permit if he finds that three (3) years have not elapsed since the termination of any sentence, parole or probation by the applicant or spouse of such applicant as the result of a felony prosecution or prosecution for any offense named or described above. 
(Ord. No. 89-19, 8-8-89) 
Sec. 17-80. - Denial by building official; appeal procedure. 
(1)  If the building official refuses to approve any application for license or permit hereunder, the action of the building official in so refusing shall become final unless the applicant shall within ten (10) days after the refusal to grant such license or permit file a written appeal addressed to the city commission upon the question as to whether or not his application should be granted. 
(2)  The application shall be referred to the city commission by the city secretary. The city commission shall set a date for a hearing not more than thirty (30) days from the date the written request was filed with the city secretary. 
(3)  At the hearing the applicant shall be required to appear before the city commission, and a full hearing on the application shall be had. The city commission shall, at such hearing, determine whether the application for the license or permit shall be granted or refused. The action of the city commission thereon shall be final and conclusive. 
(Ord. No. 89-19, 8-8-89) 
Sec. 17-81. - Fees; duration of licenses and permits; refunds; assignments; changed locations; nonconforming use. 
(1)  Fees. The fees required by this article shall be established from time to time by the city commission. 
(2)  Term. All licenses or permits issued under this division shall terminate one (1) year from the date of issuance. 
(3)  Refunds. No refunds of any license or permit fee paid hereunder shall be made by the city for any cause whatsoever. 
(4)  Nonassignable. Licenses or permits issued hereunder shall be deemed personal to the licensee or permittee, and shall not be assignable. 
(5)  Transfers of location. A permit or license holder shall conduct business only at the address shown on the permit or license. All permits or licenses issued under this article shall be nontransferable as to permittee, licensee or as to location. Permits or licenses shall not be transferred from one location to another with out applying for a new permit. 
(6)  Permit or license a privilege; restrictions. Any permit or license issued under the terms of this article shall be purely a personal privilege revocable in the manner and for the causes herein provided, subject to appeal as herein provided, and shall not constitute property, nor shall it be subject to execution nor shall it descend by the laws of the testate or intestate, devolution, but shall cease upon the death of the permittee or licensee. No permittee or licensee shall in any manner advertise its services as permitted, licensed or bonded by the city. 
(7)  An adult entertainment enterprise in operation prior to the effective date of the adult entertainment enterprise ordinance which does not conform to the regulations pertaining to adult entertainment enterprise shall be deemed a nonconforming use and those provisions of Appendix A, Section 11 of the Code of Ordinances entitled Nonconforming Uses shall apply except insofar as hereby amended: 
(a)  The owner, manager, officer, trustee, receiver or person who is primarily responsible for the management of the adult entertainment enterprise in operation prior to the effective date of the adult entertainment enterprise ordinance shall register with the building official within thirty (30) days immediately following the effective date of the adult entertainment enterprise ordinance as such nonconforming use, claiming exemption from the locational requirements of the adult entertainment enterprise ordinance, and providing the following information: 
1.  If the registrant is an individual: 
a.  The registrant's full legal name, including any and all other name(s) by which the registrant has been known during the last five (5) years. 
b.  The location by street and number of the registrant's residence. 
2.  If the registrant is by a firm, association or partnership, all of the information required in subsection 17-81(7)(a)1.a. regarding individual registrants shall be given as to each member of the firm, association or partnership. 
3.  If the registration is made in behalf of a corporation, then all of the information required in subsection 17-81(7)(a)1.a. regarding individual registrants shall be given as to the manager, officer, trustee, receiver or person who is primarily responsible for the management of the premises and in addition shall state the exact corporation name and when and where the corporation has been chartered and if requested by the building official shall give the name of each and every stockholder of such corporation. 
4.  The location by street and number of the premises of such existing adult entertainment enterprise, and the name under which the business is conducted. 
5.  If the premises are leased, the name of the lesser and the lessee. 
6.  A general description of the services to be provided. 
7.  Telephone number of the adult entertainment enterprise. 
8.  The legal description of the parcel of land on which the adult entertainment enterprise is located. 
9.  The date on which the registrant became the legal owner of the adult entertainment enterprise for which registration is sought, and the date on which the adult entertainment enterprise began operations at the location for which registration is sought. 
10.  Written proof that the registrant is at least twenty-one (21) years of age. 
11.  The registrant's height, weight and color of hair and eyes. 
12.  Two (2) portrait photographs, at least two (2) inches by two (2) inches in size, taken within the previous six (6) months, otherwise, the nonconforming use shall be illegal and shall terminate. 
(b)  Such nonconforming uses shall not be increased, enlarged, extended, or altered except that the use may be changed to a conforming use. 
(c)  An adult entertainment enterprise lawfully operating as a conforming use is not rendered a nonconforming use by the construction or location of a church, school, hospital, park, dwelling or expansion in width of Broadway/Highway 80. 
(d)  The right of the nonconforming use to continue operation once registered shall be deemed personal to the registrant and shall not be assignable nor transferable. 
(e)  All registrations for nonconforming use as hereby provided in this article shall be updated (renewed) annually. 
(Ord. No. 89-19, 8-8-89) 
Sec. 17-82. - Applicability of other laws. 
(1)  All other provisions of this article and all other city ordinances pertaining to any regulated use remain in full force and effect and the provisions of this article are in addition to said provisions and ordinances. 
(2)  It shall be unlawful to allow a person who is younger than twenty-one (21) years of age to enter an adult entertainment establishment for the purpose of being a customer there, or being solicited by an adult entertainment enterprise for the purpose of being a customer there. 
(Ord. No. 89-19, 8-8-89) 
Sec. 17-83. - Required records. 
(1)  Every adult entertainment establishment or enterprise permittee or registrant shall maintain a current list of all employees employed by the establishment or enterprise, showing the name and current address of each employee. 
(2)  The records required by paragraph (1) of this section shall be kept available and open for inspection by the police department at any reasonable time.
