(4)  As deemed necessary by the planning and zoning commission in commercial, industrial, public grounds and multi-family dwelling areas. 
(Ord. of 8-25-81, § 10) 
Cross reference- Sidewalks generally, § 25-1 et seq. 
Sec. 26-48. - Water installations. 
(a)  Water supply and distribution. All subdivisions shall be provided with water supply and water distribution systems approved by the city engineer. 
(b)  Fire hydrants. Standard fire hydrants shall be installed as part of the water distribution system in accordance with the specifications of the state board of insurance. 
(Ord. of 8-25-81, § 10) 
Cross reference- Plumbing generally, § 7-61 et seq. 
Sec. 26-49. - Sewers. 
(a)  All subdivisions shall be provided with a sewage disposal system approved by the city engineer. 
(b)  Connection with the sanitary sewer system shall be required except where the city engineer determines that the connection will require unreasonable expenditures when compared with other methods of sewage disposal. Where septic tanks are installed, the subdivider shall conduct percolation tests under the supervision of the city engineer in order to determine its adequacy in relation to the proposed lot sizes. If a sanitary sewage disposal system is to be installed, the plans for such system must be approved by the state health department, prior to approval of the final plat by the planning and zoning commission. 
(Ord. of 8-25-81, § 10) 
Sec. 26-50. - Utility lines. 
    All utility lines that pass under a street or alley shall be installed before the street or alley is paved. When it is necessary that utility lines pass under the street or alley pavements, they shall be installed to a point at least three (3) feet beyond the edge of the pavement. 
(Ord. of 8-25-81, § 10) 
Cross reference- Plumbing generally, § 7-61 et seq. 
Sec. 26-51. - Monuments. 
(a)  All block corners, angle points and points of curve, and all corners of boundary lines of the subdivision shall be designated with concrete monuments. 
(b)  The exact intersection point on the monument shall be marked by a three-quarter-inch diameter galvanized iron pipe, three (3) feet in length with the top of the pipe one (1) inch above the top of the concrete which shall be flush with the existing ground surface. 
(c)  Where, due to topographic conditions, permanent structures, or other conditions, the view is obstructed between any two (2) adjacent monuments, intermediate monuments shall be set so as to assure a clear view between adjacent monuments. All such intermediate property corners shall be marked with reinforcing iron bars one-half-inch in diameter by two (2) feet in length, driven nearly flush with the ground or counter-sunk slightly to avoid being disturbed. 
(d)  All final plats must be in full accordance with the certifications signed by either the engineer or surveyor in regard to the plat being properly staked on the ground and in compliance with requirements concerning the markers or monuments used. 
(Ord. of 8-25-81, § 10) 
Sec. 26-52. - Drainage. 
(a)  Easement. Where a subdivision is traversed by a watercourse, drainage way, natural channel or stream, there shall be provided an easement or right-of-way conforming substantially to the limit of the watercourse, with additional width to accommodate future needs. Drainage easements shall be determined by the city engineer both as to location and width. 
(b)  Drainage facilities. Drainage facilities shall be provided and constructed as specified by the city engineer. 
(Ord. of 8-25-81, § 10) 
Sec. 26-53. - Blocks. 
    Block lengths shall not exceed one thousand two hundred (1,200) feet, except along major thoroughfares. Maximum block lengths along a major street shall be one thousand six hundred (1,600) feet except under special conditions determined by the planning and zoning commission. 
(Ord. of 8-25-81, § 10) 
Sec. 26-54. - Crosswalk ways. 
    Crosswalk ways six (6) feet in width shall be dedicated where deemed necessary by the planning and zoning commission to provide circulation or access to schools, playgrounds, shopping centers and transportation and other community facilities, and to provide for circulation of pedestrians within the subdivision. Crosswalk ways shall be constructed with a six (6) foot wide concrete sidewalk. 
(Ord. of 8-25-81, § 10) 
Sec. 26-55. - Minimum lot size. 
(a)  In the "A" districts, under the city zoning ordinance, the minimum area of the lot shall be six thousand (6,000) square feet. 
(b)  In the "B" district, under the city zoning ordinance, the minimum area of the lot shall be five thousand (5,000) square feet for a single-family dwelling or six thousand (6,000) square feet for a two-family dwelling. 
(c)  In the "E", "J", "K", "L" and "M" districts, under the city zoning ordinance, the minimum area of the lots shall be four thousand (4,000) square feet for single-family dwellings; five thousand (5,000) square feet for a two-family dwelling; and for apartment houses or buildings arranged or designed for more than two (2) families, the minimum area shall be five thousand (5,000) square feet, plus six hundred (600) square feet for each family in excess of two (2). 
(d)  In the "C", "D", "F", "G" and "H" districts, under the city zoning ordinance, the minimum area of the lots shall be five thousand (5,000) square feet for single-family dwellings; six thousand (6,000) square feet for a two-family dwelling; and for apartment houses or buildings arranged or designed for more than two (2) families, the minimum area shall be six thousand (6,000) square feet, plus six hundred (600) square feet for each family in excess of two (2). 
(Ord. of 8-25-81, § 10) 
Sec. 26-56. - Building lines. 
    Building or setback lines are established and shall be indicated on all subdivision plats as follows: 
    Front yards. 
(1)  In the "A" districts, under the city zoning ordinance, there shall be a front yard having a depth of not less than twenty-five (25) feet from the property line to the front line of the building, covered porch or covered terrace or attached accessory building. 
(2)  In the "B", "C", "D", and "F" districts, under the city zoning ordinance, there shall be a front yard having a depth of not less than twenty-five (25) feet from the property line to the front line of the building, covered porch or covered terrace or attached accessory building. 
(3)  In the "E", "G" and "J" districts, under the city zoning ordinance, there shall be a front yard having a depth of not less than fifteen (15) feet from the property line to the front line of the building, covered porch, covered terrace or attached accessory building. 
(4)  In the "K", "L", "M" and "H" districts, under the city zoning ordinance, no front yard is required unless the building is erected or structurally altered for dwelling purposes, in which event, a front yard of not less than fifteen (15) feet in depth is required. 
(5)  Where the frontage on one (1) side of a street between two (2) intersecting streets is zoned for two (2) classes of districts, the setback on the more restricted district shall apply to the entire block. 
    Side yards. 
(1)  In the "A", "B", "C", "D" and "E" districts, under the city zoning ordinance, and in all other districts where a building is erected or structurally altered for dwelling purposes, there shall be two (2) side yards, one (1) on each side of the building, having a combined width of not less than twenty (20) percent of the width of the lot, provided, that in no case shall either side yard be less than five (5) feet, and provided further, that the combined width of the two (2) side yards need not exceed twelve (12) feet. 
(2)  In the "D" district, under the city zoning ordinance, and in other districts where a building is erected or structurally altered for a dwelling more than three (3) stories in height, each of the two (2) side yards shall be increased one (1) foot in width for each additional story above the third. 
(3)  In the "F", "G", "H", "J", "K", "L" and "M" districts, under the city zoning ordinance, if the property is not needed for dwelling purposes no side yards are required, unless a lot abuts upon the side of a lot zoned for dwelling purposes. Where a lot abuts upon the side of a lot zoned for dwelling purposes, there shall be a side yard of not less than five (5) feet. In other cases a side yard, if provided for a business or industrial building, shall be not less than four (4) feet. 
(4)  For the purposes of side yard regulations, two (2) or more detached one- or two-family dwellings shall be considered as one (1) building when occupying one (1) lot; however, there shall be a minimum of ten (10) feet between the sides of the buildings on the same lot. 
(5)  In the case of group houses or court apartments, when the back of the buildings face upon the side yard, the width of the side yard shall be increased by one (1) foot for each building or apartment abutting thereon. If any stairway opens into or is served by such side yard, the minimum width of the side yard shall be ten (10) feet. 
    Rear yards. 
(1)  In all districts, under the city zoning ordinance, where buildings are erected or structurally altered for dwelling purposes there shall be a rear yard having a depth of not less than twenty (20) percent of the depth of the lot, provided the rear yard shall not exceed twenty-five (25) feet. 
(2)  In the "F" and "G" districts, under the city zoning ordinance, there shall be a rear yard having a depth of not less than twenty (20) percent of the depth of the lot, provided the rear yard shall not exceed twenty-five (25) feet. 
(3)  In the "H", "J", "K", "L" and "M" districts, under the city zoning ordinance, when property is not used for dwelling purposes, and when not abutting on the rear on a dwelling district, no rear yard is required. If abutting on the rear on an "A", "B", "C" or "E" dwelling district, a rear yard of at least ten (10) feet is required. 
(4)  In computing the required depth of a rear yard for any building where the rear yard abuts on an alley, the required depth of the rear yard shall be measured from the center of the alley. 
(5)  An accessory building not exceeding one (1) story in height may occupy not more than sixty (60) percent of a minimum required rear yard. 
(6)  An accessory building exceeding one (1) story in height may occupy not more than forty (40) percent of a minimum required rear yard. 
(Ord. of 8-25-81, § 10) 
Sec. 26-57. - Corner lots. 
    On corner lots, the side yard regulations shall be the same as for the interior lots, except in the case of a side street or reversed frontage (where the corner lot faces an intersecting street), in which case there shall also be a side yard on the street side equal to the front yard on the lots in the rear. No accessory building on a corner lot shall project beyond the front yard line on the lots in the rear. This section shall not be so interpreted as to reduce the buildable width of a corner lot facing an intersecting street to less than twenty-eight (28) feet. 
(Ord. of 8-25-81, § 10) 
Sec. 26-58. - Waiver of side and front yard requirements. 
    The side and front yard requirements for dwellings shall be waived where dwellings are erected above stores or shops. 
(Ord. of 8-25-81, § 10) 
Sec. 26-59. - Courts, places, group houses. 
(a)  The width of a place or court shall not be less than forty (40) feet measured between the buildings or from the buildings to the opposite property line; however, open or unclosed porches may project into the required place or court not more than twenty (20) percent of the width of such a place or court. 
(b)  All other requirements, including front, side and rear yards, shall be complied with in accordance with the district in which group houses or court apartments are located. 
(c)  Every part of a required yard or court shall be open and unobstructed, from its lowest point to the sky, except for the ordinary projections of sills, belt courses, cornices, etc.; however, the projections shall not extend into a court more than twenty-four (24) inches or into a minimum side yard more than twenty-four (24) inches. 
(Ord. of 8-25-81, § 10) 
Sec. 26-60. - Responsibility for street and utilities installation. 
(a)  In general, the subdivider or developer shall be required to construct, at his expense, all streets, alleys, sidewalks, crosswalks, sanitary sewers, sewage lift stations, septic tanks or other sewage facilities, water mains and water systems, drainage culverts, storm sewers, bridges, street lights and other appurtenances which are necessary and required to adequately serve the subdivision or addition to be developed by him. 
(b)  All streets, utilities and other appurtenances constructed by the developer shall become the property of the city upon completion and acceptance by the city engineer. 
(c)  It is the policy of the city to participate with the developer in the cost of construction of such facilities where sizes and capabilities of facilities are required to service urban development of a larger area than that being subdivided or into areas extending beyond the limits of the proposed subdivision; however, the city reserves the right to consider each facility on its own merits. 
(Ord. of 8-25-81, § 11) 
Sec. 26-61. - Parks, playgrounds and other public facilities. 
(a)  Parks and playgrounds. The location, size and shape of any proposed park or playground shall be in accordance with the master plan of the city and county as approved by the planning and zoning commission and accepted by the city commission. 
(b)  Schools. The location, size and shape of any proposed school site shall be in accordance with the comprehensive plan of the city and county, as approved by the planning and zoning commission and by the city commission. 
(c)  Public facilities and other special land uses. The location, size and shape of any proposed public facility or other special land use site shall be in accordance with the comprehensive plan of the city and county, as approved by the planning and zoning commission and accepted by the city commission. 
(d)  Disapproval. The disapproval of any proposed park, playground, school, public facility or other special land use site, as described in this section, by the planning and zoning commission or the city commission shall be deemed a refusal by the proper authority to accept the offered dedication. 
(Ord. of 8-25-81, § 12) 
Sec. 26-62. - Where subdivision is unit of larger tract. 
    Where the proposed subdivision constitutes a unit of a large tract owned by the subdivider, which is intended to be subsequently subdivided as additional units of the same subdivision, the preliminary and final plats shall be accompanied by a layout of the entire area, showing the tentative proposed layout of streets, blocks, drainage, water, sewage and other improvements for the area. The overall layout, if approved by the planning and zoning commission, shall be attached to and filed with a copy of the approved subdivision plat in the permanent files of the city engineer. Thereafter, plats of subsequent units of the subdivision shall conform to such approved overall layout, unless changed by the planning and zoning commission. Except where the subdivider agrees to such change, the planning and zoning commission may change such approved overall layout only when the planning and zoning commission finds: 
(1)  The adherence to the previously approved overall layout will hinder the orderly subdivision of other land in the area in accordance with the provisions of this chapter; or 
(2)  That adherence to the previously approved overall layout will be detrimental to the public health, safety or welfare, or will be injurious to other property in the area. 
(Ord. of 8-25-81, § 13) 
Secs. 26-63-26-80. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - TOWNHOUSE SUBDIVISIONS 

Sec. 26-81. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this article, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings ascribed to them by this section: 
    Access street shall apply to those public streets within or bounding a townhouse subdivision which serve a townhouse subdivision and other adjacent property. 
    Interior street shall apply to public streets not more than six hundred (600) feet long within a townhouse subdivision, which streets are located and designed to serve a limited area within the subdivision and shall not serve other properties outside the subdivision. 
    Open space shall apply to private property, under common ownership, designated as a recreation area, private park, play lot area or plaza area and shall include those building setbacks and ornamental areas open to general view within the subdivision. Open space does not include streets, alleys, utility easements and required building setbacks. 
    Townhouse and row house shall be interchangeable in definition and shall mean a structure which is one of a series of dwelling units designed for a single-family occupancy, which are connected or immediately adjacent to each other. 
    Townhouse subdivision shall apply to those developments in which it is proposed to partition land into individual lots and construct townhouses which may be individually owned and where the minimum lot sizes are to be less than those required under article III. 
(Ord. of 8-25-81, § 14) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2; definitions applicable to this chapter, § 26-2. 
Sec. 26-82. - Compliance. 
    Any person proposing to develop a "townhouse subdivision" within the city or within its jurisdictional area shall comply with the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. of 8-25-81, § 14) 
Sec. 26-83. - Streets. 
(a)  Interior streets, if dedicated to public use, shall have a minimum right-of-way width of fifty-five (55) feet and shall be developed with a minimum of thirty-six (36) foot paving section, with concrete curbs and gutters. 
(b)  Access streets shall have a minimum right-of-way of fifty (50) feet and shall be developed with a minimum thirty-two (32) foot pavement section. 
(c)  All townhouse subdivisions shall have a direct access street to at least one dedicated and accessible public street having a right-of-way width of not less than fifty (50) feet. 
(d)  Alleys shall have a minimum right-of-way of twenty (20) feet. 
(Ord. of 8-25-81, § 14) 
Sec. 26-84. - Building setback lines. 
(a)  Building setback lines of ten (10) feet shall be required on all lots fronting on an access street. 
(b)  Building setback lines of twenty (20) feet shall be required on all lots siding on access streets or upon a plat boundary. 
(c)  No building setback lines shall be required on the sides of lots abutting interior streets. 
(d)  Where townhouse lots and dwelling units are designed to face upon an open or common access court rather than upon a public street, the open or common court shall be at least forty (40) feet wide and not more than two hundred (200) feet long, measured from the public street upon which the court opens. The court may not include vehicular drives or parking areas in front of dwelling units. 
(Ord. of 8-25-81, § 14) 
Sec. 26-85. - Lots. 
(a)  The lot area shall be a minimum of two thousand five hundred (2,500) square feet. 
(b)  The lot width shall be a minimum of twenty-five (25) feet. 
(c)  The dwelling units may be constructed up to the side lot lines, and openings shall not face a side lot line unless the side wall of the dwelling unit is at least ten (10) feet from the side lot line. 
(d)  The lot size may be reduced on the condition that open space be dedicated according to the following schedule: 
For every one hundred (100) square feet of open space per lot provided, the minimum lot area may be reduced by two hundred (200) square feet. No lot shall, however, have a lot area of less than two thousand (2,000) square feet, and a width of less than twenty-five (25) feet.

Sec. 26-86. - Utilities to be underground. 
    All utilities, including, but not limited to, sanitary sewers, water, gas, telephone, television cable and electrical, shall be placed underground. 
(Ord. of 8-25-81, § 14) 
Chapter 27 - TAXATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Taxation, Article X. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 27-1. - Tax on residential gas and electricity. 
    The imposition of the one (1) percent city sales tax on residential use of gas and electricity shall be continued within the city. 
(Ord. of 4-27-79) 
State Law reference- Local Sales and Use Tax Act, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 1066c; continuation of tax on gas and electricity for residential use, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 1066c, § 4A. 
Sec. 27-2. - Additional penalty and costs when delinquent taxes referred to attorney. 
(a)  Whenever any accounts for delinquent taxes owed the city are given to an attorney for collection, on or after the first day of July of the year they become delinquent, the city shall be entitled to, and shall collect, an additional penalty of fifteen (15) percent of the delinquent taxes and penalty, including any interest owed, due on each delinquent property at the time of collection, either before or after the suit and/or foreclosure sale as provided by the Texas Property Tax Code, Section 33.07. 
(b)  In addition to the collection expenses provided for in subsection (a), the city shall be entitled to collect the actual expenses incurred by the city in providing all data and information as to the name, identity and location of necessary parties and the legal description of property necessary to the filing of any suit for delinquent taxes. 
(Ord. of 9-22-81, §§ 1, 2) 
Sec. 27-3. - Authority to levy occupational taxes. 
    The city commission is authorized to levy and assess against every person in the city who shall hereafter be taxed by the occupation tax laws of the state, and occupation tax equal in each instance to one-half of the occupation tax levied by the state on each occupation and establishment. 
Cross reference- Licenses and business regulations, § 17-1 et seq. 
State Law reference- Authorization for occupation tax, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 7048; occupation taxes generally, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. Tax-Gen. art. 19.01 et seq. 
Sec. 27-4. - Taxation of property exempt under Art. VIII, Section 1-j, Texas Constitution. 
    All of that property described in the Texas Constitution, Article VIII, Section 1-j, shall be fully taxable in the City of Sweetwater, Texas, beginning January 1, 1990. 
(Ord. No. 89-26, § 1, 12-12-89) 
Editor's note- Ord No. 89-26, § 1, adopted Dec. 12, 1989, did not specifically amend the Code and at the discretion of the editor said provisions have been included herein as § 27-4. 
Secs. 27-5-27-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - HOTEL OCCUPANCY TAX[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Hotel occupancy tax, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 1266j, §§ 3a, 3b. 

Sec. 27-21. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases are, for the purpose of this article and except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning, defined as follows: 
    City comptroller shall mean the city comptroller of the City of Sweetwater. 
    Consideration shall mean the cost of the room, sleeping space, bed or dormitory space, but shall not include cost of any food sold or personal services rendered to the occupant not related to cleaning and readying such room or space for occupancy, and shall not include any tax assessed for the occupancy thereof by any other governmental agency. 
    Hotel shall mean any building or buildings, trailer, railroad pullman car not being utilized for transportation of travelers, or other facility in which the public may, for consideration, obtain sleeping accommodations. The term shall include hotels, motels, tourist homes, houses or courts, lodging houses, inns, rooming houses, trailer motels, railroad pullman cars parked on a siding, or otherwise used for sleeping accommodations not involving transportation of travelers, dormitory space where bed space is rented by individuals or groups, apartments not occupied by "permanent residents", as that term is hereinafter defined, and all other facilities where rooms or sleeping facilities or space are furnished for a consideration. As defined herein "hotel" shall not include hospitals, sanitariums or nursing homes. 
    Occupancy shall mean the use or possession, or the right to the use of possession of any room, space or sleeping facility in a hotel for any purpose. 
    Occupant shall mean anyone who, for consideration uses, possesses, or has the right to use or possess any room or rooms, or sleeping space, or facility in a hotel under any lease, concession, permit, right of access, license, contract or agreement. 
    Permanent resident shall mean any occupant who has or shall have the right of occupancy of any room or rooms or sleeping space or facility in a hotel for at least thirty (30) consecutive days during the calendar year or preceding year. 
    Person shall mean any individual, company, corporation, or association owning, operating, managing or controlling any hotel. 
    Quarterly period shall mean the regular calendar quarters of the year, the first quarter being compiled of the months of January, February and March; the second quarter being the months of April, May and June; the third quarter being the months of July, August, and September; and the fourth quarter being October, November and December. 
(Ord. No. 9-27-77, § 1; Ord. No. 84-06-259/III, 6-12-84) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2 
Sec. 27-22. - Tax imposed, administration and delegation of functions. 
(a)  There is hereby levied a tax on the cost of occupancy of any room or space furnished by any hotel or motel where such cost of occupancy is at the rate of two dollars ($2.00) or more per day. Such tax shall be in an amount equal to seven (7) percent of the consideration paid by the occupant of such room to the hotel or motel, exclusive of other occupancy taxes proposed by other governmental agencies, effective the first day of October, 1991. 
(b)  No tax shall be imposed hereunder upon a permanent resident. 
(c)  No tax shall be imposed hereunder upon a corporation or association organized and operated exclusively for religious, charitable or educational purposes, no part of the net earnings of which ensures to the benefit of any private shareholder or individual. 
(d)  Any revenues received by the City of Sweetwater, Texas, from this tax may only be used for the purposes specified in Section 351.101 of the Texas Tax Code which are as follows: 
(1)  The acquisition of sites for and the construction, improvement, enlarging, equipping, repairing, operation and maintenance of convention center facilities. 
(2)  The furnishing of facilities, personnel, and materials for the registration of convention delegates or registrants. 
(3)  Advertising and conducting solicitations and promotional programs to attract tourist and convention delegates or registrants to the municipality or its vicinity. 
(4)  The encouragement, promotion, improvement and application of the arts, including instrumental and vocal music, dance, drama, folk art, creative writing, architecture, design and allied fields, painting, sculpture, photography, graphic and craft arts, motion pictures, radio, television, tape and sound recording, and other arts related to the presentation, performance, execution, and exhibition of these major art forms. 
(5)  Historical restoration and preservation projects or activities or advertising and conducting solicitations and promotional programs to encourage tourists and convention delegates to visit preserved historic sites or museums. 
(6)  Revenues derived from the tax authorized by this article shall be expended pursuant to Chapter 351 of the Tax Code of the State of Texas and such revenues may not be used for general revenue purposes or general governmental operations. 
(7)  The city commission by contract may delegate to a person or entity, the management or supervision of programs and activities funded with revenue from the tax authorized by this article. The city commission in writing shall approve in advance the annual budget of the person or entity to which it delegates those functions and shall require such person or entity to make periodic reports to the governing body at least annually listing the expenditures made by the person or entity of revenues from the tax authorized by this article provided by the municipality. Such person or entity shall maintain revenue provided by the city from the hotel occupancy tax in a separate account established for that purpose and may not commingle that revenue with any other money or maintain it in any other account. The delegation, the management or supervision of the city's convention and visitors programs and activities funded with revenue from the hotel tax shall be by contract. The city shall approve the annual budget of the person or entity to whom the management or supervision of the programs and activities funded with hotel tax revenue is delegated. 
(8)  The person or entity to whom these functions are delegated shall maintain complete and accurate financial records of each expenditure of hotel occupancy tax revenue and on request of the city commission shall make the records available for inspection and review. 
(9)  Hotel occupancy tax revenues shall be spent and allocated pursuant to Chapter 351 of the Texas Tax Code. 
(Ord. of 9-27-77, § 2; Ord. No. 84-06-259/III, § 2, 6-12-84; Ord. No. 86-48, § 1, 9-9-86; Ord. No. 89-25, 11-14-89; Ord. No. 91-11, § 1, 9-10-91) 
Sec. 27-23. - Collection. 
(a)  Every person owning, operating, managing or controlling any hotel shall collect the tax imposed by section 27-22 hereof for the City of Sweetwater. 
(b)  The person required to collect the tax referred to may deduct and withhold from the person's tax payment to the city, as reimbursement for the cost of collecting the tax, an amount equal to one (1) percent of the amount of tax collected and required to be reported to the city. 
(c)  The failure on the part of the person collecting such tax to make timely payment of such tax and to file reports required by the City of Sweetwater in a timely fashion shall result in a forfeiture of the reimbursement permitted herein. The times for payment and reporting are as specified in section 27-24. 
(Ord. of 9-27-77, § 3; Ord. of 10-27-81, § 2; Ord. No. 84-06-259/III, §§ 3, 5, 6-12-84) 
Sec. 27-24. - Reports and payment. 
    On the last day of the month following each quarterly period, every person required in section 27-23 hereof to collect the tax imposed herein, shall file a report with the city comptroller showing the consideration paid for all room occupancies in the preceding quarter, the amount of the tax collected on such occupancies, and any other information the city comptroller may reasonably require. Such person shall pay the tax due on such occupancies at the time of filing such report. There shall also be furnished to the city comptroller of the City of Sweetwater at the time of payment of said tax a copy of the quarterly report filed with the state comptroller in connection with the State of Texas Hotel Occupancy Tax. 
(Ord. of 9-27-77, § 4; Ord. No. 84-06-259/III, § 4, 6-12-84) 
Sec. 27-25. - Rules and regulations. 
    The city comptroller shall have the power to make such rules and regulations as are reasonable and necessary to effectively collect the tax levied hereby, and shall, upon reasonable notice, have access to books and records necessary to enable him to determine the corrections of any report filed as required by this article and the amount of taxes due under the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. of 9-27-77, § 5; Ord. No. 84-06-259/III, § 6, 6-12-84) 
Sec. 27-26. - Penalties. 
    If any person required by the provisions of this article to collect the tax imposed herein, or make reports as required herein, in paying to the city comptroller the tax imposed herein, shall fail to collect such tax, file such report or pay such tax, or if such person shall file a false report, such person shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction be punished by a fine not to exceed two hundred dollars ($200.00) and shall pay to the city comptroller the tax due, together with the penalty of five (5) percent of the tax due for each thirty (30) days that the same is not timely filed. 
(Ord. of 9-27-77, § 6; Ord. No. 84-06-259/III, § 7, 6-12-84) 
Chapter 28 - VEHICLES FOR HIRE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Authority to regulate, license and fix charges or fares for vehicles carrying passengers for hire, Art. III, § 19. 
Cross reference- Ambulances, § 14-61 et seq.; motor vehicles and traffic, § 19-1 et seq. 
State Law reference- Authority of city to regulate vehicles for hire, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 1175(21). 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 28-1-28-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - TAXICABS AND BUSES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 28-16. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this article, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribe to them by this section: 
    Driver or chauffeur: Every person who actually drives or manipulates a vehicle used as a taxicab or bus, whether as owner or as agent, servant or employee of an owner. 
    Franchise: An authority duly granted by the city commission, by ordinance, after finding that public convenience and necessity require the granting of the franchise and after compliance by the applicant for such franchise with the conditions precedent to the effectiveness of such franchise as prescribed under the terms and provisions of this article. 
    Franchise holder or owner: The term "owner" and the term "franchise holder" shall be construed to mean any person who obtains a franchise from the city or has the control, direction, maintenance or the benefit of the collection of revenue derived from the operation of taxicabs or buses on or over the streets or public ways in the city, whether as owner or otherwise, except "driver" as herein defined. 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 28-17. - Driver considered employee and agent of franchise holder. 
    Every person who drives a taxicab or bus in the city, whether the owner of the taxicab or bus he drives or not, shall be regarded as the employee, agent and representative of the holder of the franchise for whom the taxicab or bus is being operated, regardless of whether the franchise holder owns, leases, contracts for or otherwise legally controls the taxicab or bus so being driven and operated in the service of the franchise holder. 
Secs. 28-18-28-30. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - FRANCHISES 

Sec. 28-31. - Required. 
    No person shall drive or operate a taxicab or bus in the city unless the owner of such vehicle has been granted a franchise for the operation of such vehicle as a taxicab or bus in accordance with the terms and provisions of this article. 
Sec. 28-32. - Application. 
(a)  Every person proposing to operate a taxicab or bus service in the city shall make application, in writing, to the city manager requesting that the city commission grant a franchise by ordinance for such proposed taxicab or bus service. 
(b)  Such application shall set forth full and complete information on the following matters: 
(1)  The full name and permanent residence and mailing address of the applicant. If a partnership, then such information shall be given on all partners and persons having an interest in the business. If a corporation, the name and location of its principal place of business, the name and address of all the officers, directors and all stock holders in the corporation. 
(2)  The sex, age and customary calling of all persons having an interest in the requested taxicab or bus franchise. 
(3)  A current financial statement of applicant. The same shall be furnished on each partner and if a corporation, the same shall reflect the financial status of the corporation. 
(4)  A complete statement of the assets going into the taxicab or bus business for which the application is being made, together with full information on liabilities existing against such assets. 
(5)  The address and description of the contemplated headquarters of the taxicab or bus company and location and description of any taxicab or bus stands to be put into operation. 
(6)  The trade name of the taxicab or bus operation in this city. 
(7)  The color scheme of the taxicabs or buses and uniform color and description. 
(8)  A description and number of all taxicabs and buses to be put into operation. The name, make, year and model must be given and ownership of the units given. If units are leased, then that fact must be stated. 
(9)  A description of insurance coverage to be carried, together with the name and address of agent and company, or certificate of self insurance. 
(10)  A certified copy of any corporate applicant's charter must be furnished and certified copy of any foreign corporation's permit to do business in this state. 
(11)  An experience record of the applicant. 
(12)  Whether the applicant operates or has an interest in any taxicab or bus business any where other than the city, and complete information concerning same. 
(13)  Such additional factual information as may be reasonably required in this article or under authority of the city manager to afford complete information to the commission when presented to them in considering the application. 
(c)  The application shall be verified under oath and shall be prepared in quadruplicate. 
Sec. 28-33. - Public convenience and necessity prerequisite. 
    No franchise for taxicab or bus service shall be granted by the city commission unless required by the public convenience and necessity. 
Sec. 28-34. - Hearing-Required. 
    Before any franchise to operate taxicabs or buses in the city will be granted by the city commission to any person applying under this division, the city commission shall hold a hearing to consider whether public convenience and necessity require the proposed taxicab or bus service for which application is made. 
Sec. 28-35. - Same-Requirements prerequisite to setting of hearing. 
(a)  No hearing shall be set to determine public convenience and necessity unless and until there is a finding by the city manager that the applicant is fit, able and willing to perform transportation by taxicab or bus, as provided in this article, and that there could be a public demand and need for the type of service proposed to be given by the applicant. 
(b)  If the city manager finds that the applicant is not fit, able and willing to perform transportation service by taxicab or bus, or that public convenience and necessity does not require the additional taxicab or bus service, no franchise ordinance shall be prepared by the city attorney; provided, that the applicant may, within five (5) days after notice, in writing, of city manager's findings, appeal to the city commission, in writing, requesting the city commission to consider passage of an ordinance granting a franchise for the taxicab or bus service for which original application was made. 
Sec. 28-36. - Same-Notice of hearing. 
    When an application under this division is filed with the city manager, the city commission shall fix a time and place for a hearing on the application. Notice of the hearing shall be given, in writing, to the applicant and to all persons holding franchises for taxicab or bus services in the city. Due notice shall be given to the public by publication in a newspaper published in the city, the cost of such public notice to be borne by the applicant in advance of publication. The notice shall set out the name of the applicant and the nature of the application, the kind of equipment proposed to be used and all other pertinent data deemed necessary properly to inform the public, as well as the date, place and hour of the hearing which shall not be less than thirty (30) nor more than forty-five (45) days after the date of first publication. 
Sec. 28-37. - Same-Conduct. 
(a)  In all hearings before the city commission on the issue of whether to grant a taxicab or bus franchise, the burden of proof shall be upon the applicant to establish by clear, cogent and convincing evidence that the public convenience and necessity require such operation of the taxicab or bus service for which the application has been made and that the applicant is fit, able and willing to perform such transportation of persons and property by taxicab or bus as proposed in the application. 
(b)  Every holder of a franchise for the operation of a taxicab or bus service in the city or any other citizen may file such complaints and protests as such person may deem appropriate touching upon questions of public convenience and necessity affected by the applicant's proposed operations. 
(c)  In determining whether public convenience and necessity require the granting of a franchise for the proposed taxicab or bus service, the city commission shall take into consideration the following matters: 
(1)  Whether the demands of public convenience and necessity require such proposed or such additional taxicab or bus service within the city. 
(2)  The financial responsibility of the applicant. 
(3)  The number, kind and type of equipment to be used by the applicant. 
(4)  The number of taxicabs or buses already in operation in the city. 
(5)  Whether existing transportation is adequate to meet the public need. 
(6)  The probable effect of increased service on local traffic conditions. 
(7)  Whether the safe use of streets of the city by the public, both vehicular and pedestrian, will be endangered unduly by the granting of the proposed additional taxicab or bus service. 
(8)  The character, experience and responsibility of the applicant. 
(9)  Whether the applicant is fit, able and willing to perform transportation by taxicab or bus. 
(10)  The ratio of the number of taxicabs or buses operating in the city to the population of the city. 
(11)  Such other relevant facts as the city commission or city manager may deem reasonably advisable, pertinent or necessary to aid in determining whether public convenience and necessity require the additional taxicab or bus services. 
Sec. 28-38. - City attorney to prepare franchise ordinance. 
    If the city manager finds that public convenience and necessity may require the additional taxicab service for which the applicant has applied, the city attorney shall prepare the appropriate franchise ordinance for consideration by the city commission. All interested parties shall be entitled to a hearing before the city manager prior to his making any findings hereunder. 
Sec. 28-39. - Transferability and other privileges. 
    No grant, right or privilege, whether by franchise or otherwise, afforded any person under the terms and provisions of this article shall be transferable to any other person, without written application to the city for such transfer and approval thereof by action of the city commission. 
Sec. 28-40. - Insurance. 
    Before the granting of any franchise to operate a taxicab or bus service in the city shall become effective, the grantee shall procure and furnish to the city manager, and thereafter keep in full force and effect, a policy of public liability and property damage insurance, to be approved by the city attorney, and issued in the amounts and under the provisions required by state law. 
ARTICLE III. - HORSE-DRAWN CARRIAGES 

Sec. 28-41. - Permit required. 
    No person shall drive or operate a horse-drawn carriage or other touring vehicle employing the use of draft animals for locomotion, unless the owner of such horse-drawn carriage or other touring vehicle has been issued an annual permit for the operation of such horse-drawn carriage or touring vehicle in accordance with the terms and provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 93-12, 11-9-93; Ord. No. 93-13, 12-14-93) 
Sec. 28-42. - Application. 
(a)  Every person proposing to operate a horse-drawn carriage or touring vehicle employing the use of draft animals for locomotion shall make application in writing to the city manager requesting that such permit be issued. 
(b)  Such application shall set forth full and complete information on the following matters: 
(1)  The applicant has public liability and property damage insurance, which shall include the city as an additional insured, insuring the applicant against the bodily injury or death of each person in any one (1) accident in a sum of at least one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00); and providing insurance against bodily injury to or the death of two (2) or more persons in any one (1) accident with minimum coverage afforded of at least three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00); and for injury to or destruction of property in any one (1) accident providing coverage in a minimum amount of twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00). 
(2)  A proposed route for such carriages or touring vehicles and the location of the stops or stands which the applicant desires to utilize and a schedule of times and days of the time and location at which the service will be provided. 
(3)  Prove evidence or information satisfactory to the city manager that the carriages and equipment proposed to be utilized in the service are in safe and presentable condition. 
(4)  That the carriage wheels have or shall have all steel or iron outer rims adequately sheathed in rubber or other synthetic material to prevent damage to the city streets. 
(5)  All horseshoes used shall be of a type approved by the city manager. 
(6)  Applicant agrees to keep all carriage stops, stands or routes clear and free of animal void waste or excrement and will maintain all such stands or stops in a clean and sanitary manner. 
(7)  Fares will be posted so that they will be visible to the public. 
(8)  Applicant agrees to protect the health and well being of each animal employed in the provision of this service. 
(9)  Each animal employed in the provision of this service is required to be vaccinated for the prevention of rabies and any other disease that may be communicated from the animal to humans. 
(Ord. No. 93-12, 11-9-93; Ord. No. 93-13, 12-14-93) 
Sec. 28-43. - Issuance of permit. 
    If the city manager finds that the public convenience and necessity will be served and the applicant has complied with all the requirements for the issuance of a permit to operate a horse-drawn carriage or a touring vehicle employing the use of draft animals for locomotion, upon the payment of a permit fee of ten dollars ($10.00) annually, the city manager shall issue a touring vehicle permit. 
(Ord. No. 93-12, 11-9-93; Ord. No. 93-13, 12-14-93) 
Sec. 28-44. - Compliance. 
    The issuance of such a permit shall be conditioned upon continued compliance by the permittee with each of the requirements contained within this article. 
(Ord. No. 93-12, 11-9-93; Ord. No. 93-13, 12-14-93) 
Chapter 29 - WATER AND WASTEWATER[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Flood hazard prevention, § 11-1 et seq.; lakes and watercourses, § 16-1 et seq.; pollution of streams, lakes and other bodies of water declared a nuisance, § 21-2; plumbing, § 7-61 et seq.; drainage requirements for new subdivisions, § 26-52. 
State Law reference- Authority of city relative to water and sewer systems, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 1175(11), (29). 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 29-1-29-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - WATER 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 29-16. - Sale of untreated water prohibited; consumption prohibited. 
    No untreated water shall be sold from the municipal water system for human consumption. No person purchasing untreated water from the city shall use or cause it to be used for human consumption. 
(Ord. of 10-9-79) 
Sec. 29-17. - Tampering with city utility system. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to connect to the water mains or pipes of the city behind meters, to tamper with or in any manner interfere with the water mains, pipes, valves, meters, or any of the water connections or devices used in connection with the transportation of water or wastewater belonging to the city, or to reconnect or activate metering devices without the consent of the city. 
(b)  The violation of any provision of this section shall be prima facie evidence that such act of violation has been committed by the householder or occupant of property benefited or affected by the violation, therefore, the city reserves the right to disconnect or terminate water service to the premises. 
(Code 1956, § 28-5; Ord. of 8-8-67; Ord. No. 2001-08, 9-11-01) 
Sec. 29-18. - Unlawful discharges on streets and sidewalks. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in any commercial activity within the city which results in the discharge of water upon the sidewalks, alleys or public streets of the city. 
(b)  The commercial activities prohibited by subsection (a) shall not constitute a violation if a suitable drain is provided to effectively collect and dispose of the water and if the drain has been inspected and approved by the city water department. 
(Ord. of 2-10-70) 
Secs. 29-19-29-30. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - WELLS 

Sec. 29-31. - Drilling permit required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the drilling of water wells within the city without first obtaining a permit therefor from the city. 
(Ord. of 6-10-80) 
Sec. 29-32. - Permit fee. 
    The fee for a permit required by this division shall be as established from time to time by the city commission. 
(Ord. of 6-10-80) 
Sec. 29-33. - Liability insurance required. 
    In order to secure a permit required by this division, the applicant must demonstrate a valid liability policy in the sum established from time to time by the city commission. 
(Ord. of 6-10-80) 
Sec. 29-34. - Distance of windmill towers from electrical lines. 
    Windmill towers shall not be located nearer to an electric line carrying in excess of two hundred fifty (250) volts of electricity than a distance equal to the height of the windmill and tower above its supporting surface plus six (6) feet. 
(Ord. of 6-10-80) 
Sec. 29-35. - Setbacks for windmills, towers and water storage facilities. 
    The setback for windmills, towers and water storage facilities shall be the same as outlined in the zoning ordinance of the city. 
(Ord. of 6-10-80) 
Sec. 29-36. - Electric wiring of pump motors. 
    Electric wiring of water pump motors shall conform to the standards set forth in chapter 9. 
(Ord. of 6-10-80) 
Sec. 29-37. - Water not to enter city system. 
    Water from water wells shall not be connected to the city water supply unless a backflow preventer has properly been installed. Said installation shall be approved by the plumbing inspector and the owner thereof shall permit periodic inspection of the backflow. 
(Ord. of 6-10-80) 
Secs. 29-38-29-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - WASTEWATER 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 29-51-29-65. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - DISCHARGES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Plumbing code, §§ 7-61 et seq. 

Sec. 29-66. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this division, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section. 
    B.O.D. or Biochemical oxygen demand shall mean the quantity of oxygen by weight, expressed in milligrams per liter, utilized in the biochemical oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory conditions for five (5) days at a temperature of twenty (20) degrees centigrade. 
    Building sewer shall mean the extension from the building drain to the public sewer or other place of disposal (also called the house lateral and house connection). 
    C.O.D. or chemical oxygen demand shall mean the measure of the oxygen consuming capacity of inorganic and organic matter present in the matter or wastewater expressed in milligrams per liter as the amount of oxygen consumed from a chemical oxidant in a specific test, but not differentiating between stable and unstable organic matter and thus not necessarily correlating with biochemical oxygen demand. 
    Control manhole shall mean a manhole giving access to a building sewer at some point before the building sewer discharge mixes with other discharges in the public sewer. 
    Control point shall mean the point of access to a course of discharge before the discharge mixes with other discharges in the public sewer. 
    Garbage shall mean animal and vegetable wastes and residue from preparation, cooking and dispensing of food; and from the handling, processing, storage and sale of food products and produce. 
    Industrial waste shall mean waste resulting from any process of industry, manufacturing, trade, or business from the development of any natural resource, or any mixture of the waste with water or normal wastewater, as distinct from normal wastewater. 
    Industrial waste charge shall mean the charge made on those persons who discharge industrial wastes into the city's sewerage system. 
    Milligrams per liter shall mean the same as parts per million and is a weight to volume ratio; the milligram per liter value multiplied by the factor 8.34 shall be equivalent to pounds per million gallons of water. 
    Natural outlet shall mean any outlet into a watercourse, ditch, lake, or body of surface water or groundwater. 
    Normal domestic wastewater shall mean wastewater excluding industrial wastewater discharged by a person into sanitary sewers and in which the average concentration of total suspended solids is not more than three hundred (300) milligrams per liter and biochemical oxygen demand is not more than three hundred fifty (350) milligrams per liter. 
    Overload shall mean the imposition of organic or hydraulic loading on a treatment facility in excess of its engineered design capacity. 
    pH shall mean the logarithm (base 10) of the reciprocal of the hydrogen ion concentration. 
    Public sewer shall mean any pipe or conduit carrying wastewater or unpolluted drainage in which owners of abutting properties shall have the use, subject to control by the city. 
    Sanitary sewer shall mean a public sewer that conveys domestic wastewater or industrial wastes or a combination of both, and into which storm water, surface water, groundwater, and other unpolluted wastes are not intentionally passed. 
    Slug shall mean any discharge of water, wastewater or industrial waste which in concentration of any given constituent or in quantity of flow, exceeds for any period of duration longer than fifteen (15) minutes more than five (5) times the average twenty-four-hour concentration of flows during normal operation. 
    Standard methods shall mean the examination and analytical procedures set forth in the latest edition, at the time of analysis, of "Standard Methods for the Examination of Water and Wastewater" as prepared, approved, and published jointly by the American Public Health Association, the American Water Works Association, and the Water Pollution Control Federation. 
    Storm sewer shall mean a public sewer which carries storm and surface waters and drainage and into which domestic wastewater or industrial wastes are not intentionally passed. 
    Storm water shall mean rainfall or any other forms of precipitation. 
    Superintendent shall mean the director of utilities of the city or his duly authorized deputy, agent or representative. 
    Suspended solids or SS shall mean solids measured in milligrams per liter that either float on the surface of, or are in suspension in, water, wastewater, or other liquids, and which are largely removable by a laboratory filtration device. 
    To discharge includes to deposit, conduct, drain, emit, throw, run, allow to seep, or otherwise release or, dispose of, or to allow, permit, or suffer any of these acts or omissions. 
    Trap shall mean a device designed to skim, settle, or otherwise remove grease, oil, sand, flammable wastes or other harmful substances. 
    Unpolluted wastewater shall mean water containing: 
(1)  No free or emulsified grease or oil. 
(2)  No acids or alkalis. 
(3)  No phenols or other substances producing taste or odor in receiving water. 
(4)  No toxic or poisonous substances in suspension, colloidal state, or solution. 
(5)  No noxious or otherwise obnoxious or odorous gases. 
(6)  Not more than an insignificant amount in milligrams per liter each of suspended solids and BOD, as determined by the state department of water resources. 
(7)  Color not exceeding fifty (50) units as measured by the platinum-cobalt method of determination as specified in standard methods. 
    Waste shall mean rejected, unutilized or superfluous substances in liquid, gaseous, or solid form resulting from domestic, agricultural, or industrial activities. 
    Wastewater shall mean a combination of the water-carried waste from residences, business buildings, institutions, and industrial establishments, together with any ground, surface, and storm water that may be present. 
    Wastewater facilities includes all facilities for collection, pumping, treating, and disposing of wastewater and industrial wastes. 
    Wastewater treatment plant shall mean any city-owned facilities, devices, and structures used for receiving, processing and treating wastewater, industrial waste, and sludges from the sanitary sewers. 
    Wastewater service charge shall mean the charge on all users of the public sewer system whose wastes do not exceed in strength the concentration values established as representative of normal wastewater. 
    Watercourse shall mean a natural or man-made channel in which a flow of water occurs, either continuously or intermittently. 
    Technical terms used herein, but not defined in this section, shall have meanings as given in the latest edition of "Glossary of Water and Wastewater Engineering," prepared jointly by the Water Pollution Control Federation, American Waterworks Association, American Public Health Association and the American Society of Civil Engineers. 
(Ord. No. 83-13-49/III, § 1, 5-24-83) 
Sec. 29-67. - Modes of disposal of wastewater, storm water and other unpolluted drainage. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to construct or maintain any privy, privy vault, cesspool or other private facility intended or used for the disposal of normal domestic wastewaters, sewage or industrial wastes or wastewaters. This subsection shall not apply to: 
(1)  Approved gray-water irrigation systems or rainwater systems. 
(2)  City approved and required grease and lint traps, sand traps or monitoring tank applications designed to protect the public sewer system from prohibited wastes. 
(3)  Private onsite sewage disposal systems installed in compliance with the regulations of the State of Texas and approved for use by the City of Sweetwater where the public sewer system is not reasonably available, as determined by the city. 
(b)  Unless subsection (a)(3) of this section applies, the owner of any new establishment, house, building or property used for human occupancy, habitation, employment, recreation or industrial or commercial purpose within the corporate limits of the city shall install, at his or her own expense, code approved facilities for conveying all normal domestic wastewater and all other wastewaters to the proper public sewer. Those existing at the passage of this ordinance [from which this article derives] shall connect to the public sewer system or, where sewer is available to in-city customers that do not connect to the public sewer system whose property line is one hundred (100) feet or less from an accessible public sewer main, shall pay for sewer at the current rate as set forth in the city's central rate schedule as established from time to time by the city commission. 
(c)  No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged wastes, except normal domestic wastewater, from any industrial or commercial establishment, building, or property into sanitary sewers without obtaining a permit from the city as outlined herein. 
(d)  No person shall make any new connections from inflow sources or discharge into the public sanitary sewers any of the following: 
(1)  Unpolluted storm water, surface water, groundwater, roof runoff or subsurface drainage. 
(2)  Unpolluted cooling water. 
(3)  Unpolluted industrial process waters. 
(4)  Other unpolluted drainage. 
(e)  In compliance with the Texas Water Quality Act and other provisions of state law, storm water and other unpolluted water described in subsection (d) may be discharged to public sewers specifically designated as storm sewers by the city manager or to a specifically designated and authorized natural outlet. 
(f)  Unless authorized by the state department of water resources and the city manager, no person may deposit or discharge any wastewater, industrial waste, or polluted liquids on public or private property or into or adjacent to any: 
(1)  Natural outlet. 
(2)  Watercourse. 
(3)  Storm sewer. 
(4)  Other area within the jurisdiction of the city. 
(g)  The city manager shall verify prior to discharge that wastes authorized to be discharged shall receive suitable treatment within the provisions of laws, regulations, ordinances, rules and orders of federal, state and local governments. 
(Ord. No. 83-13-49/III, § 2, 5-24-83; Ord. No. 2014-14, 12-9-14) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 29-68. - Prohibited discharges generally. 
(a)  In addition to those discharges otherwise prohibited by this division, no person may discharge into public sewers any waste which by itself or by interaction with other wastes may: 
(1)  Injure or interfere with wastewater treatment processes or facilities. 
(2)  Constitute a hazard to humans or animals. 
(3)  Create a hazard in receiving water of the wastewater treatment plant effluent. 
(b)  All discharges shall conform to requirements of this division. 
(Ord. No. 83-13-49/III, § 3, 5-24-83) 
Sec. 29-69. - Chemical discharges. 
(a)  No discharge to public sewers may contain: 
(1)  Cyanide greater than one (1) milligram per liter. 
(2)  Fluoride, other than that contained in the public water supply. 
(3)  Chlorides in concentrations greater than two hundred fifty (250) milligrams per liter. 
(4)  Gasoline, benzene, naphtha, fuel oil, or other flammable or explosive liquid, solid or gas. 
(5)  Substances causing an excessive chemical oxygen demand. 
(b)  No waste or wastewater discharge to public waters may contain: 
(1)  Strong acid, iron pickling wastes, or concentrated plating solutions, whether neutralized or not. 
(2)  Fats, wax, grease, or oils, whether emulsified or not, in excess of one hundred (100) milligrams per liter or containing substances which may solidify or become viscous at temperatures between thirty-two (32) and one hundred fifty (150) degrees Fahrenheit (0 and 65 degrees Centigrade). 
(3)  Objectionable or toxic substances, exerting an excessive chloride requirement, to such degree that any such material received in the composite wastewater treatment works exceeds the limits established by the city manager for such materials. 
(4)  Obnoxious, toxic or poisonous solids, liquids, or gases in quantities sufficient to violate the provisions of section 29-68. 
(c)  No waste, wastewater, or other substance may be discharged into public sewers which has a pH lower than six (6) or higher than ten (10) or any other corrosive property capable of causing damage or hazard to structures, equipment, or personnel at the wastewater facilities. 
(d)  All waste, wastewater, or other substance containing phenols, hydrogen sulfide, or other taste and odor-producing substances, shall conform to concentration limits established by the city manager. After treatment of the composite wastewater, concentration limits may not exceed the requirements established by state, federal, or other agencies with jurisdiction over discharges to receiving waters. 
(Ord. No. 83-13-49/III, § 4, 5-24-83) 
Sec. 29-70. - Hazardous metals and toxic materials. 
(a)  No discharge may contain concentrations of hazardous metals, in terms of milligrams per liter, as determined by individual sampling in excess of the following, as established by the Texas Water Quality Act.

(Ord. No. 83-13-49/III, § 5, 5-24-83) 
Editor's note- The concentrations contained herein are in accordance with the provisions of the Texas Water Code, V.T.C.A., Water Code, §§ 5.31 and 5.132 and in accordance with Texas Department of Water Resources Rule, § 156.19. 
Sec. 29-71. - Particle size. 
(a)  No person may discharge garbage or other solids into public sewers unless it is shredded to a degree that all particles can be carried freely under the flow conditions normally prevailing in public sewers. Particles greater than one-half (1/2) inch in any dimensions are prohibited. 
(b)  The city manager is entitled to review and approve the installation and operation of any garbage grinder equipped with a motor of three-fourths (3/4) horsepower (0.76 hp metric) or greater. 
(Ord. No. 83-13-49/III, § 6, 5-24-83) 
Sec. 29-72. - Temperature. 
    No person may discharge liquid or vapor having a temperature higher than one hundred fifty (150) degrees Fahrenheit (65 degrees Centigrade), or any substance which causes the temperature of the total wastewater treatment plant influent to increase at a rate of ten (10) degrees Fahrenheit or more per hour, or a combined total increase of plant influent to one hundred ten (110) degrees Fahrenheit. 
(Ord. No. 83-13-49/III, § 7, 5-24-83) 
Sec. 29-73. - Radioactive waste. 
(a)  No person may discharge radioactive wastes or isotopes into public sewers without the permission of the city manager. 
(b)  The city manager may establish, in compliance with applicable state and federal regulations, regulations for discharge of radioactive wastes into public sewers. 
(Ord. No. 83-13-49/III, § 8, 5-24-83) 
Sec. 29-74. - Impairment of facilities. 
(a)  No person may discharge into public sewers any substance capable of causing: 
(1)  Obstruction to the flow in sewers. 
(2)  Interference with the operation of treatment processes or facilities. 
(3)  Excessive loading of treatment facilities. 
(b)  Discharges prohibited by subsection (a) include, but are not limited to, materials which exert or cause concentrations of: 
(1)  Inert suspended solids greater than two hundred fifty (250) milligrams per liter, including but not limited to: 
a.  Fuller's earth. 
b.  Lime slurries. 
c.  Lime residues. 
(2)  Dissolved solids greater than one thousand milligrams per liter, including but not limited to: 
a.  Sodium chloride. 
b.  Sodium sulfate. 
(3)  Excessive discoloration including but not limited to: 
a.  Dye wastes. 
b.  Vegetable tanning solutions. 
(4)  BOD, COD, or chlorine demand in excess of normal plant capacity. 
(c)  No person may discharge into public sewers any water or waste which may contain more than 0.2 milligrams per liter of dissolved sulfides. 
(d)  No person may discharge into public sewers any substance that may: 
(1)  Deposit grease or oil in the sewer lines in such a manner as to clog the sewers. 
(2)  Overload skimming and grease handling equipment. 
(3)  Pass to receiving waters without being effectively treated by normal wastewater treatment processes due to nonamendability of the substance to bacterial action. 
(4)  Deleteriously affect the treatment process due to excessive quantities. 
(e)  No person may discharge any substance into public sewers which: 
(1)  Is not amenable to treatment or reduction by the processes and facilities employed. 
(2)  Is amenable to treatment only to such a degree that the treatment plant effluent cannot meet the requirements of other agencies having jurisdiction over discharge to the receiving waters. 
(f)  The city manager shall regulate the flow and concentration of slugs when they may: 
(1)  Impair the treatment processes. 
(2)  Cause damage to collection facilities. 
(3)  Incur treatment cists exceeding those for normal wastewater. 
(4)  Render the effluent unfit for stream disposal or industrial use. 
(g)  No person may discharge into public sewers solid or viscous substances which may violate subsection (a) if present in sufficient quantity or size including but not limited to: 
(1)  Ashes. 
(2)  Cinders. 
(3)  Sand. 
(4)  Mud. 
(5)  Straw. 
(6)  Shavings. 
(7)  Metal. 
(8)  Glass. 
(9)  Rags. 
(10)  Feathers. 
(11)  Tar. 
(12)  Plastics. 
(13)  Wood. 
(14)  Unground garbage. 
(15)  Whole blood. 
(16)  Paunch manure. 
(17)  Hair and fleshings. 
(18)  Entrails. 
(19)  Paper products, either whole or ground by garbage grinders. 
(20)  Slops. 
(21)  Chemical residue. 
(22)  Bulk solids. 
(Ord. No. 83-13-49/III, § 9, 5-24-83) 
Sec. 29-75. - Approving authority requirements. 
(a)  If discharges or proposed discharges to public sewers may: 
(1)  Deleteriously affect wastewater facilities, processes, equipment, or receiving waters. 
(2)  Create a hazard to life or health. 
(3)  Create a public nuisance. 
(4)  Create treatment cists in excess of those for normal domestic sewage. 
(5)  Constitute an average daily volume of one (1) percent or more of the average daily wastewater flow of the city. 
(6)  Contain any of the prohibited wastes described, all or in part, in sections 29-68 through 29-74. 
The city manager shall require: 
a.  Pretreatment to an acceptable condition for discharge to the public sewers. 
b.  Control over the quantities and rates of discharge. 
c.  Payment to cover the cost of handling and treating the wastes, provided such wastes are amenable to the wastewater treatment plant operated by the city. 
d.  Review and approval of the city manager prior to the issuance of permit to discharge to the public sewers. 
(b)  Where necessary in the opinion of the city manager, the owner of the premises from which wastes, as described in subsection (a), are originated, issued, or discharged, shall provide at his own expense, such preliminary treatment as may be necessary to reduce the biochemical oxygen demand and suspend solids to the concentrations of normal domestic sewage, or to reduce the objectionable characteristics or constituents to within the maximum limits outlined in sections 29-68 through 29-74. 
(c)  If pretreatment or control is required, the city manager shall review and approve the design and installation of the equipment and processes. Plans, specifications, and other pertinent information relating to proposed pretreatment facilities shall be submitted for the approval of the city manager and no construction of such facilities shall be commenced until said approvals are obtained in writing. This provision shall not constitute a responsibility of the city for the designing or warranting the performance of such systems. 
(d)  The design and installation of equipment and processes for pretreatment of waste must conform to all applicable statutes, codes, ordinances and other laws. 
(e)  Any person responsible for a discharge requiring pretreatment, flow equalizing, or other facilities shall provide and maintain the facilities in effective operating condition at his own expense. 
(f)  Discharges requiring a trap include: 
(1)  Grease or waste containing grease in amounts that will impede or stop the flow in the public sewers. 
(2)  Oil. 
(3)  Sand. 
(4)  Flammable wastes. 
(5)  Other harmful ingredients. 
(g)  Any person responsible for discharges requiring a trap shall at his own expense and as required by the city manager: 
(1)  Provide equipment and facilities of a type and capacity approved by the city manager. 
(2)  Locate the trap in a manner that provides ready and easy accessibility for cleaning and inspection. 
(3)  Maintain the trap in effective operating condition. 
(h)  The city manager is entitled to determine whether a discharge or proposed discharge is included under subsection (a) of this section. 
(i)  The city manager shall reject wastes when he determines that a discharge does not meet the requirements of subsection (a). 
(Ord. No. 83-13-49/III, § 10, 5-24-83) 
Sec. 29-76. - User charge system. 
(a)  Persons making discharges of industrial waste into the city sewer system shall pay a charge to cover all costs of collection and treatment. 
(b)  When discharges of any waste into the city sewer system are approved by the city manager, the city or its authorized representative shall enter into an agreement or arrangement providing: 
(1)  The terms of acceptance by the city. 
(2)  Payment by the person making the discharge, in accordance with the user charge system as established in subsection (e). 
(3)  Sewer connection procedures and requirements shall be in accordance with this Code, technical codes adopted by this Code and other applicable ordinances of the city. 
(4)  A sewer application approved with the connection fee paid. 
(5)  Construction of sewer connections shall be approved by city inspectors prior to sewer use. 
(c)  Each user of the wastewater treatment system will be notified at least annually, in conjunction with a regular sewer bill, of the rate and that portions of user charges or ad valorem taxes which are attributable to the operation and maintenance of the wastewater treatment system. 
(d)  The city will apply excess revenues collected from a class of users to the cost of operation and maintenance attributable to that class for the next year and adjust the rates accordingly. 
(e)  The basis for the industrial waste charge shall be at the rate of $0.025 × millions of gallons of wastewater × [(B.).D. - 350 + Suspended Solids - 300) (8.34)]. Such rate shall continue until changed by action of the governing body of the city. If the concentration of biochemical oxygen demand or suspended solids is less than the concentration of normal domestic sewage, there shall be no industrial waste charge, nor shall there be a credit given to the total industrial waste charge. 
(Ord. No. 83-13-49/III, § 11, 5-24-83) 
Sec. 29-77. - Sampling, testing and flow measurement of industrial waste. 
(a)  Within one hundred twenty (120) days from the date of receipt of written notice from the city, the owner of any property or premises from which industrial wastes are originated, issued, or discharged shall install a suitable manhole in the drain which delivers his wastes into the public sewer to facilitate observation, sampling and the measurement of the wastes. Such a manhole may be a prerequisite to granting a permit in the case of future connection involving industrial wastes. Such manhole, when required, shall be accessibly and safely located and shall be constructed in accordance with plans approved by the city. The manhole shall be installed by the owner at his own expense, near the point where his drain is connected to the public sewer, and shall be maintained by him so as to be safe and accessible at all times. 
(b)  Sampling shall be conducted according to customarily accepted methods, reflecting the effect of constituents upon the sewage works and determining the existence of hazards to health, life, limb, and property. The particular analysis involved will determine whether a twenty-four (24) hour composite sample from all outfalls of a premises is appropriate or whether a grab sample or samples should be taken. Normally, but not always, biochemical oxygen demand and suspended solids analyses are obtained from twenty-four (24) hour composites of all outfalls. Where applicable, sixteen (16) hour, eight (8) hour or some other period may be required. Periodic grab samples are used to determine pH and oil and grease. 
(c)  Examination and analyses of the characteristics of waters and wastes required by this division shall be: 
(1)  Conducted in accordance with the latest edition of Standard Methods; and 
(2)  Determined from suitable samples taken at the control manhole provided or other control point authorized by the approving authority. 
(d)  Biochemical oxygen demand and suspended solids shall be determined from composite sampling, except to detect unauthorized discharges. 
(e)  Tests upon which industrial waste charges, described in section 29-76, are based shall be performed annually, with costs incurred by the city. Costs for tests performed at intervals less than one (1) year, or for purposes other than industrial waste discharge computations, shall be paid according to an agreement between the owner involved and the city. 
(f)  The volume of industrial waste flows shall be taken as a portion of the metered water consumption, with suitable allowance for evaporation, inclusion on products, etc., agreed upon by the owner involved and the city. The metered water consumption shall be that volume recorded by the city, where public water supply is used, together with authentic records of consumption from any private sources used. Measurement of water from private sources shall be done at the expense of the owner in a manner approved by the city. 
(g)  At the discretion of the owner, industrial waste flows may be measured directly by a suitable device, provided and maintained by the owner and approved by the city. 
(Ord. No. 83-13-49/III, § 12, 5-24-83) 
Sec. 29-78. - Power to enter property. 
(a)  The superintendent and other duly authorized employees of the city bearing proper credentials and identification are entitled to enter any public or private property at any reasonable time for the purpose of enforcing this ordinance. 
(b)  Anyone acting under this authority shall observe the establishment's rules and regulations concerning safety, internal security and fire protection. 
(c)  Except when caused by negligence or failure of any person to maintain safe conditions, the city shall indemnify the person against loss or damage to their property by city employees and against liability claims and demands for personal injury or property damages asserted against the person growing out of the sampling operation. 
(d)  The superintendent and other duly authorized employees of the city bearing proper credentials and identification are entitled to enter all private properties through which the city holds a negotiated easement for the purposes of: 
(1)  Inspection, observation, measurement, sampling or repair. 
(2)  Maintenance of any portion of the sewage system lying within the easements. 
(3)  Conducting any other authorized activity. All activities shall be conducted in full accordance with the terms of the negotiated easement pertaining to the private property involved. 
(e)  No person acting under authority of this provision may inquire into any processes including metallurgical, chemical, oil refining, ceramic, paper or other industries beyond that point having a direct bearing on the kind and source of discharge to the public sewers. 
(Ord. No. 83-13-49/III, § 13, 5-24-83) 
Sec. 29-79. - Authority to disconnect service. 
(a)  The city may terminate water and wastewater disposal service and disconnect a customer from the system when:
